ZAP Scanning Report

Summary of Alerts

Risk LevelNumber of Alerts
High1
Medium82
Low1349
Informational0

Alert Detail

High (Medium)Remote OS Command Injection

Description

Attack technique used for unauthorized execution of operating system commands. This attack is possible when an application accepts untrusted input to build operating system commands in an insecure manner involving improper data sanitization, and/or improper calling of external programs.
URL
https://och.berkeley.edu/registration/guest
Parameter
move-in-year
Attack
2017|timeout /T {0}

Solution

If at all possible, use library calls rather than external processes to recreate the desired functionality.

Run your code in a "jail" or similar sandbox environment that enforces strict boundaries between the process and the operating system. This may effectively restrict which files can be accessed in a particular directory or which commands can be executed by your software.

OS-level examples include the Unix chroot jail, AppArmor, and SELinux. In general, managed code may provide some protection. For example, java.io.FilePermission in the Java SecurityManager allows you to specify restrictions on file operations.

This may not be a feasible solution, and it only limits the impact to the operating system; the rest of your application may still be subject to compromise.

For any data that will be used to generate a command to be executed, keep as much of that data out of external control as possible. For example, in web applications, this may require storing the command locally in the session's state instead of sending it out to the client in a hidden form field.

Use a vetted library or framework that does not allow this weakness to occur or provides constructs that make this weakness easier to avoid.

For example, consider using the ESAPI Encoding control or a similar tool, library, or framework. These will help the programmer encode outputs in a manner less prone to error.

If you need to use dynamically-generated query strings or commands in spite of the risk, properly quote arguments and escape any special characters within those arguments. The most conservative approach is to escape or filter all characters that do not pass an extremely strict whitelist (such as everything that is not alphanumeric or white space). If some special characters are still needed, such as white space, wrap each argument in quotes after the escaping/filtering step. Be careful of argument injection.

If the program to be executed allows arguments to be specified within an input file or from standard input, then consider using that mode to pass arguments instead of the command line.

If available, use structured mechanisms that automatically enforce the separation between data and code. These mechanisms may be able to provide the relevant quoting, encoding, and validation automatically, instead of relying on the developer to provide this capability at every point where output is generated.

Some languages offer multiple functions that can be used to invoke commands. Where possible, identify any function that invokes a command shell using a single string, and replace it with a function that requires individual arguments. These functions typically perform appropriate quoting and filtering of arguments. For example, in C, the system() function accepts a string that contains the entire command to be executed, whereas execl(), execve(), and others require an array of strings, one for each argument. In Windows, CreateProcess() only accepts one command at a time. In Perl, if system() is provided with an array of arguments, then it will quote each of the arguments.

Assume all input is malicious. Use an "accept known good" input validation strategy, i.e., use a whitelist of acceptable inputs that strictly conform to specifications. Reject any input that does not strictly conform to specifications, or transform it into something that does. Do not rely exclusively on looking for malicious or malformed inputs (i.e., do not rely on a blacklist). However, blacklists can be useful for detecting potential attacks or determining which inputs are so malformed that they should be rejected outright.

When performing input validation, consider all potentially relevant properties, including length, type of input, the full range of acceptable values, missing or extra inputs, syntax, consistency across related fields, and conformance to business rules. As an example of business rule logic, "boat" may be syntactically valid because it only contains alphanumeric characters, but it is not valid if you are expecting colors such as "red" or "blue."

When constructing OS command strings, use stringent whitelists that limit the character set based on the expected value of the parameter in the request. This will indirectly limit the scope of an attack, but this technique is less important than proper output encoding and escaping.

Note that proper output encoding, escaping, and quoting is the most effective solution for preventing OS command injection, although input validation may provide some defense-in-depth. This is because it effectively limits what will appear in output. Input validation will not always prevent OS command injection, especially if you are required to support free-form text fields that could contain arbitrary characters. For example, when invoking a mail program, you might need to allow the subject field to contain otherwise-dangerous inputs like ";" and ">" characters, which would need to be escaped or otherwise handled. In this case, stripping the character might reduce the risk of OS command injection, but it would produce incorrect behavior because the subject field would not be recorded as the user intended. This might seem to be a minor inconvenience, but it could be more important when the program relies on well-structured subject lines in order to pass messages to other components.

Even if you make a mistake in your validation (such as forgetting one out of 100 input fields), appropriate encoding is still likely to protect you from injection-based attacks. As long as it is not done in isolation, input validation is still a useful technique, since it may significantly reduce your attack surface, allow you to detect some attacks, and provide other security benefits that proper encoding does not address.

Reference

http://cwe.mitre.org/data/definitions/78.html

https://www.owasp.org/index.php/Command_Injection

CWE Id

78

WASC Id

31

Medium (Medium)X-Frame-Options Header Not Set

Description

X-Frame-Options header is not included in the HTTP response to protect against 'ClickJacking' attacks.
URL
https://och.berkeley.edu/

Solution

Most modern Web browsers support the X-Frame-Options HTTP header. Ensure it's set on all web pages returned by your site (if you expect the page to be framed only by pages on your server (e.g. it's part of a FRAMESET) then you'll want to use SAMEORIGIN, otherwise if you never expect the page to be framed, you should use DENY. ALLOW-FROM allows specific websites to frame the web page in supported web browsers).

Reference

http://blogs.msdn.com/b/ieinternals/archive/2010/03/30/combating-clickjacking-with-x-frame-options.aspx

Medium (Medium)X-Frame-Options Header Not Set

Description

X-Frame-Options header is not included in the HTTP response to protect against 'ClickJacking' attacks.
URL
https://och.berkeley.edu/robots.txt

Solution

Most modern Web browsers support the X-Frame-Options HTTP header. Ensure it's set on all web pages returned by your site (if you expect the page to be framed only by pages on your server (e.g. it's part of a FRAMESET) then you'll want to use SAMEORIGIN, otherwise if you never expect the page to be framed, you should use DENY. ALLOW-FROM allows specific websites to frame the web page in supported web browsers).

Reference

http://blogs.msdn.com/b/ieinternals/archive/2010/03/30/combating-clickjacking-with-x-frame-options.aspx

Medium (Medium)X-Frame-Options Header Not Set

Description

X-Frame-Options header is not included in the HTTP response to protect against 'ClickJacking' attacks.
URL
https://och.berkeley.edu/sitemap.xml

Solution

Most modern Web browsers support the X-Frame-Options HTTP header. Ensure it's set on all web pages returned by your site (if you expect the page to be framed only by pages on your server (e.g. it's part of a FRAMESET) then you'll want to use SAMEORIGIN, otherwise if you never expect the page to be framed, you should use DENY. ALLOW-FROM allows specific websites to frame the web page in supported web browsers).

Reference

http://blogs.msdn.com/b/ieinternals/archive/2010/03/30/combating-clickjacking-with-x-frame-options.aspx

Medium (Medium)Application Error Disclosure

Description

This page contains an error/warning message that may disclose sensitive information like the location of the file that produced the unhandled exception. This information can be used to launch further attacks against the web application. The alert could be a false positive if the error message is found inside a documentation page.
URL
https://och.berkeley.edu/tracking
Parameter
N/A
Evidence
HTTP 500 Internal server error

Solution

Review the source code of this page. Implement custom error pages. Consider implementing a mechanism to provide a unique error reference/identifier to the client (browser) while logging the details on the server side and not exposing them to the user.

Reference

CWE Id

200

WASC Id

13

X-Frame-Options header is not included in the HTTP response to protect against 'ClickJacking' attacks.
URL
https://och.berkeley.edu/v2/js/registration.min.1430390459.js

Solution

Most modern Web browsers support the X-Frame-Options HTTP header. Ensure it's set on all web pages returned by your site (if you expect the page to be framed only by pages on your server (e.g. it's part of a FRAMESET) then you'll want to use SAMEORIGIN, otherwise if you never expect the page to be framed, you should use DENY. ALLOW-FROM allows specific websites to frame the web page in supported web browsers).

Reference

http://blogs.msdn.com/b/ieinternals/archive/2010/03/30/combating-clickjacking-with-x-frame-options.aspx

Reference

http://blogs.msdn.com/b/ieinternals/archive/2010/03/30/combating-clickjacking-with-x-frame-options.aspx

Medium (Medium)X-Frame-Options Header Not Set

Description

X-Frame-Options header is not included in the HTTP response to protect against 'ClickJacking' attacks.
URL
https://och.berkeley.edu/help/article/can-i-post-a-sublet-on-the-message-boards

Solution

Most modern Web browsers support the X-Frame-Options HTTP header. Ensure it's set on all web pages returned by your site (if you expect the page to be framed only by pages on your server (e.g. it's part of a FRAMESET) then you'll want to use SAMEORIGIN, otherwise if you never expect the page to be framed, you should use DENY. ALLOW-FROM allows specific websites to frame the web page in supported web browsers).

Reference

http://blogs.msdn.com/b/ieinternals/archive/2010/03/30/combating-clickjacking-with-x-frame-options.aspx

https://och.berkeley.edu/help/article/create-account

ALLOW-FROM allows specific websites to frame the web page in supported web browsers).

http://blogs.msdn.com/b/ieinternals/archive/2010/03/30/combating-clickjacking-with-x-frame-options.aspx

Low (Medium)Cookie set without HttpOnly flag

Description

A cookie has been set without the HttpOnly flag, which means that the cookie can be accessed by JavaScript. If a malicious script can be run on this page then the cookie will be accessible and can be transmitted to another site. If this is a session cookie then session hijacking may be possible.
URL
http://och.berkeley.edu/
Parameter
PHPSESSID=pictv7hahc1pkusdqgfj6d86k4; path=/
Evidence
PHPSESSID=pictv7hahc1pkusdqgfj6d86k4; path=/

Solution

Ensure that the HttpOnly flag is set for all cookies.

Reference

www.owasp.org/index.php/HttpOnly

WASC Id

13

Low (Medium)Incomplete or No Cache-control and Pragma HTTP Header Set

Description

The cache-control and pragma HTTP header have not been set properly or are missing allowing the browser and proxies to cache content.
URL
https://och.berkeley.edu/
Evidence
no-store, no-cache, must-revalidate, post-check=0, pre-check=0

Solution

Whenever possible ensure the cache-control HTTP header is set with no-cache, no-store, must-revalidate, private; and that the pragma HTTP header is set with no-cache.

Reference

https://www.owasp.org/index.php/Session_Management_Cheat_Sheet#Web_Content_Caching

WASC Id

13

Low (Medium)Cookie set without secure flag

Description

A cookie has been set without the secure flag, which means that the cookie can be accessed via unencrypted connections.
URL
https://och.berkeley.edu/
Parameter
PHPSESSID=g3vrvr1j1lrb53ubl5r8gjh7f6; path=/
Evidence
PHPSESSID=g3vrvr1j1lrb53ubl5r8gjh7f6; path=/

Solution

Whenever a cookie contains sensitive information or is a session token, then it should always be passed using an encrypted tunnel. Ensure that the secure flag is set for cookies containing such sensitive information.

Reference

http://www.owasp.org/index.php/Testing_for_cookies_attributes_(OWASP-SM-002)

WASC Id

Low (Medium)Cross-Domain JavaScript Source File Inclusion

Description

The page at the following URL includes one or more script files from a third-party domain
URL
https://och.berkeley.edu/
Parameter
//ajax.googleapis.com/ajax/libs/jquery/1.11.1/jquery.min.js
Evidence
//ajax.googleapis.com/ajax/libs/jquery/1.11.1/jquery.min.js

Solution

Ensure JavaScript source files are loaded from only trusted sources, and the sources can't be controlled by end users of the application

Reference

Low (Medium)Cross-Domain JavaScript Source File Inclusion

Description

The page at the following URL includes one or more script files from a third-party domain
URL
https://och.berkeley.edu/
Parameter
//translate.google.com/translate_a/element.js?cb=googleTranslateElementInit
Evidence
//translate.google.com/translate_a/element.js?cb=googleTranslateElementInit

Solution

Ensure JavaScript source files are loaded from only trusted sources, and the sources can't be controlled by end users of the application

Reference

Low (Medium)Web Browser XSS Protection Not Enabled

Description

Web Browser XSS Protection is not enabled, or is disabled by the configuration of the 'X-XSS-Protection' HTTP response header on the web server
URL
https://och.berkeley.edu/
Other information
The X-XSS-Protection HTTP response header allows the web server to enable or disable the web browser's XSS protection mechanism. The following values would attempt to enable it: X-XSS-Protection: 1; mode=block X-XSS-Protection: 1; report=http://www.example.com/xss The following values would disable it: X-XSS-Protection: 0 The X-XSS-Protection HTTP response header is currently supported on Internet Explorer, Chrome and Safari (WebKit). Note that this alert is only raised if the response body could potentially contain an XSS payload (with a text-based content type, with a non-zero length).

Solution

Ensure that the web browser's XSS filter is enabled, by setting the X-XSS-Protection HTTP response header to '1'.

Reference

https://www.owasp.org/index.php/XSS_(Cross_Site_Scripting)_Prevention_Cheat_Sheet

https://blog.veracode.com/2014/03/guidelines-for-setting-security-headers/

CWE Id

933

WASC Id

14

Low (Medium)X-Content-Type-Options Header Missing

Description

The Anti-MIME-Sniffing header X-Content-Type-Options was not set to 'nosniff'. This allows older versions of Internet Explorer and Chrome to perform MIME-sniffing on the response body, potentially causing the response body to be interpreted and displayed as a content type other than the declared content type. Current (early 2014) and legacy versions of Firefox will use the declared content type (if one is set), rather than performing MIME-sniffing.
URL
https://och.berkeley.edu/
Other information
This issue still applies to error type pages (401, 403, 500, etc) as those pages are often still affected by injection issues, in which case there is still concern for browsers sniffing pages away from their actual content type.

Solution

Ensure that the application/web server sets the Content-Type header appropriately, and that it sets the X-Content-Type-Options header to 'nosniff' for all web pages.

If possible, ensure that the end user uses a standards-compliant and modern web browser that does not perform MIME-sniffing at all, or that can be directed by the web application/web server to not perform MIME-sniffing.

Reference

http://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/ie/gg622941%28v=vs.85%29.aspx

https://www.owasp.org/index.php/List_of_useful_HTTP_headers

WASC Id

15

Low (Medium)Incomplete or No Cache-control and Pragma HTTP Header Set

Description

The cache-control and pragma HTTP header have not been set properly or are missing allowing the browser and proxies to cache content.
URL
https://och.berkeley.edu/robots.txt
Evidence
no-store, no-cache, must-revalidate, post-check=0, pre-check=0

Solution

Whenever possible ensure the cache-control HTTP header is set with no-cache, no-store, must-revalidate, private; and that the pragma HTTP header is set with no-cache.

Reference

https://www.owasp.org/index.php/Session_Management_Cheat_Sheet#Web_Content_Caching

CWE Id

525

https://och.berkeley.edu/robots.txt
Parameter
incap_ses_124_496857=F9PkT6YNoxAaUb5nPoq4Adzw1VYAAAAABIF6qBVwKtbLLztxrOM+LA==; path=/; Domain=.berkeley.edu
Evidence
incap_ses_124_496857=F9PkT6YNoxAaUb5nPoq4Adzw1VYAAAAABIF6qBVwKtbLLztxrOM+LA==; path=/; Domain=.berkeley.edu

Solution

Whenever a cookie contains sensitive information or is a session token, then it should always be passed using an encrypted tunnel. Ensure that the secure flag is set for cookies containing such sensitive information.

Reference

http://www.owasp.org/index.php/Testing_for_cookies_attributes_(OWASP-SM-002)

WASC Id

13

Low (Medium)Web Browser XSS Protection Not Enabled

Description

Web Browser XSS Protection is not enabled, or is disabled by the configuration of the 'X-XSS-Protection' HTTP response header on the web server
URL
https://och.berkeley.edu/robots.txt
Other information
The X-XSS-Protection HTTP response header allows the web server to enable or disable the web browser's XSS protection mechanism. The following values would attempt to enable it: X-XSS-Protection: 1; mode=block X-XSS-Protection: 1; report=http://www.example.com/xss The following values would disable it: X-XSS-Protection: 0 The X-XSS-Protection HTTP response header is currently supported on Internet Explorer, Chrome and Safari (WebKit). Note that this alert is only raised if the response body could potentially contain an XSS payload (with a text-based content type, with a non-zero length).

Solution

Ensure that the web browser's XSS filter is enabled, by setting the X-XSS-Protection HTTP response header to '1'.

Reference

https://www.owasp.org/index.php/XSS_(Cross_Site_Scripting)_Prevention_Cheat_Sheet

https://blog.veracode.com/2014/03/guidelines-for-setting-security-headers/

CWE Id

933

WASC Id

14

Low (Medium)X-Content-Type-Options Header Missing

Description

The Anti-MIME-Sniffing header X-Content-Type-Options was not set to 'nosniff'. This allows older versions of Internet Explorer and Chrome to perform MIME-sniffing on the response body, potentially causing the response body to be interpreted and displayed as a content type other than the declared content type. Current (early 2014) and legacy versions of Firefox will use the declared content type (if one is set), rather than performing MIME-sniffing.
URL
https://och.berkeley.edu/robots.txt
Other information
This issue still applies to error type pages (401, 403, 500, etc) as those pages are often still affected by injection issues, in which case there is still concern for browsers sniffing pages away from their actual content type.

Solution

Ensure that the application/web server sets the Content-Type header appropriately, and that it sets the X-Content-Type-Options header to 'nosniff' for all web pages.

If possible, ensure that the end user uses a standards-compliant and modern web browser that does not perform MIME-sniffing at all, or that can be directed by the web application/web server to not perform MIME-sniffing.

Reference

http://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/ie/gg622941%28v=vs.85%29.aspx

https://www.owasp.org/index.php/List_of_useful_HTTP_headers

WASC Id

15

Low (Medium)Incomplete or No Cache-control and Pragma HTTP Header Set

Description

The cache-control and pragma HTTP header have not been set properly or are missing allowing the browser and proxies to cache content.
URL
https://och.berkeley.edu/sitemap.xml
Evidence
no-store, no-cache, must-revalidate, post-check=0, pre-check=0

Solution

Whenever possible ensure the cache-control HTTP header is set with no-cache, no-store, must-revalidate, private; and that the pragma HTTP header is set with no-cache.

Reference

https://www.owasp.org/index.php/Session_Management_Cheat_Sheet#Web_Content_Caching

CWE Id

525

Low (Medium)Cookie set without HttpOnly flag

Description

A cookie has been set without the HttpOnly flag, which means that the cookie can be accessed by JavaScript. If a malicious script can be run on this page then the cookie will be accessible and can be transmitted to another site. If this is a session cookie then session hijacking may be possible.
URL
https://och.berkeley.edu/sitemap.xml
Parameter
PHPSESSID=841mkpsjcnpi31qm6u54qp1js3; path=/
Evidence
PHPSESSID=841mkpsjcnpi31qm6u54qp1js3; path=/

Solution

Ensure that the HttpOnly flag is set for all cookies.

Reference

www.owasp.org/index.php/HttpOnly

WASC Id

13

Low (Medium)Cross-Domain JavaScript Source File Inclusion

Description

The page at the following URL includes one or more script files from a third-party domain
URL
https://och.berkeley.edu/sitemap.xml
Parameter
//ajax.googleapis.com/ajax/libs/jquery/1.11.1/jquery.min.js
Evidence
//ajax.googleapis.com/ajax/libs/jquery/1.11.1/jquery.min.js

Solution

Ensure JavaScript source files are loaded from only trusted sources, and the sources can't be controlled by end users of the application

Reference

Low (Medium)Cross-Domain JavaScript Source File Inclusion

Description

The page at the following URL includes one or more script files from a third-party domain
URL
https://och.berkeley.edu/sitemap.xml
Parameter
//translate.google.com/translate_a/element.js?cb=googleTranslateElementInit
Evidence
//translate.google.com/translate_a/element.js?cb=googleTranslateElementInit

Solution

Ensure JavaScript source files are loaded from only trusted sources, and the sources can't be controlled by end users of the application

Reference

Low (Medium)Web Browser XSS Protection Not Enabled

Description

Web Browser XSS Protection is not enabled, or is disabled by the configuration of the 'X-XSS-Protection' HTTP response header on the web server
URL
https://och.berkeley.edu/sitemap.xml
Other information
The X-XSS-Protection HTTP response header allows the web server to enable or disable the web browser's XSS protection mechanism. The following values would attempt to enable it: X-XSS-Protection: 1; mode=block X-XSS-Protection: 1; report=http://www.example.com/xss The following values would disable it: X-XSS-Protection: 0 The X-XSS-Protection HTTP response header is currently supported on Internet Explorer, Chrome and Safari (WebKit). Note that this alert is only raised if the response body could potentially contain an XSS payload (with a text-based content type, with a non-zero length).

Solution

Ensure that the web browser's XSS filter is enabled, by setting the X-XSS-Protection HTTP response header to '1'.

Reference

https://www.owasp.org/index.php/XSS_(Cross_Site_Scripting)_Prevention_Cheat_Sheet

https://blog.veracode.com/2014/03/guidelines-for-setting-security-headers/

incap_ses_124_496857=/2DdEy5IKD0aUb5nPoq4Ad7w1VYAAAAAmI95ms/uxm7XMZzsRDtsPw==; path=/; Domain=.berkeley.edu
Evidence
incap_ses_124_496857=/2DdEy5IKD0aUb5nPoq4Ad7w1VYAAAAAmI95ms/uxm7XMZzsRDtsPw==; path=/; Domain=.berkeley.edu

Solution

Whenever a cookie contains sensitive information or is a session token, then it should always be passed using an encrypted tunnel. Ensure that the secure flag is set for cookies containing such sensitive information.

Reference

http://www.owasp.org/index.php/Testing_for_cookies_attributes_(OWASP-SM-002)

WASC Id

13

Low (Medium)Cookie set without HttpOnly flag

Description

A cookie has been set without the HttpOnly flag, which means that the cookie can be accessed by JavaScript. If a malicious script can be run on this page then the cookie will be accessible and can be transmitted to another site. If this is a session cookie then session hijacking may be possible.
URL
https://och.berkeley.edu/property/rental/filter
Parameter
PHPSESSID=3h0ca5mpdc9o52lfoiksofpkm6; path=/
Evidence
PHPSESSID=3h0ca5mpdc9o52lfoiksofpkm6; path=/

Solution

Ensure that the HttpOnly flag is set for all cookies.

Reference

www.owasp.org/index.php/HttpOnly

WASC Id

13

Low (Medium)Incomplete or No Cache-control and Pragma HTTP Header Set

Description

The cache-control and pragma HTTP header have not been set properly or are missing allowing the browser and proxies to cache content.
URL
https://och.berkeley.edu/tracking
Evidence
no-store, no-cache, must-revalidate, post-check=0, pre-check=0

Solution

Whenever possible ensure the cache-control HTTP header is set with no-cache, no-store, must-revalidate, private; and that the pragma HTTP header is set with no-cache.

Reference

https://www.owasp.org/index.php/Session_Management_Cheat_Sheet#Web_Content_Caching

WASC Id

13

Low (Medium)Cross-Domain JavaScript Source File Inclusion

Description

The page at the following URL includes one or more script files from a third-party domain
URL
https://och.berkeley.edu/tracking
Parameter
//ajax.googleapis.com/ajax/libs/jquery/1.11.1/jquery.min.js
Evidence
//ajax.googleapis.com/ajax/libs/jquery/1.11.1/jquery.min.js

Solution

Ensure JavaScript source files are loaded from only trusted sources, and the sources can't be controlled by end users of the application

Reference

Low (Medium)Cross-Domain JavaScript Source File Inclusion

Description

The page at the following URL includes one or more script files from a third-party domain
URL
https://och.berkeley.edu/tracking
Parameter
//translate.google.com/translate_a/element.js?cb=googleTranslateElementInit
Evidence
//translate.google.com/translate_a/element.js?cb=googleTranslateElementInit

Solution

Ensure JavaScript source files are loaded from only trusted sources, and the sources can't be controlled by end users of the application

Reference

Low (Medium)Web Browser XSS Protection Not Enabled

Description

Web Browser XSS Protection is not enabled, or is disabled by the configuration of the 'X-XSS-Protection' HTTP response header on the web server
URL
https://och.berkeley.edu/tracking
Other information
The X-XSS-Protection HTTP response header allows the web server to enable or disable the web browser's XSS protection mechanism. The following values would attempt to enable it: X-XSS-Protection: 1; mode=block X-XSS-Protection: 1; report=http://www.example.com/xss The following values would disable it: X-XSS-Protection: 0 The X-XSS-Protection HTTP response header is currently supported on Internet Explorer, Chrome and Safari (WebKit). Note that this alert is only raised if the response body could potentially contain an XSS payload (with a text-based content type, with a non-zero length).

Solution

Ensure that the web browser's XSS filter is enabled, by setting the X-XSS-Protection HTTP response header to '1'.

Reference

https://www.owasp.org/index.php/XSS_(Cross_Site_Scripting)_Prevention_Cheat_Sheet

https://blog.veracode.com/2014/03/guidelines-for-setting-security-headers/

CWE Id

933

WASC Id

14

Low (Medium)X-Content-Type-Options Header Missing

Description

The Anti-MIME-Sniffing header X-Content-Type-Options was not set to 'nosniff'. This allows older versions of Internet Explorer and Chrome to perform MIME-sniffing on the response body, potentially causing the response body to be interpreted and displayed as a content type other than the declared content type. Current (early 2014) and legacy versions of Firefox will use the declared content type (if one is set), rather than performing MIME-sniffing.
URL
https://och.berkeley.edu/tracking
Other information
This issue still applies to error type pages (401, 403, 500, etc) as those pages are often still affected by injection issues, in which case there is still concern for browsers sniffing pages away from their actual content type.

Solution

Ensure that the application/web server sets the Content-Type header appropriately, and that it sets the X-Content-Type-Options header to 'nosniff' for all web pages.

If possible, ensure that the end user uses a standards-compliant and modern web browser that does not perform MIME-sniffing at all, or that can be directed by the web application/web server to not perform MIME-sniffing.

Reference

http://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/ie/gg622941%28v=vs.85%29.aspx

https://www.owasp.org/index.php/List_of_useful_HTTP_headers

WASC Id

15

Low (Medium)Incomplete or No Cache-control and Pragma HTTP Header Set

Description

The cache-control and pragma HTTP header have not been set properly or are missing allowing the browser and proxies to cache content.
URL
https://och.berkeley.edu/index/cookie-test
Evidence
no-store, no-cache, must-revalidate, post-check=0, pre-check=0

Solution

Whenever possible ensure the cache-control HTTP header is set with no-cache, no-store, must-revalidate, private; and that the pragma HTTP header is set with no-cache.

Reference

https://www.owasp.org/index.php/Session_Management_Cheat_Sheet#Web_Content_Caching

CWE Id

525

https://och.berkeley.edu/index/cookie-test
Parameter
visid_incap_496857=4IND+ohuRO2GYE/C2CfhqNrw1VYAAAAAQUIPAAAAAAD7/Ds+duivzn7Oz7wJ4wfE; expires=Wed, 01 Mar 2017 12:24:07 GMT; path=/; Domain=.berkeley.edu
Evidence
visid_incap_496857=4IND+ohuRO2GYE/C2CfhqNrw1VYAAAAAQUIPAAAAAAD7/Ds+duivzn7Oz7wJ4wfE; expires=Wed, 01 Mar 2017 12:24:07 GMT; path=/; Domain=.berkeley.edu

Solution

Ensure that the HttpOnly flag is set for all cookies.

Reference

www.owasp.org/index.php/HttpOnly

WASC Id

13

Low (Medium)Cookie set without HttpOnly flag

Description

A cookie has been set without the HttpOnly flag, which means that the cookie can be accessed by JavaScript. If a malicious script can be run on this page then the cookie will be accessible and can be transmitted to another site. If this is a session cookie then session hijacking may be possible.
URL
https://och.berkeley.edu/index/cookie-test
Parameter
incap_ses_124_496857=5ugdfzgVulwaUb5nPoq4Ad/w1VYAAAAAkbDYK10XYHxUZkG3HjUC5A==; path=/; Domain=.berkeley.edu
Evidence
incap_ses_124_496857=5ugdfzgVulwaUb5nPoq4Ad/w1VYAAAAAkbDYK10XYHxUZkG3HjUC5A==; path=/; Domain=.berkeley.edu

Solution

Ensure that the HttpOnly flag is set for all cookies.

Reference

www.owasp.org/index.php/HttpOnly

WASC Id

13

Low (Medium)Cookie set without secure flag

Description

A cookie has been set without the secure flag, which means that the cookie can be accessed via unencrypted connections.
URL
https://och.berkeley.edu/index/cookie-test
Parameter
PHPSESSID=ojdq2b7dc0trqh7lnk6n843it4; path=/
Evidence
PHPSESSID=ojdq2b7dc0trqh7lnk6n843it4; path=/

Solution

Whenever a cookie contains sensitive information or is a session token, then it should always be passed using an encrypted tunnel. Ensure that the secure flag is set for cookies containing such sensitive information.

Reference

http://www.owasp.org/index.php/Testing_for_cookies_attributes_(OWASP-SM-002)

WASC Id

13

Description

A cookie has been set without the secure flag, which means that the cookie can be accessed via unencrypted connections.
URL
https://och.berkeley.edu/index/cookie-test
Parameter
visid_incap_496857=4IND+ohuRO2GYE/C2CfhqNrw1VYAAAAAQUIPAAAAAAD7/Ds+duivzn7Oz7wJ4wfE; expires=Wed, 01 Mar 2017 12:24:07 GMT; path=/; Domain=.berkeley.edu

WASC Id

13

Low (Medium)Cookie set without secure flag

Description

A cookie has been set without the secure flag, which means that the cookie can be accessed via unencrypted connections.
URL
https://och.berkeley.edu/index/cookie-test
Parameter
incap_ses_124_496857=5ugdfzgVulwaUb5nPoq4Ad/w1VYAAAAAkbDYK10XYHxUZkG3HjUC5A==; path=/; Domain=.berkeley.edu
Evidence
incap_ses_124_496857=5ugdfzgVulwaUb5nPoq4Ad/w1VYAAAAAkbDYK10XYHxUZkG3HjUC5A==; path=/; Domain=.berkeley.edu

Solution

Whenever a cookie contains sensitive information or is a session token, then it should always be passed using an encrypted tunnel. Ensure that the secure flag is set for cookies containing such sensitive information.

Reference

http://www.owasp.org/index.php/Testing_for_cookies_attributes_(OWASP-SM-002)

WASC Id

13

Low (Medium)Web Browser XSS Protection Not Enabled

Description

Web Browser XSS Protection is not enabled, or is disabled by the configuration of the 'X-XSS-Protection' HTTP response header on the web server
URL
https://och.berkeley.edu/index/cookie-test
Other information
The X-XSS-Protection HTTP response header allows the web server to enable or disable the web browser's XSS protection mechanism. The following values would attempt to enable it: X-XSS-Protection: 1; mode=block X-XSS-Protection: 1; report=http://www.example.com/xss The following values would disable it: X-XSS-Protection: 0 The X-XSS-Protection HTTP response header is currently supported on Internet Explorer, Chrome and Safari (WebKit). Note that this alert is only raised if the response body could potentially contain an XSS payload (with a text-based content type, with a non-zero length).

Solution

Ensure that the web browser's XSS filter is enabled, by setting the X-XSS-Protection HTTP response header to '1'.

Reference

https://www.owasp.org/index.php/XSS_(Cross_Site_Scripting)_Prevention_Cheat_Sheet

https://blog.veracode.com/2014/03/guidelines-for-setting-security-headers/

CWE Id

933

WASC Id

14

Low (Medium)X-Content-Type-Options Header Missing

Description

The Anti-MIME-Sniffing header X-Content-Type-Options was not set to 'nosniff'. This allows older versions of Internet Explorer and Chrome to perform MIME-sniffing on the response body, potentially causing the response body to be interpreted and displayed as a content type other than the declared content type. Current (early 2014) and legacy versions of Firefox will use the declared content type (if one is set), rather than performing MIME-sniffing.
URL
https://och.berkeley.edu/index/cookie-test
Other information
This issue still applies to error type pages (401, 403, 500, etc) as those pages are often still affected by injection issues, in which case there is still concern for browsers sniffing pages away from their actual content type.

Solution

Ensure that the application/web server sets the Content-Type header appropriately, and that it sets the X-Content-Type-Options header to 'nosniff' for all web pages.

If possible, ensure that the end user uses a standards-compliant and modern web browser that does not perform MIME-sniffing at all, or that can be directed by the web application/web server to not perform MIME-sniffing.

Reference

http://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/ie/gg622941%28v=vs.85%29.aspx

https://www.owasp.org/index.php/List_of_useful_HTTP_headers

WASC Id

15

Low (Medium)Cookie set without HttpOnly flag

Description

A cookie has been set without the HttpOnly flag, which means that the cookie can be accessed by JavaScript. If a malicious script can be run on this page then the cookie will be accessible and can be transmitted to another site. If this is a session cookie then session hijacking may be possible.
URL
https://och.berkeley.edu/guestpm
Parameter
PHPSESSID=0aao5nfd2trvnda7ccsq8659p0; path=/
Evidence
PHPSESSID=0aao5nfd2trvnda7ccsq8659p0; path=/

Solution

Reference

www.owasp.org/index.php/HttpOnly

WASC Id

13

Low (Medium)Incomplete or No Cache-control and Pragma HTTP Header Set

Description

The cache-control and pragma HTTP header have not been set properly or are missing allowing the browser and proxies to cache content.
URL
https://och.berkeley.edu/index/external-link-notification
Evidence
no-store, no-cache, must-revalidate, post-check=0, pre-check=0

Solution

Whenever possible ensure the cache-control HTTP header is set with no-cache, no-store, must-revalidate, private; and that the pragma HTTP header is set with no-cache.

Reference

https://www.owasp.org/index.php/Session_Management_Cheat_Sheet#Web_Content_Caching

WASC Id

13

Low (Medium)Cross-Domain JavaScript Source File Inclusion

Description

The page at the following URL includes one or more script files from a third-party domain
URL
https://och.berkeley.edu/index/external-link-notification
Parameter
//ajax.googleapis.com/ajax/libs/jquery/1.11.1/jquery.min.js
Evidence
//ajax.googleapis.com/ajax/libs/jquery/1.11.1/jquery.min.js

Solution

Ensure JavaScript source files are loaded from only trusted sources, and the sources can't be controlled by end users of the application

Reference

Low (Medium)Cross-Domain JavaScript Source File Inclusion

Description

The page at the following URL includes one or more script files from a third-party domain
URL
https://och.berkeley.edu/index/external-link-notification
Parameter
//translate.google.com/translate_a/element.js?cb=googleTranslateElementInit
Evidence
//translate.google.com/translate_a/element.js?cb=googleTranslateElementInit

Solution

Ensure JavaScript source files are loaded from only trusted sources, and the sources can't be controlled by end users of the application

Reference

Low (Medium)Web Browser XSS Protection Not Enabled

Description

Web Browser XSS Protection is not enabled, or is disabled by the configuration of the 'X-XSS-Protection' HTTP response header on the web server
URL
https://och.berkeley.edu/index/external-link-notification
Other information
The X-XSS-Protection HTTP response header allows the web server to enable or disable the web browser's XSS protection mechanism. The following values would attempt to enable it: X-XSS-Protection: 1; mode=block X-XSS-Protection: 1; report=http://www.example.com/xss The following values would disable it: X-XSS-Protection: 0 The X-XSS-Protection HTTP response header is currently supported on Internet Explorer, Chrome and Safari (WebKit). Note that this alert is only raised if the response body could potentially contain an XSS payload (with a text-based content type, with a non-zero length).

Solution

Ensure that the web browser's XSS filter is enabled, by setting the X-XSS-Protection HTTP response header to '1'.

Reference

https://www.owasp.org/index.php/XSS_(Cross_Site_Scripting)_Prevention_Cheat_Sheet

https://blog.veracode.com/2014/03/guidelines-for-setting-security-headers/

CWE Id

933

WASC Id

14

Low (Medium)X-Content-Type-Options Header Missing

Description

The Anti-MIME-Sniffing header X-Content-Type-Options was not set to 'nosniff'. This allows older versions of Internet Explorer and Chrome to perform MIME-sniffing on the response body, potentially causing the response body to be interpreted and displayed as a content type other than the declared content type. Current (early 2014) and legacy versions of Firefox will use the declared content type (if one is set), rather than performing MIME-sniffing.
URL
https://och.berkeley.edu/index/external-link-notification
Other information
This issue still applies to error type pages (401, 403, 500, etc) as those pages are often still affected by injection issues, in which case there is still concern for browsers sniffing pages away from their actual content type.

Solution

Ensure that the application/web server sets the Content-Type header appropriately, and that it sets the X-Content-Type-Options header to 'nosniff' for all web pages.

If possible, ensure that the end user uses a standards-compliant and modern web browser that does not perform MIME-sniffing at all, or that can be directed by the web application/web server to not perform MIME-sniffing.

Reference

http://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/ie/gg622941%28v=vs.85%29.aspx

https://www.owasp.org/index.php/List_of_useful_HTTP_headers

visid_incap_496857=4IND+ohuRO2GYE/C2CfhqNrw1VYAAAAAQUIPAAAAAAD7/Ds+duivzn7Oz7wJ4wfE; expires=Wed, 01 Mar 2017 12:23:48 GMT; path=/; Domain=.berkeley.edu
Evidence
visid_incap_496857=4IND+ohuRO2GYE/C2CfhqNrw1VYAAAAAQUIPAAAAAAD7/Ds+duivzn7Oz7wJ4wfE; expires=Wed, 01 Mar 2017 12:23:48 GMT; path=/; Domain=.berkeley.edu

Solution

Ensure that the HttpOnly flag is set for all cookies.

Reference

www.owasp.org/index.php/HttpOnly

WASC Id

13

Low (Medium)Cookie set without HttpOnly flag

Description

A cookie has been set without the HttpOnly flag, which means that the cookie can be accessed by JavaScript. If a malicious script can be run on this page then the cookie will be accessible and can be transmitted to another site. If this is a session cookie then session hijacking may be possible.
URL
https://och.berkeley.edu/message-board
Parameter
incap_ses_124_496857=qKEzHmk2mjQaUb5nPoq4AeDw1VYAAAAA+uFP95Mt+3ZAS9UB5I/7qQ==; path=/; Domain=.berkeley.edu
Evidence
incap_ses_124_496857=qKEzHmk2mjQaUb5nPoq4AeDw1VYAAAAA+uFP95Mt+3ZAS9UB5I/7qQ==; path=/; Domain=.berkeley.edu

Solution

Ensure that the HttpOnly flag is set for all cookies.

Reference

www.owasp.org/index.php/HttpOnly

WASC Id

13

Low (Medium)Cookie set without secure flag

Description

A cookie has been set without the secure flag, which means that the cookie can be accessed via unencrypted connections.
URL
https://och.berkeley.edu/message-board
Parameter
PHPSESSID=db635hq4mj29o4neqgam04nc85; path=/
Evidence
PHPSESSID=db635hq4mj29o4neqgam04nc85; path=/

Solution

Whenever a cookie contains sensitive information or is a session token, then it should always be passed using an encrypted tunnel. Ensure that the secure flag is set for cookies containing such sensitive information.

Reference

http://www.owasp.org/index.php/Testing_for_cookies_attributes_(OWASP-SM-002)

WASC Id

13

Low (Medium)Incomplete or No Cache-control and Pragma HTTP Header Set

Description

The cache-control and pragma HTTP header have not been set properly or are missing allowing the browser and proxies to cache content.
URL
https://och.berkeley.edu/help
Evidence
no-store, no-cache, must-revalidate, post-check=0, pre-check=0

Solution

Whenever possible ensure the cache-control HTTP header is set with no-cache, no-store, must-revalidate, private; and that the pragma HTTP header is set with no-cache.

Reference

https://www.owasp.org/index.php/Session_Management_Cheat_Sheet#Web_Content_Caching

CWE Id

WASC Id

13

Low (Medium)Cross-Domain JavaScript Source File Inclusion

Description

The page at the following URL includes one or more script files from a third-party domain
URL
https://och.berkeley.edu/help
Parameter
//ajax.googleapis.com/ajax/libs/jquery/1.11.1/jquery.min.js
Evidence
//ajax.googleapis.com/ajax/libs/jquery/1.11.1/jquery.min.js

Solution

Ensure JavaScript source files are loaded from only trusted sources, and the sources can't be controlled by end users of the application

Reference

Low (Medium)Cross-Domain JavaScript Source File Inclusion

Description

The page at the following URL includes one or more script files from a third-party domain
URL
https://och.berkeley.edu/help
Parameter
//translate.google.com/translate_a/element.js?cb=googleTranslateElementInit
Evidence
//translate.google.com/translate_a/element.js?cb=googleTranslateElementInit

Solution

Ensure JavaScript source files are loaded from only trusted sources, and the sources can't be controlled by end users of the application

Reference

Low (Medium)Web Browser XSS Protection Not Enabled

Description

Web Browser XSS Protection is not enabled, or is disabled by the configuration of the 'X-XSS-Protection' HTTP response header on the web server
URL
https://och.berkeley.edu/help
Other information
The X-XSS-Protection HTTP response header allows the web server to enable or disable the web browser's XSS protection mechanism. The following values would attempt to enable it: X-XSS-Protection: 1; mode=block X-XSS-Protection: 1; report=http://www.example.com/xss The following values would disable it: X-XSS-Protection: 0 The X-XSS-Protection HTTP response header is currently supported on Internet Explorer, Chrome and Safari (WebKit). Note that this alert is only raised if the response body could potentially contain an XSS payload (with a text-based content type, with a non-zero length).

Solution

Ensure that the web browser's XSS filter is enabled, by setting the X-XSS-Protection HTTP response header to '1'.

Reference

https://www.owasp.org/index.php/XSS_(Cross_Site_Scripting)_Prevention_Cheat_Sheet

https://blog.veracode.com/2014/03/guidelines-for-setting-security-headers/

CWE Id

933

WASC Id

14

Low (Medium)X-Content-Type-Options Header Missing

Description

The Anti-MIME-Sniffing header X-Content-Type-Options was not set to 'nosniff'. This allows older versions of Internet Explorer and Chrome to perform MIME-sniffing on the response body, potentially causing the response body to be interpreted and displayed as a content type other than the declared content type. Current (early 2014) and legacy versions of Firefox will use the declared content type (if one is set), rather than performing MIME-sniffing.
URL
https://och.berkeley.edu/help
Other information
This issue still applies to error type pages (401, 403, 500, etc) as those pages are often still affected by injection issues, in which case there is still concern for browsers sniffing pages away from their actual content type.

Solution

Ensure that the application/web server sets the Content-Type header appropriately, and that it sets the X-Content-Type-Options header to 'nosniff' for all web pages.

If possible, ensure that the end user uses a standards-compliant and modern web browser that does not perform MIME-sniffing at all, or that can be directed by the web application/web server to not perform MIME-sniffing.

Reference

http://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/ie/gg622941%28v=vs.85%29.aspx

https://www.owasp.org/index.php/List_of_useful_HTTP_headers

WASC Id

15

Low (Medium)Incomplete or No Cache-control and Pragma HTTP Header Set

Description

The cache-control and pragma HTTP header have not been set properly or are missing allowing the browser and proxies to cache content.
URL
https://och.berkeley.edu/resource
Evidence
no-store, no-cache, must-revalidate, post-check=0, pre-check=0

Solution

Whenever possible ensure the cache-control HTTP header is set with no-cache, no-store, must-revalidate, private; and that the pragma HTTP header is set with no-cache.

Reference

https://www.owasp.org/index.php/Session_Management_Cheat_Sheet#Web_Content_Caching

Low (Medium)Web Browser XSS Protection Not Enabled

Description

Web Browser XSS Protection is not enabled, or is disabled by the configuration of the 'X-XSS-Protection' HTTP response header on the web server
URL
https://och.berkeley.edu/resource
Other information
The X-XSS-Protection HTTP response header allows the web server to enable or disable the web browser's XSS protection mechanism. The following values would attempt to enable it: X-XSS-Protection: 1; mode=block X-XSS-Protection: 1; report=http://www.example.com/xss The following values would disable it: X-XSS-Protection: 0 The X-XSS-Protection HTTP response header is currently supported on Internet Explorer, Chrome and Safari (WebKit). Note that this alert is only raised if the response body could potentially contain an XSS payload (with a text-based content type, with a non-zero length).

Solution

Ensure that the web browser's XSS filter is enabled, by setting the X-XSS-Protection HTTP response header to '1'.

Reference

https://www.owasp.org/index.php/XSS_(Cross_Site_Scripting)_Prevention_Cheat_Sheet

https://blog.veracode.com/2014/03/guidelines-for-setting-security-headers/

A cookie has been set without the secure flag, which means that the cookie can be accessed via unencrypted connections.
URL
https://och.berkeley.edu/registration
Parameter
incap_ses_124_496857=6ifTTv+twUIaUb5nPoq4AeHw1VYAAAAANccTmcgkM/+SbyHEKdE/rA==; path=/; Domain=.berkeley.edu
Evidence
incap_ses_124_496857=6ifTTv+twUIaUb5nPoq4AeHw1VYAAAAANccTmcgkM/+SbyHEKdE/rA==; path=/; Domain=.berkeley.edu

Solution

Whenever a cookie contains sensitive information or is a session token, then it should always be passed using an encrypted tunnel. Ensure that the secure flag is set for cookies containing such sensitive information.

Reference

http://www.owasp.org/index.php/Testing_for_cookies_attributes_(OWASP-SM-002)

WASC Id

13

Low (Medium)Cross-Domain JavaScript Source File Inclusion

Description

The page at the following URL includes one or more script files from a third-party domain
URL
https://och.berkeley.edu/registration
Parameter
//ajax.googleapis.com/ajax/libs/jquery/1.11.1/jquery.min.js
Evidence
//ajax.googleapis.com/ajax/libs/jquery/1.11.1/jquery.min.js

Solution

Ensure JavaScript source files are loaded from only trusted sources, and the sources can't be controlled by end users of the application

Reference

Low (Medium)Cross-Domain JavaScript Source File Inclusion

Description

The page at the following URL includes one or more script files from a third-party domain
URL
https://och.berkeley.edu/registration
Parameter
//translate.google.com/translate_a/element.js?cb=googleTranslateElementInit
Evidence
//translate.google.com/translate_a/element.js?cb=googleTranslateElementInit

Solution

Ensure JavaScript source files are loaded from only trusted sources, and the sources can't be controlled by end users of the application

Reference

Low (Medium)Web Browser XSS Protection Not Enabled

Description

Web Browser XSS Protection is not enabled, or is disabled by the configuration of the 'X-XSS-Protection' HTTP response header on the web server
URL
https://och.berkeley.edu/registration
Other information
The X-XSS-Protection HTTP response header allows the web server to enable or disable the web browser's XSS protection mechanism. The following values would attempt to enable it: X-XSS-Protection: 1; mode=block X-XSS-Protection: 1; report=http://www.example.com/xss The following values would disable it: X-XSS-Protection: 0 The X-XSS-Protection HTTP response header is currently supported on Internet Explorer, Chrome and Safari (WebKit). Note that this alert is only raised if the response body could potentially contain an XSS payload (with a text-based content type, with a non-zero length).

Solution

Ensure that the web browser's XSS filter is enabled, by setting the X-XSS-Protection HTTP response header to '1'.

Reference

https://www.owasp.org/index.php/XSS_(Cross_Site_Scripting)_Prevention_Cheat_Sheet

https://blog.veracode.com/2014/03/guidelines-for-setting-security-headers/

CWE Id

933

WASC Id

14

Low (Medium)X-Content-Type-Options Header Missing

Description

The Anti-MIME-Sniffing header X-Content-Type-Options was not set to 'nosniff'. This allows older versions of Internet Explorer and Chrome to perform MIME-sniffing on the response body, potentially causing the response body to be interpreted and displayed as a content type other than the declared content type. Current (early 2014) and legacy versions of Firefox will use the declared content type (if one is set), rather than performing MIME-sniffing.
URL
https://och.berkeley.edu/registration
Other information
This issue still applies to error type pages (401, 403, 500, etc) as those pages are often still affected by injection issues, in which case there is still concern for browsers sniffing pages away from their actual content type.

Solution

Ensure that the application/web server sets the Content-Type header appropriately, and that it sets the X-Content-Type-Options header to 'nosniff' for all web pages.

If possible, ensure that the end user uses a standards-compliant and modern web browser that does not perform MIME-sniffing at all, or that can be directed by the web application/web server to not perform MIME-sniffing.

Reference

http://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/ie/gg622941%28v=vs.85%29.aspx

https://www.owasp.org/index.php/List_of_useful_HTTP_headers

WASC Id

15

Low (Medium)Cookie set without HttpOnly flag

Description

A cookie has been set without the HttpOnly flag, which means that the cookie can be accessed by JavaScript. If a malicious script can be run on this page then the cookie will be accessible and can be transmitted to another site. If this is a session cookie then session hijacking may be possible.
URL
https://och.berkeley.edu/property/search?premium=1388706
Parameter
PHPSESSID=ehh98kmlqb4i8v5g5lsv08jrl4; path=/
Evidence
PHPSESSID=ehh98kmlqb4i8v5g5lsv08jrl4; path=/

Solution

Ensure that the HttpOnly flag is set for all cookies.

Reference

www.owasp.org/index.php/HttpOnly

WASC Id

13

Low (Medium)Incomplete or No Cache-control and Pragma HTTP Header Set

Description

The cache-control and pragma HTTP header have not been set properly or are missing allowing the browser and proxies to cache content.
URL
https://och.berkeley.edu/login
Evidence
no-store, no-cache, must-revalidate, post-check=0, pre-check=0

Solution

Whenever possible ensure the cache-control HTTP header is set with no-cache, no-store, must-revalidate, private; and that the pragma HTTP header is set with no-cache.

Reference

https://www.owasp.org/index.php/Session_Management_Cheat_Sheet#Web_Content_Caching

Low (Medium)Web Browser XSS Protection Not Enabled

Description

Web Browser XSS Protection is not enabled, or is disabled by the configuration of the 'X-XSS-Protection' HTTP response header on the web server
URL
https://och.berkeley.edu/login
Other information
The X-XSS-Protection HTTP response header allows the web server to enable or disable the web browser's XSS protection mechanism. The following values would attempt to enable it: X-XSS-Protection: 1; mode=block X-XSS-Protection: 1; report=http://www.example.com/xss The following values would disable it: X-XSS-Protection: 0 The X-XSS-Protection HTTP response header is currently supported on Internet Explorer, Chrome and Safari (WebKit). Note that this alert is only raised if the response body could potentially contain an XSS payload (with a text-based content type, with a non-zero length).

Solution

Ensure that the web browser's XSS filter is enabled, by setting the X-XSS-Protection HTTP response header to '1'.

Reference

https://www.owasp.org/index.php/XSS_(Cross_Site_Scripting)_Prevention_Cheat_Sheet

https://blog.veracode.com/2014/03/guidelines-for-setting-security-headers/

CWE Id

933

WASC Id

14

Low (Medium)Password Autocomplete in browser

Description

AUTOCOMPLETE attribute is not disabled in HTML FORM/INPUT element containing password type input. Passwords may be stored in browsers and retrieved.
URL
https://och.berkeley.edu/login
Parameter
input
Evidence
<input type="password" name="password" id="password" placeholder="Enter your password">

Solution

Turn off AUTOCOMPLETE attribute in form or individual input elements containing password by using AUTOCOMPLETE='OFF'

Reference

http://msdn.microsoft.com/library/default.asp?url=/workshop/author/forms/autocomplete_ovr.asp

CWE Id

525

Low (Medium)X-Content-Type-Options Header Missing

Description

The Anti-MIME-Sniffing header X-Content-Type-Options was not set to 'nosniff'. This allows older versions of Internet Explorer and Chrome to perform MIME-sniffing on the response body, potentially causing the response body to be interpreted and displayed as a content type other than the declared content type. Current (early 2014) and legacy versions of Firefox will use the declared content type (if one is set), rather than performing MIME-sniffing.
URL
https://och.berkeley.edu/login
Other information
This issue still applies to error type pages (401, 403, 500, etc) as those pages are often still affected by injection issues, in which case there is still concern for browsers sniffing pages away from their actual content type.

Solution

Ensure that the application/web server sets the Content-Type header appropriately, and that it sets the X-Content-Type-Options header to 'nosniff' for all web pages.

If possible, ensure that the end user uses a standards-compliant and modern web browser that does not perform MIME-sniffing at all, or that can be directed by the web application/web server to not perform MIME-sniffing.

Reference

http://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/ie/gg622941%28v=vs.85%29.aspx

https://www.owasp.org/index.php/List_of_useful_HTTP_headers

WASC Id

15

Description

The cache-control and pragma HTTP header have not been set properly or are missing allowing the browser and proxies to cache content.
URL
https://och.berkeley.edu/registration/property-manager
Evidence
no-store, no-cache, must-revalidate, post-check=0, pre-check=0

Solution

Whenever possible ensure the cache-control HTTP header is set with no-cache, no-store, must-revalidate, private; and that the pragma HTTP header is set with no-cache.

Reference

https://www.owasp.org/index.php/Session_Management_Cheat_Sheet#Web_Content_Caching

Low (Medium)Web Browser XSS Protection Not Enabled

Description

Web Browser XSS Protection is not enabled, or is disabled by the configuration of the 'X-XSS-Protection' HTTP response header on the web server
URL
https://och.berkeley.edu/registration/property-manager
Other information
The X-XSS-Protection HTTP response header allows the web server to enable or disable the web browser's XSS protection mechanism. The following values would attempt to enable it: X-XSS-Protection: 1; mode=block X-XSS-Protection: 1; report=http://www.example.com/xss The following values would disable it: X-XSS-Protection: 0 The X-XSS-Protection HTTP response header is currently supported on Internet Explorer, Chrome and Safari (WebKit). Note that this alert is only raised if the response body could potentially contain an XSS payload (with a text-based content type, with a non-zero length).

Solution

Ensure that the web browser's XSS filter is enabled, by setting the X-XSS-Protection HTTP response header to '1'.

Reference

https://www.owasp.org/index.php/XSS_(Cross_Site_Scripting)_Prevention_Cheat_Sheet

https://blog.veracode.com/2014/03/guidelines-for-setting-security-headers/

WASC Id

14

Low (Medium)X-Content-Type-Options Header Missing

Description

The Anti-MIME-Sniffing header X-Content-Type-Options was not set to 'nosniff'. This allows older versions of Internet Explorer and Chrome to perform MIME-sniffing on the response body, potentially causing the response body to be interpreted and displayed as a content type other than the declared content type. Current (early 2014) and legacy versions of Firefox will use the declared content type (if one is set), rather than performing MIME-sniffing.
URL
https://och.berkeley.edu/registration/property-manager
Other information
This issue still applies to error type pages (401, 403, 500, etc) as those pages are often still affected by injection issues, in which case there is still concern for browsers sniffing pages away from their actual content type.

Solution

Ensure that the application/web server sets the Content-Type header appropriately, and that it sets the X-Content-Type-Options header to 'nosniff' for all web pages.

If possible, ensure that the end user uses a standards-compliant and modern web browser that does not perform MIME-sniffing at all, or that can be directed by the web application/web server to not perform MIME-sniffing.

Reference

http://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/ie/gg622941%28v=vs.85%29.aspx

https://www.owasp.org/index.php/List_of_useful_HTTP_headers

WASC Id

15

Low (Medium)Cookie set without HttpOnly flag

Description

A cookie has been set without the HttpOnly flag, which means that the cookie can be accessed by JavaScript. If a malicious script can be run on this page then the cookie will be accessible and can be transmitted to another site. If this is a session cookie then session hijacking may be possible.
URL
https://och.berkeley.edu/user/add-favorites/property/225722?from=%2F
Parameter
PHPSESSID=qsf5vgaj0aq5pegiep0fmhl307; path=/
Evidence
PHPSESSID=qsf5vgaj0aq5pegiep0fmhl307; path=/

Solution

Ensure that the HttpOnly flag is set for all cookies.

Reference

www.owasp.org/index.php/HttpOnly

WASC Id

13

Low (Medium)Cookie set without secure flag

Description

A cookie has been set without the secure flag, which means that the cookie can be accessed via unencrypted connections.
URL
https://och.berkeley.edu/user/add-favorites/property/225722?from=%2F
Parameter
PHPSESSID=qsf5vgaj0aq5pegiep0fmhl307; path=/
Evidence
PHPSESSID=qsf5vgaj0aq5pegiep0fmhl307; path=/

Solution

Whenever a cookie contains sensitive information or is a session token, then it should always be passed using an encrypted tunnel. Ensure that the secure flag is set for cookies containing such sensitive information.

Reference

http://www.owasp.org/index.php/Testing_for_cookies_attributes_(OWASP-SM-002)

WASC Id

13

Low (Medium)Incomplete or No Cache-control and Pragma HTTP Header Set

Description

The cache-control and pragma HTTP header have not been set properly or are missing allowing the browser and proxies to cache content.
URL
https://och.berkeley.edu/privacy-policy
Evidence
no-store, no-cache, must-revalidate, post-check=0, pre-check=0

Solution

Whenever possible ensure the cache-control HTTP header is set with no-cache, no-store, must-revalidate, private; and that the pragma HTTP header is set with no-cache.

Reference

https://www.owasp.org/index.php/Session_Management_Cheat_Sheet#Web_Content_Caching

WASC Id

13

Low (Medium)Cross-Domain JavaScript Source File Inclusion

Description

The page at the following URL includes one or more script files from a third-party domain
URL
https://och.berkeley.edu/privacy-policy
Parameter
//ajax.googleapis.com/ajax/libs/jquery/1.11.1/jquery.min.js
Evidence
//ajax.googleapis.com/ajax/libs/jquery/1.11.1/jquery.min.js

Solution

Ensure JavaScript source files are loaded from only trusted sources, and the sources can't be controlled by end users of the application

Reference

Low (Medium)Cross-Domain JavaScript Source File Inclusion

Description

The page at the following URL includes one or more script files from a third-party domain
URL
https://och.berkeley.edu/privacy-policy
Parameter
//translate.google.com/translate_a/element.js?cb=googleTranslateElementInit
Evidence
//translate.google.com/translate_a/element.js?cb=googleTranslateElementInit

Solution

Ensure JavaScript source files are loaded from only trusted sources, and the sources can't be controlled by end users of the application

Reference

Low (Medium)Web Browser XSS Protection Not Enabled

Description

Web Browser XSS Protection is not enabled, or is disabled by the configuration of the 'X-XSS-Protection' HTTP response header on the web server
URL
https://och.berkeley.edu/privacy-policy
Other information
The X-XSS-Protection HTTP response header allows the web server to enable or disable the web browser's XSS protection mechanism. The following values would attempt to enable it: X-XSS-Protection: 1; mode=block X-XSS-Protection: 1; report=http://www.example.com/xss The following values would disable it: X-XSS-Protection: 0 The X-XSS-Protection HTTP response header is currently supported on Internet Explorer, Chrome and Safari (WebKit). Note that this alert is only raised if the response body could potentially contain an XSS payload (with a text-based content type, with a non-zero length).

Solution

Ensure that the web browser's XSS filter is enabled, by setting the X-XSS-Protection HTTP response header to '1'.

Reference

https://www.owasp.org/index.php/XSS_(Cross_Site_Scripting)_Prevention_Cheat_Sheet

https://blog.veracode.com/2014/03/guidelines-for-setting-security-headers/

CWE Id

933

WASC Id

14

Low (Medium)X-Content-Type-Options Header Missing

Description

The Anti-MIME-Sniffing header X-Content-Type-Options was not set to 'nosniff'. This allows older versions of Internet Explorer and Chrome to perform MIME-sniffing on the response body, potentially causing the response body to be interpreted and displayed as a content type other than the declared content type. Current (early 2014) and legacy versions of Firefox will use the declared content type (if one is set), rather than performing MIME-sniffing.
URL
https://och.berkeley.edu/privacy-policy
Other information
This issue still applies to error type pages (401, 403, 500, etc) as those pages are often still affected by injection issues, in which case there is still concern for browsers sniffing pages away from their actual content type.

Solution

Ensure that the application/web server sets the Content-Type header appropriately, and that it sets the X-Content-Type-Options header to 'nosniff' for all web pages.

If possible, ensure that the end user uses a standards-compliant and modern web browser that does not perform MIME-sniffing at all, or that can be directed by the web application/web server to not perform MIME-sniffing.

Reference

http://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/ie/gg622941%28v=vs.85%29.aspx

https://www.owasp.org/index.php/List_of_useful_HTTP_headers

WASC Id

13

Low (Medium)Cookie set without HttpOnly flag

Description

A cookie has been set without the HttpOnly flag, which means that the cookie can be accessed by JavaScript. If a malicious script can be run on this page then the cookie will be accessible and can be transmitted to another site. If this is a session cookie then session hijacking may be possible.
URL
https://och.berkeley.edu/property/view/listingid/270849
Parameter
visid_incap_496857=4IND+ohuRO2GYE/C2CfhqNrw1VYAAAAAQUIPAAAAAAD7/Ds+duivzn7Oz7wJ4wfE; expires=Wed, 01 Mar 2017 12:23:46 GMT; path=/; Domain=.berkeley.edu

WASC Id

13

Low (Medium)Cookie set without secure flag

Description

A cookie has been set without the secure flag, which means that the cookie can be accessed via unencrypted connections.
URL
https://och.berkeley.edu/property/view/listingid/270849
Parameter

Evidence
PHPSESSID=doea8iflkuk4j16dunfhalad66; path=/

Solution

Whenever a cookie contains sensitive information or is a session token, then it should always be passed using an encrypted tunnel. Ensure that the secure flag is set for cookies containing such sensitive information.

Reference

http://www.owasp.org/index.php/Testing_for_cookies_attributes_(OWASP-SM-002)

WASC Id

13

Low (Medium)Incomplete or No Cache-control and Pragma HTTP Header Set

Description

The cache-control and pragma HTTP header have not been set properly or are missing allowing the browser and proxies to cache content.
URL
https://och.berkeley.edu/disclaimer
Evidence
no-store, no-cache, must-revalidate, post-check=0, pre-check=0

Solution

Whenever possible ensure the cache-control HTTP header is set with no-cache, no-store, must-revalidate, private; and that the pragma HTTP header is set with no-cache.

Reference

https://www.owasp.org/index.php/Session_Management_Cheat_Sheet#Web_Content_Caching

WASC Id

13

Low (Medium)Cross-Domain JavaScript Source File Inclusion

Description

The page at the following URL includes one or more script files from a third-party domain
URL
https://och.berkeley.edu/disclaimer
Parameter
//ajax.googleapis.com/ajax/libs/jquery/1.11.1/jquery.min.js
Evidence
//ajax.googleapis.com/ajax/libs/jquery/1.11.1/jquery.min.js

Solution

Ensure JavaScript source files are loaded from only trusted sources, and the sources can't be controlled by end users of the application

Reference

Low (Medium)Cross-Domain JavaScript Source File Inclusion

Description

The page at the following URL includes one or more script files from a third-party domain
URL
https://och.berkeley.edu/disclaimer
Parameter
//translate.google.com/translate_a/element.js?cb=googleTranslateElementInit
Evidence
//translate.google.com/translate_a/element.js?cb=googleTranslateElementInit

Solution

Ensure JavaScript source files are loaded from only trusted sources, and the sources can't be controlled by end users of the application

Reference

Low (Medium)Web Browser XSS Protection Not Enabled

Description

Web Browser XSS Protection is not enabled, or is disabled by the configuration of the 'X-XSS-Protection' HTTP response header on the web server
URL
https://och.berkeley.edu/disclaimer
Other information
The X-XSS-Protection HTTP response header allows the web server to enable or disable the web browser's XSS protection mechanism. The following values would attempt to enable it: X-XSS-Protection: 1; mode=block X-XSS-Protection: 1; report=http://www.example.com/xss The following values would disable it: X-XSS-Protection: 0 The X-XSS-Protection HTTP response header is currently supported on Internet Explorer, Chrome and Safari (WebKit). Note that this alert is only raised if the response body could potentially contain an XSS payload (with a text-based content type, with a non-zero length).

Solution

Ensure that the web browser's XSS filter is enabled, by setting the X-XSS-Protection HTTP response header to '1'.

Reference

https://www.owasp.org/index.php/XSS_(Cross_Site_Scripting)_Prevention_Cheat_Sheet

https://blog.veracode.com/2014/03/guidelines-for-setting-security-headers/

CWE Id

933

WASC Id

14

Low (Medium)X-Content-Type-Options Header Missing

Description

The Anti-MIME-Sniffing header X-Content-Type-Options was not set to 'nosniff'. This allows older versions of Internet Explorer and Chrome to perform MIME-sniffing on the response body, potentially causing the response body to be interpreted and displayed as a content type other than the declared content type. Current (early 2014) and legacy versions of Firefox will use the declared content type (if one is set), rather than performing MIME-sniffing.
URL
https://och.berkeley.edu/disclaimer
Other information
This issue still applies to error type pages (401, 403, 500, etc) as those pages are often still affected by injection issues, in which case there is still concern for browsers sniffing pages away from their actual content type.

Solution

Ensure that the application/web server sets the Content-Type header appropriately, and that it sets the X-Content-Type-Options header to 'nosniff' for all web pages.

If possible, ensure that the end user uses a standards-compliant and modern web browser that does not perform MIME-sniffing at all, or that can be directed by the web application/web server to not perform MIME-sniffing.

Reference

http://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/ie/gg622941%28v=vs.85%29.aspx

https://www.owasp.org/index.php/List_of_useful_HTTP_headers

WASC Id

15

www.owasp.org/index.php/HttpOnly

Low (Medium)Web Browser XSS Protection Not Enabled

Description

Web Browser XSS Protection is not enabled, or is disabled by the configuration of the 'X-XSS-Protection' HTTP response header on the web server
URL
https://och.berkeley.edu/help/contact
Other information
The X-XSS-Protection HTTP response header allows the web server to enable or disable the web browser's XSS protection mechanism. The following values would attempt to enable it: X-XSS-Protection: 1; mode=block X-XSS-Protection: 1; report=http://www.example.com/xss The following values would disable it: X-XSS-Protection: 0 The X-XSS-Protection HTTP response header is currently supported on Internet Explorer, Chrome and Safari (WebKit). Note that this alert is only raised if the response body could potentially contain an XSS payload (with a text-based content type, with a non-zero length).

Solution

Ensure that the web browser's XSS filter is enabled, by setting the X-XSS-Protection HTTP response header to '1'.

Reference

https://www.owasp.org/index.php/XSS_(Cross_Site_Scripting)_Prevention_Cheat_Sheet

https://blog.veracode.com/2014/03/guidelines-for-setting-security-headers/

CWE Id

933

WASC Id

14

Low (Medium)X-Content-Type-Options Header Missing

Description

The Anti-MIME-Sniffing header X-Content-Type-Options was not set to 'nosniff'. This allows older versions of Internet Explorer and Chrome to perform MIME-sniffing on the response body, potentially causing the response body to be interpreted and displayed as a content type other than the declared content type. Current (early 2014) and legacy versions of Firefox will use the declared content type (if one is set), rather than performing MIME-sniffing.
URL
https://och.berkeley.edu/help/contact
Other information
This issue still applies to error type pages (401, 403, 500, etc) as those pages are often still affected by injection issues, in which case there is still concern for browsers sniffing pages away from their actual content type.

Solution

Ensure that the application/web server sets the Content-Type header appropriately, and that it sets the X-Content-Type-Options header to 'nosniff' for all web pages.

If possible, ensure that the end user uses a standards-compliant and modern web browser that does not perform MIME-sniffing at all, or that can be directed by the web application/web server to not perform MIME-sniffing.

Reference

http://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/ie/gg622941%28v=vs.85%29.aspx

https://www.owasp.org/index.php/List_of_useful_HTTP_headers

WASC Id

15

Low (Medium)Cookie set without HttpOnly flag

Description

A cookie has been set without the HttpOnly flag, which means that the cookie can be accessed by JavaScript. If a malicious script can be run on this page then the cookie will be accessible and can be transmitted to another site. If this is a session cookie then session hijacking may be possible.
URL
https://och.berkeley.edu/v2/css/styles.1456495874.css
Parameter
visid_incap_496857=PkbdkzhsTcOLkMJa8XZzXeXw1VYAAAAAQUIPAAAAAACCfy6AR1Ejqgx1V5hwkNh7; expires=Wed, 01 Mar 2017 12:23:48 GMT; path=/; Domain=.berkeley.edu
Evidence
visid_incap_496857=PkbdkzhsTcOLkMJa8XZzXeXw1VYAAAAAQUIPAAAAAACCfy6AR1Ejqgx1V5hwkNh7; expires=Wed, 01 Mar 2017 12:23:48 GMT; path=/; Domain=.berkeley.edu

Solution

Ensure that the HttpOnly flag is set for all cookies.

Reference

www.owasp.org/index.php/HttpOnly

WASC Id

13

Low (Medium)Cookie set without HttpOnly flag

Description

A cookie has been set without the HttpOnly flag, which means that the cookie can be accessed by JavaScript. If a malicious script can be run on this page then the cookie will be accessible and can be transmitted to another site. If this is a session cookie then session hijacking may be possible.
URL
https://och.berkeley.edu/v2/css/styles.1456495874.css
Parameter
incap_ses_124_496857=gpdgQpn+rmQofr5nPoq4AeXw1VYAAAAAbFeVSKXhhF5Co5UOeDmgCg==; path=/; Domain=.berkeley.edu
Evidence
incap_ses_124_496857=gpdgQpn+rmQofr5nPoq4AeXw1VYAAAAAbFeVSKXhhF5Co5UOeDmgCg==; path=/; Domain=.berkeley.edu

Solution

Ensure that the HttpOnly flag is set for all cookies.

Reference

www.owasp.org/index.php/HttpOnly

WASC Id

13

Low (Medium)Cookie set without secure flag

Description

A cookie has been set without the secure flag, which means that the cookie can be accessed via unencrypted connections.
URL
https://och.berkeley.edu/v2/css/styles.1456495874.css
Parameter
visid_incap_496857=PkbdkzhsTcOLkMJa8XZzXeXw1VYAAAAAQUIPAAAAAACCfy6AR1Ejqgx1V5hwkNh7; expires=Wed, 01 Mar 2017 12:23:48 GMT; path=/; Domain=.berkeley.edu
Evidence
visid_incap_496857=PkbdkzhsTcOLkMJa8XZzXeXw1VYAAAAAQUIPAAAAAACCfy6AR1Ejqgx1V5hwkNh7; expires=Wed, 01 Mar 2017 12:23:48 GMT; path=/; Domain=.berkeley.edu

Solution

Whenever a cookie contains sensitive information or is a session token, then it should always be passed using an encrypted tunnel. Ensure that the secure flag is set for cookies containing such sensitive information.

Reference

http://www.owasp.org/index.php/Testing_for_cookies_attributes_(OWASP-SM-002)

WASC Id

13

Low (Medium)Cookie set without secure flag

Description

A cookie has been set without the secure flag, which means that the cookie can be accessed via unencrypted connections.
URL
https://och.berkeley.edu/v2/css/styles.1456495874.css
Parameter
incap_ses_124_496857=gpdgQpn+rmQofr5nPoq4AeXw1VYAAAAAbFeVSKXhhF5Co5UOeDmgCg==; path=/; Domain=.berkeley.edu
Evidence
incap_ses_124_496857=gpdgQpn+rmQofr5nPoq4AeXw1VYAAAAAbFeVSKXhhF5Co5UOeDmgCg==; path=/; Domain=.berkeley.edu

Solution

Whenever a cookie contains sensitive information or is a session token, then it should always be passed using an encrypted tunnel. Ensure that the secure flag is set for cookies containing such sensitive information.

Reference

http://www.owasp.org/index.php/Testing_for_cookies_attributes_(OWASP-SM-002)

WASC Id

13

Low (Medium)Web Browser XSS Protection Not Enabled

Description

Web Browser XSS Protection is not enabled, or is disabled by the configuration of the 'X-XSS-Protection' HTTP response header on the web server
URL
https://och.berkeley.edu/v2/css/styles.1456495874.css
Other information
The X-XSS-Protection HTTP response header allows the web server to enable or disable the web browser's XSS protection mechanism. The following values would attempt to enable it: X-XSS-Protection: 1; mode=block X-XSS-Protection: 1; report=http://www.example.com/xss The following values would disable it: X-XSS-Protection: 0 The X-XSS-Protection HTTP response header is currently supported on Internet Explorer, Chrome and Safari (WebKit). Note that this alert is only raised if the response body could potentially contain an XSS payload (with a text-based content type, with a non-zero length).

Solution

Ensure that the web browser's XSS filter is enabled, by setting the X-XSS-Protection HTTP response header to '1'.

Reference

https://www.owasp.org/index.php/XSS_(Cross_Site_Scripting)_Prevention_Cheat_Sheet

https://blog.veracode.com/2014/03/guidelines-for-setting-security-headers/

CWE Id

933

WASC Id

14

Low (Medium)X-Content-Type-Options Header Missing

Description

The Anti-MIME-Sniffing header X-Content-Type-Options was not set to 'nosniff'. This allows older versions of Internet Explorer and Chrome to perform MIME-sniffing on the response body, potentially causing the response body to be interpreted and displayed as a content type other than the declared content type. Current (early 2014) and legacy versions of Firefox will use the declared content type (if one is set), rather than performing MIME-sniffing.
URL
https://och.berkeley.edu/v2/css/styles.1456495874.css
Other information
This issue still applies to error type pages (401, 403, 500, etc) as those pages are often still affected by injection issues, in which case there is still concern for browsers sniffing pages away from their actual content type.

Solution

Ensure that the application/web server sets the Content-Type header appropriately, and that it sets the X-Content-Type-Options header to 'nosniff' for all web pages.

If possible, ensure that the end user uses a standards-compliant and modern web browser that does not perform MIME-sniffing at all, or that can be directed by the web application/web server to not perform MIME-sniffing.

Reference

http://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/ie/gg622941%28v=vs.85%29.aspx

https://www.owasp.org/index.php/List_of_useful_HTTP_headers
