WASC Id

13

Low (Medium)Web Browser XSS Protection Not Enabled

Description

Web Browser XSS Protection is not enabled, or is disabled by the configuration of the 'X-XSS-Protection' HTTP response header on the web server
URL
https://och.berkeley.edu/v2/university/137.0.0024.css
Other information
The X-XSS-Protection HTTP response header allows the web server to enable or disable the web browser's XSS protection mechanism. The following values would attempt to enable it: X-XSS-Protection: 1; mode=block X-XSS-Protection: 1; report=http://www.example.com/xss The following values would disable it: X-XSS-Protection: 0 The X-XSS-Protection HTTP response header is currently supported on Internet Explorer, Chrome and Safari (WebKit). Note that this alert is only raised if the response body could potentially contain an XSS payload (with a text-based content type, with a non-zero length).

Solution

Ensure that the web browser's XSS filter is enabled, by setting the X-XSS-Protection HTTP response header to '1'.

Reference

https://www.owasp.org/index.php/XSS_(Cross_Site_Scripting)_Prevention_Cheat_Sheet

https://blog.veracode.com/2014/03/guidelines-for-setting-security-headers/

Description

This allows older versions of Internet Explorer and Chrome to perform MIME-sniffing on the response body, potentially causing the response body to be interpreted and displayed as a content type other than the declared content type. https://och.berkeley.edu/v2/university/137.0.0024.css
Other information

Solution

If possible, ensure that the end user uses a standards-compliant and modern web browser that does not perform MIME-sniffing at all, or that can be directed by the web application/web server to not perform MIME-sniffing.

incap_ses_124_496857=zWd2J/GnrSeogr5nPoq4Aebw1VYAAAAAhS/ny5aJcALOP80cWvmxtw==; path=/; Domain=.berkeley.edu
Evidence
incap_ses_124_496857=zWd2J/GnrSeogr5nPoq4Aebw1VYAAAAAhS/ny5aJcALOP80cWvmxtw==; path=/; Domain=.berkeley.edu

Solution

Ensure that the HttpOnly flag is set for all cookies.

Reference

www.owasp.org/index.php/HttpOnly

WASC Id

13

Low (Medium)Cookie set without secure flag

Description

A cookie has been set without the secure flag, which means that the cookie can be accessed via unencrypted connections.
URL
https://och.berkeley.edu/property/view/listingid/272099
Parameter
PHPSESSID=rapob2jefng0sr4npleicrbkv3; path=/
Evidence
PHPSESSID=rapob2jefng0sr4npleicrbkv3; path=/

Solution

Whenever a cookie contains sensitive information or is a session token, then it should always be passed using an encrypted tunnel. Ensure that the secure flag is set for cookies containing such sensitive information.

Reference

http://www.owasp.org/index.php/Testing_for_cookies_attributes_(OWASP-SM-002)

WASC Id

13

Low (Medium)Incomplete or No Cache-control and Pragma HTTP Header Set

Description

The cache-control and pragma HTTP header have not been set properly or are missing allowing the browser and proxies to cache content.
URL
https://och.berkeley.edu/v2/js/vendor/modernizr-2.6.2.min.js
Evidence
max-age=405642, public

Solution

Whenever possible ensure the cache-control HTTP header is set with no-cache, no-store, must-revalidate, private; and that the pragma HTTP header is set with no-cache.

Reference

https://www.owasp.org/index.php/Session_Management_Cheat_Sheet#Web_Content_Caching

WASC Id

13

Low (Medium)Web Browser XSS Protection Not Enabled

Description

Web Browser XSS Protection is not enabled, or is disabled by the configuration of the 'X-XSS-Protection' HTTP response header on the web server
URL
https://och.berkeley.edu/v2/js/vendor/modernizr-2.6.2.min.js
Other information
The X-XSS-Protection HTTP response header allows the web server to enable or disable the web browser's XSS protection mechanism. The following values would attempt to enable it: X-XSS-Protection: 1; mode=block X-XSS-Protection: 1; report=http://www.example.com/xss The following values would disable it: X-XSS-Protection: 0 The X-XSS-Protection HTTP response header is currently supported on Internet Explorer, Chrome and Safari (WebKit). Note that this alert is only raised if the response body could potentially contain an XSS payload (with a text-based content type, with a non-zero length).

Solution

Ensure that the web browser's XSS filter is enabled, by setting the X-XSS-Protection HTTP response header to '1'.

Reference

https://www.owasp.org/index.php/XSS_(Cross_Site_Scripting)_Prevention_Cheat_Sheet

https://blog.veracode.com/2014/03/guidelines-for-setting-security-headers/

CWE Id

933

WASC Id

14

Low (Medium)X-Content-Type-Options Header Missing

Description

The Anti-MIME-Sniffing header X-Content-Type-Options was not set to 'nosniff'. This allows older versions of Internet Explorer and Chrome to perform MIME-sniffing on the response body, potentially causing the response body to be interpreted and displayed as a content type other than the declared content type. Current (early 2014) and legacy versions of Firefox will use the declared content type (if one is set), rather than performing MIME-sniffing.
URL
https://och.berkeley.edu/v2/js/vendor/modernizr-2.6.2.min.js
Other information
This issue still applies to error type pages (401, 403, 500, etc) as those pages are often still affected by injection issues, in which case there is still concern for browsers sniffing pages away from their actual content type.

Solution

Ensure that the application/web server sets the Content-Type header appropriately, and that it sets the X-Content-Type-Options header to 'nosniff' for all web pages.

If possible, ensure that the end user uses a standards-compliant and modern web browser that does not perform MIME-sniffing at all, or that can be directed by the web application/web server to not perform MIME-sniffing.

Reference

http://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/ie/gg622941%28v=vs.85%29.aspx

https://www.owasp.org/index.php/List_of_useful_HTTP_headers

WASC Id

15

Low (Medium)Cookie set without HttpOnly flag

Description

A cookie has been set without the HttpOnly flag, which means that the cookie can be accessed by JavaScript. If a malicious script can be run on this page then the cookie will be accessible and can be transmitted to another site. If this is a session cookie then session hijacking may be possible.
URL
https://och.berkeley.edu/property/view/listingid/240890
Parameter
PHPSESSID=6sjiitegudd4nfnfhifibf53p2; path=/
Evidence
PHPSESSID=6sjiitegudd4nfnfhifibf53p2; path=/

Solution

Ensure that the HttpOnly flag is set for all cookies.

Reference

www.owasp.org/index.php/HttpOnly

WASC Id

13

Low (Medium)Cookie set without HttpOnly flag

Description

A cookie has been set without the HttpOnly flag, which means that the cookie can be accessed by JavaScript. If a malicious script can be run on this page then the cookie will be accessible and can be transmitted to another site. If this is a session cookie then session hijacking may be possible.
URL
https://och.berkeley.edu/property/view/listingid/240890
Parameter
visid_incap_496857=En0KXSm6QbqXL/vauDu72efw1VYAAAAAQUIPAAAAAAAphseHbE+A+wwYjRaW+a45; expires=Wed, 01 Mar 2017 12:24:06 GMT; path=/; Domain=.berkeley.edu

WASC Id

13

Low (Medium)Cookie set without secure flag

Description

A cookie has been set without the secure flag, which means that the cookie can be accessed via unencrypted connections.
URL
https://och.berkeley.edu/property/view/listingid/240890
Parameter
PHPSESSID=6sjiitegudd4nfnfhifibf53p2; path=/
Evidence
PHPSESSID=6sjiitegudd4nfnfhifibf53p2; path=/

Solution

Whenever a cookie contains sensitive information or is a session token, then it should always be passed using an encrypted tunnel. Ensure that the secure flag is set for cookies containing such sensitive information.

Reference

http://www.owasp.org/index.php/Testing_for_cookies_attributes_(OWASP-SM-002)

WASC Id

13

Low (Medium)Incomplete or No Cache-control and Pragma HTTP Header Set

Description

The cache-control and pragma HTTP header have not been set properly or are missing allowing the browser and proxies to cache content.
URL
https://och.berkeley.edu/v2/js/vendor/jquery-1.11.1.min.js
Evidence
max-age=2592000

Solution

Whenever possible ensure the cache-control HTTP header is set with no-cache, no-store, must-revalidate, private; and that the pragma HTTP header is set with no-cache.

Reference

https://www.owasp.org/index.php/Session_Management_Cheat_Sheet#Web_Content_Caching

WASC Id

13

Low (Medium)Cookie set without secure flag

Description

A cookie has been set without the secure flag, which means that the cookie can be accessed via unencrypted connections.
URL
https://och.berkeley.edu/v2/js/vendor/jquery-1.11.1.min.js
Parameter
incap_ses_124_496857=XB/VW9pXokSBib5nPoq4Aefw1VYAAAAARpp0+J3zIxmH8LtRa9COWg==; path=/; Domain=.berkeley.edu
Evidence
incap_ses_124_496857=XB/VW9pXokSBib5nPoq4Aefw1VYAAAAARpp0+J3zIxmH8LtRa9COWg==; path=/; Domain=.berkeley.edu

Reference

http://www.owasp.org/index.php/Testing_for_cookies_attributes_(OWASP-SM-002)

WASC Id

13

Low (Medium)Web Browser XSS Protection Not Enabled

Description

Web Browser XSS Protection is not enabled, or is disabled by the configuration of the 'X-XSS-Protection' HTTP response header on the web server
URL
https://och.berkeley.edu/v2/js/vendor/jquery-1.11.1.min.js
Other information
The X-XSS-Protection HTTP response header allows the web server to enable or disable the web browser's XSS protection mechanism. The following values would attempt to enable it: X-XSS-Protection: 1; mode=block X-XSS-Protection: 1; report=http://www.example.com/xss The following values would disable it: X-XSS-Protection: 0 The X-XSS-Protection HTTP response header is currently supported on Internet Explorer, Chrome and Safari (WebKit). Note that this alert is only raised if the response body could potentially contain an XSS payload (with a text-based content type, with a non-zero length).

Solution

Ensure that the web browser's XSS filter is enabled, by setting the X-XSS-Protection HTTP response header to '1'.

Reference

https://www.owasp.org/index.php/XSS_(Cross_Site_Scripting)_Prevention_Cheat_Sheet

https://blog.veracode.com/2014/03/guidelines-for-setting-security-headers/

CWE Id

933

WASC Id

14

Low (Medium)X-Content-Type-Options Header Missing

Description

The Anti-MIME-Sniffing header X-Content-Type-Options was not set to 'nosniff'. This allows older versions of Internet Explorer and Chrome to perform MIME-sniffing on the response body, potentially causing the response body to be interpreted and displayed as a content type other than the declared content type. Current (early 2014) and legacy versions of Firefox will use the declared content type (if one is set), rather than performing MIME-sniffing.
URL
https://och.berkeley.edu/v2/js/vendor/jquery-1.11.1.min.js
Other information
This issue still applies to error type pages (401, 403, 500, etc) as those pages are often still affected by injection issues, in which case there is still concern for browsers sniffing pages away from their actual content type.

Solution

Ensure that the application/web server sets the Content-Type header appropriately, and that it sets the X-Content-Type-Options header to 'nosniff' for all web pages.

If possible, ensure that the end user uses a standards-compliant and modern web browser that does not perform MIME-sniffing at all, or that can be directed by the web application/web server to not perform MIME-sniffing.

Reference

http://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/ie/gg622941%28v=vs.85%29.aspx

https://www.owasp.org/index.php/List_of_useful_HTTP_headers

WASC Id

15

Low (Medium)Incomplete or No Cache-control and Pragma HTTP Header Set

Description

The cache-control and pragma HTTP header have not been set properly or are missing allowing the browser and proxies to cache content.
URL
https://och.berkeley.edu/v2/js/ocp.min.1450002346.js
Evidence
max-age=418008, public

Solution

Whenever possible ensure the cache-control HTTP header is set with no-cache, no-store, must-revalidate, private; and that the pragma HTTP header is set with no-cache.

Reference

https://www.owasp.org/index.php/Session_Management_Cheat_Sheet#Web_Content_Caching

Ensure that the HttpOnly flag is set for all cookies.

Reference

www.owasp.org/index.php/HttpOnly

WASC Id

13

Low (Medium)Cookie set without secure flag

Description

A cookie has been set without the secure flag, which means that the cookie can be accessed via unencrypted connections.
URL
https://och.berkeley.edu/help/category/reset-your-password
Parameter
PHPSESSID=h3ou8e298mf07f37n3vbnjotu5; path=/
Evidence
PHPSESSID=h3ou8e298mf07f37n3vbnjotu5; path=/

Solution

Whenever a cookie contains sensitive information or is a session token, then it should always be passed using an encrypted tunnel. Ensure that the secure flag is set for cookies containing such sensitive information.

Reference

http://www.owasp.org/index.php/Testing_for_cookies_attributes_(OWASP-SM-002)

WASC Id

13

Low (Medium)Cookie set without secure flag

Description

A cookie has been set without the secure flag, which means that the cookie can be accessed via unencrypted connections.
URL
https://och.berkeley.edu/help/category/reset-your-password
Parameter
visid_incap_496857=Kp8x9Ek5Q4Ouou/XWkje2O7w1VYAAAAAQUIPAAAAAABihLuyGl4RHd6jl6FPPttA; expires=Wed, 01 Mar 2017 12:23:48 GMT; path=/; Domain=.berkeley.edu
Evidence
visid_incap_496857=Kp8x9Ek5Q4Ouou/XWkje2O7w1VYAAAAAQUIPAAAAAABihLuyGl4RHd6jl6FPPttA; expires=Wed, 01 Mar 2017 12:23:48 GMT; path=/; Domain=.berkeley.edu

http://www.owasp.org/index.php/Testing_for_cookies_attributes_(OWASP-SM-002)

WASC Id

13

Description

A cookie has been set without the secure flag, which means that the cookie can be accessed via unencrypted connections.
URL
https://och.berkeley.edu/help/category/reset-your-password
Parameter
incap_ses_124_496857=VsHQeR8GPhpGpL5nPoq4Ae7w1VYAAAAAPc+iZQRtj3w706GxttkpVg==; path=/; Domain=.berkeley.edu
Evidence
incap_ses_124_496857=VsHQeR8GPhpGpL5nPoq4Ae7w1VYAAAAAPc+iZQRtj3w706GxttkpVg==; path=/; Domain=.berkeley.edu

WASC Id

13

Low (Medium)Cross-Domain JavaScript Source File Inclusion

Description

The page at the following URL includes one or more script files from a third-party domain
URL
https://och.berkeley.edu/help/category/reset-your-password
Parameter
//ajax.googleapis.com/ajax/libs/jquery/1.11.1/jquery.min.js
Evidence
//ajax.googleapis.com/ajax/libs/jquery/1.11.1/jquery.min.js

Solution

Ensure JavaScript source files are loaded from only trusted sources, and the sources can't be controlled by end users of the application

Reference

Low (Medium)Cross-Domain JavaScript Source File Inclusion

Description

The page at the following URL includes one or more script files from a third-party domain
URL
https://och.berkeley.edu/help/category/reset-your-password
Parameter
//translate.google.com/translate_a/element.js?cb=googleTranslateElementInit
Evidence
//translate.google.com/translate_a/element.js?cb=googleTranslateElementInit

Solution

Ensure JavaScript source files are loaded from only trusted sources, and the sources can't be controlled by end users of the application

Reference

Low (Medium)Web Browser XSS Protection Not Enabled

Description

Web Browser XSS Protection is not enabled, or is disabled by the configuration of the 'X-XSS-Protection' HTTP response header on the web server
URL
https://och.berkeley.edu/help/category/reset-your-password
Other information
The X-XSS-Protection HTTP response header allows the web server to enable or disable the web browser's XSS protection mechanism. The following values would attempt to enable it: X-XSS-Protection: 1; mode=block X-XSS-Protection: 1; report=http://www.example.com/xss The following values would disable it: X-XSS-Protection: 0 The X-XSS-Protection HTTP response header is currently supported on Internet Explorer, Chrome and Safari (WebKit). Note that this alert is only raised if the response body could potentially contain an XSS payload (with a text-based content type, with a non-zero length).

Solution

Ensure that the web browser's XSS filter is enabled, by setting the X-XSS-Protection HTTP response header to '1'.

Reference

https://www.owasp.org/index.php/XSS_(Cross_Site_Scripting)_Prevention_Cheat_Sheet

https://blog.veracode.com/2014/03/guidelines-for-setting-security-headers/

CWE Id

933

WASC Id

14

Low (Medium)X-Content-Type-Options Header Missing

Description

The Anti-MIME-Sniffing header X-Content-Type-Options was not set to 'nosniff'. This allows older versions of Internet Explorer and Chrome to perform MIME-sniffing on the response body, potentially causing the response body to be interpreted and displayed as a content type other than the declared content type. Current (early 2014) and legacy versions of Firefox will use the declared content type (if one is set), rather than performing MIME-sniffing.
URL
https://och.berkeley.edu/help/category/reset-your-password
Other information
This issue still applies to error type pages (401, 403, 500, etc) as those pages are often still affected by injection issues, in which case there is still concern for browsers sniffing pages away from their actual content type.

Solution

Ensure that the application/web server sets the Content-Type header appropriately, and that it sets the X-Content-Type-Options header to 'nosniff' for all web pages.

If possible, ensure that the end user uses a standards-compliant and modern web browser that does not perform MIME-sniffing at all, or that can be directed by the web application/web server to not perform MIME-sniffing.

Reference

http://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/ie/gg622941%28v=vs.85%29.aspx

https://www.owasp.org/index.php/List_of_useful_HTTP_headers

WASC Id

15

Low (Medium)Incomplete or No Cache-control and Pragma HTTP Header Set

Description

The cache-control and pragma HTTP header have not been set properly or are missing allowing the browser and proxies to cache content.
URL
https://och.berkeley.edu/registration/lister
Evidence
no-store, no-cache, must-revalidate, post-check=0, pre-check=0

Solution

Whenever possible ensure the cache-control HTTP header is set with no-cache, no-store, must-revalidate, private; and that the pragma HTTP header is set with no-cache.

Reference

https://www.owasp.org/index.php/Session_Management_Cheat_Sheet#Web_Content_Caching

CWE Id

525

Low (Medium)X-Content-Type-Options Header Missing

Description

The Anti-MIME-Sniffing header X-Content-Type-Options was not set to 'nosniff'. This allows older versions of Internet Explorer and Chrome to perform MIME-sniffing on the response body, potentially causing the response body to be interpreted and displayed as a content type other than the declared content type. Current (early 2014) and legacy versions of Firefox will use the declared content type (if one is set), rather than performing MIME-sniffing.
URL
https://och.berkeley.edu/registration/lister
Other information
This issue still applies to error type pages (401, 403, 500, etc) as those pages are often still affected by injection issues, in which case there is still concern for browsers sniffing pages away from their actual content type.

Solution

Ensure that the application/web server sets the Content-Type header appropriately, and that it sets the X-Content-Type-Options header to 'nosniff' for all web pages.

If possible, ensure that the end user uses a standards-compliant and modern web browser that does not perform MIME-sniffing at all, or that can be directed by the web application/web server to not perform MIME-sniffing.

Reference

http://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/ie/gg622941%28v=vs.85%29.aspx

https://www.owasp.org/index.php/List_of_useful_HTTP_headers

WASC Id

15

Low (Medium)Cookie set without HttpOnly flag

Description

A cookie has been set without the HttpOnly flag, which means that the cookie can be accessed by JavaScript. If a malicious script can be run on this page then the cookie will be accessible and can be transmitted to another site. If this is a session cookie then session hijacking may be possible.
URL
https://och.berkeley.edu/registration/lister
Parameter
PHPSESSID=hg3jtklsjvjshalrv25oi7a2h5; path=/
Evidence
PHPSESSID=hg3jtklsjvjshalrv25oi7a2h5; path=/

Solution

Reference

www.owasp.org/index.php/HttpOnly

Low (Medium)Web Browser XSS Protection Not Enabled

Description

Web Browser XSS Protection is not enabled, or is disabled by the configuration of the 'X-XSS-Protection' HTTP response header on the web server
URL
https://och.berkeley.edu/registration/lister
Other information
The X-XSS-Protection HTTP response header allows the web server to enable or disable the web browser's XSS protection mechanism. The following values would attempt to enable it: X-XSS-Protection: 1; mode=block X-XSS-Protection: 1; report=http://www.example.com/xss The following values would disable it: X-XSS-Protection: 0 The X-XSS-Protection HTTP response header is currently supported on Internet Explorer, Chrome and Safari (WebKit). Note that this alert is only raised if the response body could potentially contain an XSS payload (with a text-based content type, with a non-zero length).

Solution

Ensure that the web browser's XSS filter is enabled, by setting the X-XSS-Protection HTTP response header to '1'.

Reference

https://www.owasp.org/index.php/XSS_(Cross_Site_Scripting)_Prevention_Cheat_Sheet

https://blog.veracode.com/2014/03/guidelines-for-setting-security-headers/

Evidence
visid_incap_496857=55t3894ZTXuO/EtWAEI40u7w1VYAAAAAQUIPAAAAAADvmWI4FiNwJgeaGAWPUKLv; expires=Wed, 01 Mar 2017 12:23:48 GMT; path=/; Domain=.berkeley.edu

Solution

Whenever a cookie contains sensitive information or is a session token, then it should always be passed using an encrypted tunnel. Ensure that the secure flag is set for cookies containing such sensitive information.

Reference

http://www.owasp.org/index.php/Testing_for_cookies_attributes_(OWASP-SM-002)

WASC Id

13

Low (Medium)Cookie set without secure flag

Description

A cookie has been set without the secure flag, which means that the cookie can be accessed via unencrypted connections.
URL
https://och.berkeley.edu/v2/css/ocp.search.1449272070.css
Parameter
incap_ses_124_496857=fnRZcmqDbyPupr5nPoq4Ae7w1VYAAAAArgKhcnkpyfbNl9k9kJjANQ==; path=/; Domain=.berkeley.edu
Evidence
incap_ses_124_496857=fnRZcmqDbyPupr5nPoq4Ae7w1VYAAAAArgKhcnkpyfbNl9k9kJjANQ==; path=/; Domain=.berkeley.edu

Solution

Whenever a cookie contains sensitive information or is a session token, then it should always be passed using an encrypted tunnel. Ensure that the secure flag is set for cookies containing such sensitive information.

Reference

http://www.owasp.org/index.php/Testing_for_cookies_attributes_(OWASP-SM-002)

WASC Id

13

Low (Medium)Web Browser XSS Protection Not Enabled

Description

Web Browser XSS Protection is not enabled, or is disabled by the configuration of the 'X-XSS-Protection' HTTP response header on the web server
URL
https://och.berkeley.edu/v2/css/ocp.search.1449272070.css
Other information
The X-XSS-Protection HTTP response header allows the web server to enable or disable the web browser's XSS protection mechanism. The following values would attempt to enable it: X-XSS-Protection: 1; mode=block X-XSS-Protection: 1; report=http://www.example.com/xss The following values would disable it: X-XSS-Protection: 0 The X-XSS-Protection HTTP response header is currently supported on Internet Explorer, Chrome and Safari (WebKit). Note that this alert is only raised if the response body could potentially contain an XSS payload (with a text-based content type, with a non-zero length).

Solution

Ensure that the web browser's XSS filter is enabled, by setting the X-XSS-Protection HTTP response header to '1'.

Reference

https://www.owasp.org/index.php/XSS_(Cross_Site_Scripting)_Prevention_Cheat_Sheet

https://blog.veracode.com/2014/03/guidelines-for-setting-security-headers/

CWE Id

933

WASC Id

14

Low (Medium)X-Content-Type-Options Header Missing

Description

The Anti-MIME-Sniffing header X-Content-Type-Options was not set to 'nosniff'. This allows older versions of Internet Explorer and Chrome to perform MIME-sniffing on the response body, potentially causing the response body to be interpreted and displayed as a content type other than the declared content type. Current (early 2014) and legacy versions of Firefox will use the declared content type (if one is set), rather than performing MIME-sniffing.
URL
https://och.berkeley.edu/v2/css/ocp.search.1449272070.css
Other information
This issue still applies to error type pages (401, 403, 500, etc) as those pages are often still affected by injection issues, in which case there is still concern for browsers sniffing pages away from their actual content type.

Solution

Ensure that the application/web server sets the Content-Type header appropriately, and that it sets the X-Content-Type-Options header to 'nosniff' for all web pages.

If possible, ensure that the end user uses a standards-compliant and modern web browser that does not perform MIME-sniffing at all, or that can be directed by the web application/web server to not perform MIME-sniffing.

Reference

http://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/ie/gg622941%28v=vs.85%29.aspx

https://www.owasp.org/index.php/List_of_useful_HTTP_headers

WASC Id

15

Low (Medium)Incomplete or No Cache-control and Pragma HTTP Header Set

Description

The cache-control and pragma HTTP header have not been set properly or are missing allowing the browser and proxies to cache content.
URL
https://och.berkeley.edu/index/%5C%22%5C/auth%5C/help-cookies%5C%22
Evidence
no-store, no-cache, must-revalidate, post-check=0, pre-check=0

Solution

Whenever possible ensure the cache-control HTTP header is set with no-cache, no-store, must-revalidate, private; and that the pragma HTTP header is set with no-cache.

Reference

https://www.owasp.org/index.php/Session_Management_Cheat_Sheet#Web_Content_Caching

CWE Id

525

Low (Medium)Cookie set without HttpOnly flag

Description

A cookie has been set without the HttpOnly flag, which means that the cookie can be accessed by JavaScript. If a malicious script can be run on this page then the cookie will be accessible and can be transmitted to another site. If this is a session cookie then session hijacking may be possible.
URL
https://och.berkeley.edu/index/%5C%22%5C/auth%5C/help-cookies%5C%22
Parameter
PHPSESSID=gu6dpfbjf8v48hifrb7vcj2427; path=/
Evidence
PHPSESSID=gu6dpfbjf8v48hifrb7vcj2427; path=/

Solution

Ensure that the HttpOnly flag is set for all cookies.

Reference

www.owasp.org/index.php/HttpOnly

13

Low (Medium)Cross-Domain JavaScript Source File Inclusion

Description

The page at the following URL includes one or more script files from a third-party domain
URL
https://och.berkeley.edu/index/%5C%22%5C/auth%5C/help-cookies%5C%22
Parameter
//ajax.googleapis.com/ajax/libs/jquery/1.11.1/jquery.min.js
Evidence
//ajax.googleapis.com/ajax/libs/jquery/1.11.1/jquery.min.js

Solution

Ensure JavaScript source files are loaded from only trusted sources, and the sources can't be controlled by end users of the application

Reference

Low (Medium)Web Browser XSS Protection Not Enabled

Description

Web Browser XSS Protection is not enabled, or is disabled by the configuration of the 'X-XSS-Protection' HTTP response header on the web server
URL
https://och.berkeley.edu/index/%5C%22%5C/auth%5C/help-cookies%5C%22
Other information
The X-XSS-Protection HTTP response header allows the web server to enable or disable the web browser's XSS protection mechanism. The following values would attempt to enable it: X-XSS-Protection: 1; mode=block X-XSS-Protection: 1; report=http://www.example.com/xss The following values would disable it: X-XSS-Protection: 0 The X-XSS-Protection HTTP response header is currently supported on Internet Explorer, Chrome and Safari (WebKit). Note that this alert is only raised if the response body could potentially contain an XSS payload (with a text-based content type, with a non-zero length).

Solution

Ensure that the web browser's XSS filter is enabled, by setting the X-XSS-Protection HTTP response header to '1'.

Reference

https://www.owasp.org/index.php/XSS_(Cross_Site_Scripting)_Prevention_Cheat_Sheet

Reference

Low (Medium)Web Browser XSS Protection Not Enabled

Description

Web Browser XSS Protection is not enabled, or is disabled by the configuration of the 'X-XSS-Protection' HTTP response header on the web server
URL
https://och.berkeley.edu/index/%5C%22http:%5C/%5C/och.berkeley.edu%5C%22
Other information
The X-XSS-Protection HTTP response header allows the web server to enable or disable the web browser's XSS protection mechanism. The following values would attempt to enable it: X-XSS-Protection: 1; mode=block X-XSS-Protection: 1; report=http://www.example.com/xss The following values would disable it: X-XSS-Protection: 0 The X-XSS-Protection HTTP response header is currently supported on Internet Explorer, Chrome and Safari (WebKit). Note that this alert is only raised if the response body could potentially contain an XSS payload (with a text-based content type, with a non-zero length).

Solution

Ensure that the web browser's XSS filter is enabled, by setting the X-XSS-Protection HTTP response header to '1'.

Reference

https://www.owasp.org/index.php/XSS_(Cross_Site_Scripting)_Prevention_Cheat_Sheet

https://blog.veracode.com/2014/03/guidelines-for-setting-security-headers/

CWE Id

933

WASC Id

14

Low (Medium)X-Content-Type-Options Header Missing

Description

The Anti-MIME-Sniffing header X-Content-Type-Options was not set to 'nosniff'. This allows older versions of Internet Explorer and Chrome to perform MIME-sniffing on the response body, potentially causing the response body to be interpreted and displayed as a content type other than the declared content type. Current (early 2014) and legacy versions of Firefox will use the declared content type (if one is set), rather than performing MIME-sniffing.
URL
https://och.berkeley.edu/index/%5C%22http:%5C/%5C/och.berkeley.edu%5C%22
Other information
This issue still applies to error type pages (401, 403, 500, etc) as those pages are often still affected by injection issues, in which case there is still concern for browsers sniffing pages away from their actual content type.

Solution

Ensure that the application/web server sets the Content-Type header appropriately, and that it sets the X-Content-Type-Options header to 'nosniff' for all web pages.

If possible, ensure that the end user uses a standards-compliant and modern web browser that does not perform MIME-sniffing at all, or that can be directed by the web application/web server to not perform MIME-sniffing.

Reference

http://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/ie/gg622941%28v=vs.85%29.aspx

https://www.owasp.org/index.php/List_of_useful_HTTP_headers

WASC Id

15

Low (Medium)Incomplete or No Cache-control and Pragma HTTP Header Set

Description

The cache-control and pragma HTTP header have not been set properly or are missing allowing the browser and proxies to cache content.
URL
https://och.berkeley.edu/help/category/getting-started
Evidence
no-store, no-cache, must-revalidate, post-check=0, pre-check=0

Solution

Whenever possible ensure the cache-control HTTP header is set with no-cache, no-store, must-revalidate, private; and that the pragma HTTP header is set with no-cache.

Reference

https://www.owasp.org/index.php/Session_Management_Cheat_Sheet#Web_Content_Caching

CWE Id

525

Low (Medium)Cookie set without HttpOnly flag

Description

A cookie has been set without the HttpOnly flag, which means that the cookie can be accessed by JavaScript. If a malicious script can be run on this page then the cookie will be accessible and can be transmitted to another site. If this is a session cookie then session hijacking may be possible.
URL
https://och.berkeley.edu/help/category/getting-started
Parameter
PHPSESSID=m4vjng8os54irte8knsvckneo7; path=/
Evidence
PHPSESSID=m4vjng8os54irte8knsvckneo7; path=/

Solution

Ensure that the HttpOnly flag is set for all cookies.

Reference

www.owasp.org/index.php/HttpOnly

A cookie has been set without the HttpOnly flag, which means that the cookie can be accessed by JavaScript. If a malicious script can be run on this page then the cookie will be accessible and can be transmitted to another site. If this is a session cookie then session hijacking may be possible.
URL
https://och.berkeley.edu/help/category/getting-started

Low (Medium)Cookie set without HttpOnly flag

Description

A cookie has been set without the HttpOnly flag, which means that the cookie can be accessed by JavaScript. If a malicious script can be run on this page then the cookie will be accessible and can be transmitted to another site. If this is a session cookie then session hijacking may be possible.
URL
https://och.berkeley.edu/help/category/getting-started
Parameter
incap_ses_124_496857=O2RKLbGqY1Gxqb5nPoq4Ae/w1VYAAAAAVDZ7HvzZfM6yz/nB46V4Pw==; path=/; Domain=.berkeley.edu
Evidence
incap_ses_124_496857=O2RKLbGqY1Gxqb5nPoq4Ae/w1VYAAAAAVDZ7HvzZfM6yz/nB46V4Pw==; path=/; Domain=.berkeley.edu

Reference

www.owasp.org/index.php/HttpOnly

WASC Id

13

Low (Medium)Cookie set without secure flag

Description

A cookie has been set without the secure flag, which means that the cookie can be accessed via unencrypted connections.
URL
https://och.berkeley.edu/help/category/getting-started
Parameter
PHPSESSID=m4vjng8os54irte8knsvckneo7; path=/
Evidence
PHPSESSID=m4vjng8os54irte8knsvckneo7; path=/

Solution

Whenever a cookie contains sensitive information or is a session token, then it should always be passed using an encrypted tunnel. Ensure that the secure flag is set for cookies containing such sensitive information.

Reference

http://www.owasp.org/index.php/Testing_for_cookies_attributes_(OWASP-SM-002)

WASC Id

13

Description

A cookie has been set without the secure flag, which means that the cookie can be accessed via unencrypted connections.
URL
https://och.berkeley.edu/help/category/getting-started

WASC Id

13

Low (Medium)Cross-Domain JavaScript Source File Inclusion

Description

The page at the following URL includes one or more script files from a third-party domain
URL
https://och.berkeley.edu/help/category/getting-started
Parameter
//ajax.googleapis.com/ajax/libs/jquery/1.11.1/jquery.min.js
Evidence
//ajax.googleapis.com/ajax/libs/jquery/1.11.1/jquery.min.js

Solution

Ensure JavaScript source files are loaded from only trusted sources, and the sources can't be controlled by end users of the application

Reference

Low (Medium)Cross-Domain JavaScript Source File Inclusion

Description

The page at the following URL includes one or more script files from a third-party domain
URL
https://och.berkeley.edu/help/category/getting-started
Parameter
//translate.google.com/translate_a/element.js?cb=googleTranslateElementInit
Evidence
//translate.google.com/translate_a/element.js?cb=googleTranslateElementInit

Solution

Ensure JavaScript source files are loaded from only trusted sources, and the sources can't be controlled by end users of the application

Reference

Low (Medium)Web Browser XSS Protection Not Enabled

Description

Web Browser XSS Protection is not enabled, or is disabled by the configuration of the 'X-XSS-Protection' HTTP response header on the web server
URL
https://och.berkeley.edu/help/category/getting-started
Other information
The X-XSS-Protection HTTP response header allows the web server to enable or disable the web browser's XSS protection mechanism. The following values would attempt to enable it: X-XSS-Protection: 1; mode=block X-XSS-Protection: 1; report=http://www.example.com/xss The following values would disable it: X-XSS-Protection: 0 The X-XSS-Protection HTTP response header is currently supported on Internet Explorer, Chrome and Safari (WebKit). Note that this alert is only raised if the response body could potentially contain an XSS payload (with a text-based content type, with a non-zero length).

Solution

Ensure that the web browser's XSS filter is enabled, by setting the X-XSS-Protection HTTP response header to '1'.

Reference

https://www.owasp.org/index.php/XSS_(Cross_Site_Scripting)_Prevention_Cheat_Sheet

https://blog.veracode.com/2014/03/guidelines-for-setting-security-headers/

This allows older versions of Internet Explorer and Chrome to perform MIME-sniffing on the response body, potentially causing the response body to be interpreted and displayed as a content type other than the declared content type. Current (early 2014) and legacy versions of Firefox will use the declared content type (if one is set), rather than performing MIME-sniffing.
URL
https://och.berkeley.edu/help/category/getting-started
Other information
This issue still applies to error type pages (401, 403, 500, etc) as those pages are often still affected by injection issues, in which case there is still concern for browsers sniffing pages away from their actual content type.

Solution

Ensure that the application/web server sets the Content-Type header appropriately, and that it sets the X-Content-Type-Options header to 'nosniff' for all web pages.

If possible, ensure that the end user uses a standards-compliant and modern web browser that does not perform MIME-sniffing at all, or that can be directed by the web application/web server to not perform MIME-sniffing.

Ensure that the HttpOnly flag is set for all cookies.

Reference

www.owasp.org/index.php/HttpOnly

WASC Id

13

Low (Medium)Cookie set without HttpOnly flag

Description

A cookie has been set without the HttpOnly flag, which means that the cookie can be accessed by JavaScript. If a malicious script can be run on this page then the cookie will be accessible and can be transmitted to another site. If this is a session cookie then session hijacking may be possible.
URL
https://och.berkeley.edu/help/category/frequent-questions
Parameter
incap_ses_124_496857=kt0SJ2Ii72Peqr5nPoq4Ae/w1VYAAAAABlAJSLvh//B5EijHX3LSnw==; path=/; Domain=.berkeley.edu
Evidence
incap_ses_124_496857=kt0SJ2Ii72Peqr5nPoq4Ae/w1VYAAAAABlAJSLvh//B5EijHX3LSnw==; path=/; Domain=.berkeley.edu

Solution

Ensure that the HttpOnly flag is set for all cookies.

Reference

www.owasp.org/index.php/HttpOnly

WASC Id

13

Low (Medium)Cookie set without secure flag

Description

A cookie has been set without the secure flag, which means that the cookie can be accessed via unencrypted connections.
URL
https://och.berkeley.edu/help/category/frequent-questions
Parameter
PHPSESSID=901k9a26h6qsfv6vorcil3ldp1; path=/
Evidence
PHPSESSID=901k9a26h6qsfv6vorcil3ldp1; path=/

Solution

Whenever a cookie contains sensitive information or is a session token, then it should always be passed using an encrypted tunnel. Ensure that the secure flag is set for cookies containing such sensitive information.

Reference

http://www.owasp.org/index.php/Testing_for_cookies_attributes_(OWASP-SM-002)

A cookie has been set without the secure flag, which means that the cookie can be accessed via unencrypted connections.
URL
https://och.berkeley.edu/help/category/frequent-questions

URL

Parameter

WASC Id

13

Low (Medium)Cross-Domain JavaScript Source File Inclusion

Description

The page at the following URL includes one or more script files from a third-party domain
URL
https://och.berkeley.edu/help/category/frequent-questions
Parameter
//ajax.googleapis.com/ajax/libs/jquery/1.11.1/jquery.min.js
Evidence
//ajax.googleapis.com/ajax/libs/jquery/1.11.1/jquery.min.js

Solution

Ensure JavaScript source files are loaded from only trusted sources, and the sources can't be controlled by end users of the application

Reference

Low (Medium)Cross-Domain JavaScript Source File Inclusion

Description

The page at the following URL includes one or more script files from a third-party domain
URL
https://och.berkeley.edu/help/category/frequent-questions
Parameter
//translate.google.com/translate_a/element.js?cb=googleTranslateElementInit
Evidence
//translate.google.com/translate_a/element.js?cb=googleTranslateElementInit

Solution

Ensure JavaScript source files are loaded from only trusted sources, and the sources can't be controlled by end users of the application

Reference

Low (Medium)Web Browser XSS Protection Not Enabled

Description

Web Browser XSS Protection is not enabled, or is disabled by the configuration of the 'X-XSS-Protection' HTTP response header on the web server
URL
https://och.berkeley.edu/help/category/frequent-questions
Other information
The X-XSS-Protection HTTP response header allows the web server to enable or disable the web browser's XSS protection mechanism. The following values would attempt to enable it: X-XSS-Protection: 1; mode=block X-XSS-Protection: 1; report=http://www.example.com/xss The following values would disable it: X-XSS-Protection: 0 The X-XSS-Protection HTTP response header is currently supported on Internet Explorer, Chrome and Safari (WebKit). Note that this alert is only raised if the response body could potentially contain an XSS payload (with a text-based content type, with a non-zero length).

Solution

Ensure that the web browser's XSS filter is enabled, by setting the X-XSS-Protection HTTP response header to '1'.

Reference

https://www.owasp.org/index.php/XSS_(Cross_Site_Scripting)_Prevention_Cheat_Sheet

https://blog.veracode.com/2014/03/guidelines-for-setting-security-headers/

CWE Id

933

WASC Id

14

Low (Medium)X-Content-Type-Options Header Missing

Description

The Anti-MIME-Sniffing header X-Content-Type-Options was not set to 'nosniff'. This allows older versions of Internet Explorer and Chrome to perform MIME-sniffing on the response body, potentially causing the response body to be interpreted and displayed as a content type other than the declared content type. Current (early 2014) and legacy versions of Firefox will use the declared content type (if one is set), rather than performing MIME-sniffing.
URL
https://och.berkeley.edu/help/category/frequent-questions
Other information
This issue still applies to error type pages (401, 403, 500, etc) as those pages are often still affected by injection issues, in which case there is still concern for browsers sniffing pages away from their actual content type.

Solution

Ensure that the application/web server sets the Content-Type header appropriately, and that it sets the X-Content-Type-Options header to 'nosniff' for all web pages.

If possible, ensure that the end user uses a standards-compliant and modern web browser that does not perform MIME-sniffing at all, or that can be directed by the web application/web server to not perform MIME-sniffing.

Reference

http://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/ie/gg622941%28v=vs.85%29.aspx

https://www.owasp.org/index.php/List_of_useful_HTTP_headers

WASC Id

15

Low (Medium)Incomplete or No Cache-control and Pragma HTTP Header Set

Description

The cache-control and pragma HTTP header have not been set properly or are missing allowing the browser and proxies to cache content.
URL
https://och.berkeley.edu/help/search
Evidence
no-store, no-cache, must-revalidate, post-check=0, pre-check=0

Solution

Whenever possible ensure the cache-control HTTP header is set with no-cache, no-store, must-revalidate, private; and that the pragma HTTP header is set with no-cache.

Reference

https://www.owasp.org/index.php/Session_Management_Cheat_Sheet#Web_Content_Caching

CWE Id

525

Reference

www.owasp.org/index.php/HttpOnly

Description

Web Browser XSS Protection is not enabled, or is disabled by the configuration of the 'X-XSS-Protection' HTTP response header on the web server
URL
https://och.berkeley.edu/help/search
Other information
The X-XSS-Protection HTTP response header allows the web server to enable or disable the web browser's XSS protection mechanism. The following values would attempt to enable it: X-XSS-Protection: 1; mode=block X-XSS-Protection: 1; report=http://www.example.com/xss The following values would disable it: X-XSS-Protection: 0 The X-XSS-Protection HTTP response header is currently supported on Internet Explorer, Chrome and Safari (WebKit). Note that this alert is only raised if the response body could potentially contain an XSS payload (with a text-based content type, with a non-zero length).

Solution

Ensure that the web browser's XSS filter is enabled, by setting the X-XSS-Protection HTTP response header to '1'.

Reference

https://www.owasp.org/index.php/XSS_(Cross_Site_Scripting)_Prevention_Cheat_Sheet

Ensure that the HttpOnly flag is set for all cookies.

Reference

www.owasp.org/index.php/HttpOnly

Description

Low (Medium)Cookie set without secure flag

Evidence
PHPSESSID=lvvc6gpnvau93j7ni9acm2vhd0; path=/

Solution

Reference

http://www.owasp.org/index.php/Testing_for_cookies_attributes_(OWASP-SM-002)

Solution

Reference

http://www.owasp.org/index.php/Testing_for_cookies_attributes_(OWASP-SM-002)

https://och.berkeley.edu/tracking/resource/id/3256/
Parameter
incap_ses_124_496857=jgvPRkWkoTDcuL5nPoq4AfPw1VYAAAAAEZ7qNFNTVVPxI6ysYtmO4Q==; path=/; Domain=.berkeley.edu
Evidence
incap_ses_124_496857=jgvPRkWkoTDcuL5nPoq4AfPw1VYAAAAAEZ7qNFNTVVPxI6ysYtmO4Q==; path=/; Domain=.berkeley.edu

Solution

Ensure that the HttpOnly flag is set for all cookies.

Reference

www.owasp.org/index.php/HttpOnly

WASC Id

13

Low (Medium)Cookie set without secure flag

Description

A cookie has been set without the secure flag, which means that the cookie can be accessed via unencrypted connections.
URL
https://och.berkeley.edu/tracking/resource/id/3256/
Parameter
PHPSESSID=e16nd61sdjft6qkqa3kb14jks7; path=/
Evidence
PHPSESSID=e16nd61sdjft6qkqa3kb14jks7; path=/

Solution

Whenever a cookie contains sensitive information or is a session token, then it should always be passed using an encrypted tunnel. Ensure that the secure flag is set for cookies containing such sensitive information.

Reference

http://www.owasp.org/index.php/Testing_for_cookies_attributes_(OWASP-SM-002)

13

Low (Medium)Cookie set without secure flag

Description

A cookie has been set without the secure flag, which means that the cookie can be accessed via unencrypted connections.
URL
https://och.berkeley.edu/tracking/resource/id/3244/
Parameter
PHPSESSID=iqla6jhp57fqp07ssmvthns1c3; path=/
Evidence
PHPSESSID=iqla6jhp57fqp07ssmvthns1c3; path=/

Solution

Whenever a cookie contains sensitive information or is a session token, then it should always be passed using an encrypted tunnel. Ensure that the secure flag is set for cookies containing such sensitive information.

Reference

http://www.owasp.org/index.php/Testing_for_cookies_attributes_(OWASP-SM-002)

WASC Id

13

Low (Medium)Cookie set without secure flag

Description

A cookie has been set without the secure flag, which means that the cookie can be accessed via unencrypted connections.
URL
https://och.berkeley.edu/tracking/resource/id/3244/
Parameter
visid_incap_496857=T8yL6WD4SZWD3OcmbaFitPXw1VYAAAAAQUIPAAAAAAC64VRKNnzJjli3MbZyh9HZ; expires=Wed, 01 Mar 2017 12:23:46 GMT; path=/; Domain=.berkeley.edu
Evidence
visid_incap_496857=T8yL6WD4SZWD3OcmbaFitPXw1VYAAAAAQUIPAAAAAAC64VRKNnzJjli3MbZyh9HZ; expires=Wed, 01 Mar 2017 12:23:46 GMT; path=/; Domain=.berkeley.edu

URL
https://och.berkeley.edu/tracking/resource/id/3244/
Parameter
incap_ses_124_496857=A4G3RfYfx059w75nPoq4AfXw1VYAAAAA0/Y4zYPOG8r+Cu+mXQHkxw==; path=/; Domain=.berkeley.edu
Evidence
incap_ses_124_496857=A4G3RfYfx059w75nPoq4AfXw1VYAAAAA0/Y4zYPOG8r+Cu+mXQHkxw==; path=/; Domain=.berkeley.edu

WASC Id

13

Low (Medium)Cookie set without HttpOnly flag

Description

A cookie has been set without the HttpOnly flag, which means that the cookie can be accessed by JavaScript. If a malicious script can be run on this page then the cookie will be accessible and can be transmitted to another site. If this is a session cookie then session hijacking may be possible.
URL
https://och.berkeley.edu/tracking/resource/id/3248/
Parameter
PHPSESSID=e8ep1e3fnt9eu6b9gs9ked5le5; path=/
Evidence
PHPSESSID=e8ep1e3fnt9eu6b9gs9ked5le5; path=/

Solution

Ensure that the HttpOnly flag is set for all cookies.

Reference

www.owasp.org/index.php/HttpOnly

WASC Id

WASC Id

13

Low (Medium)Cookie set without secure flag

Description

A cookie has been set without the secure flag, which means that the cookie can be accessed via unencrypted connections.
URL
https://och.berkeley.edu/tracking/resource/id/3250/
Parameter
visid_incap_496857=FodkbDnZTCeI+RkPmSt1g/bw1VYAAAAAQUIPAAAAAADjRIULd9EwUzV2xhJwoOzD; expires=Wed, 01 Mar 2017 12:23:48 GMT; path=/; Domain=.berkeley.edu
Evidence
visid_incap_496857=FodkbDnZTCeI+RkPmSt1g/bw1VYAAAAAQUIPAAAAAADjRIULd9EwUzV2xhJwoOzD; expires=Wed, 01 Mar 2017 12:23:48 GMT; path=/; Domain=.berkeley.edu

Solution

Whenever a cookie contains sensitive information or is a session token, then it should always be passed using an encrypted tunnel. Ensure that the secure flag is set for cookies containing such sensitive information.

Reference

http://www.owasp.org/index.php/Testing_for_cookies_attributes_(OWASP-SM-002)

WASC Id

13

Low (Medium)Cookie set without secure flag

Description

A cookie has been set without the secure flag, which means that the cookie can be accessed via unencrypted connections.
URL
https://och.berkeley.edu/tracking/resource/id/3250/
Parameter
incap_ses_124_496857=wSEMY+YbshguyL5nPoq4Afbw1VYAAAAAxkxmDqvRLKk3tfgJpPW1Cw==; path=/; Domain=.berkeley.edu
Evidence
incap_ses_124_496857=wSEMY+YbshguyL5nPoq4Afbw1VYAAAAAxkxmDqvRLKk3tfgJpPW1Cw==; path=/; Domain=.berkeley.edu

Solution

Whenever a cookie contains sensitive information or is a session token, then it should always be passed using an encrypted tunnel. Ensure that the secure flag is set for cookies containing such sensitive information.

Reference

http://www.owasp.org/index.php/Testing_for_cookies_attributes_(OWASP-SM-002)

WASC Id

13

Low (Medium)Cookie set without HttpOnly flag

Description

A cookie has been set without the HttpOnly flag, which means that the cookie can be accessed by JavaScript. If a malicious script can be run on this page then the cookie will be accessible and can be transmitted to another site. If this is a session cookie then session hijacking may be possible.
URL
https://och.berkeley.edu/tracking/resource/id/3247/
Parameter
PHPSESSID=5b6ijsbov8epn2md5d9mq8sb30; path=/
Evidence
PHPSESSID=5b6ijsbov8epn2md5d9mq8sb30; path=/

Solution

Ensure that the HttpOnly flag is set for all cookies.

Reference

www.owasp.org/index.php/HttpOnly

http://www.owasp.org/index.php/Testing_for_cookies_attributes_(OWASP-SM-002)

WASC Id

WASC Id

13

Low (Medium)Incomplete or No Cache-control and Pragma HTTP Header Set

Description

The cache-control and pragma HTTP header have not been set properly or are missing allowing the browser and proxies to cache content.
URL
https://och.berkeley.edu/v2/js/registration.min.1430390459.js
Evidence
max-age=419825, public

Solution

Whenever possible ensure the cache-control HTTP header is set with no-cache, no-store, must-revalidate, private; and that the pragma HTTP header is set with no-cache.

Reference

https://www.owasp.org/index.php/Session_Management_Cheat_Sheet#Web_Content_Caching

WASC Id

13

Low (Medium)Web Browser XSS Protection Not Enabled

Description

Web Browser XSS Protection is not enabled, or is disabled by the configuration of the 'X-XSS-Protection' HTTP response header on the web server
URL
https://och.berkeley.edu/v2/js/registration.min.1430390459.js
Other information
The X-XSS-Protection HTTP response header allows the web server to enable or disable the web browser's XSS protection mechanism. The following values would attempt to enable it: X-XSS-Protection: 1; mode=block X-XSS-Protection: 1; report=http://www.example.com/xss The following values would disable it: X-XSS-Protection: 0 The X-XSS-Protection HTTP response header is currently supported on Internet Explorer, Chrome and Safari (WebKit). Note that this alert is only raised if the response body could potentially contain an XSS payload (with a text-based content type, with a non-zero length).

Solution

Ensure that the web browser's XSS filter is enabled, by setting the X-XSS-Protection HTTP response header to '1'.

Reference

https://www.owasp.org/index.php/XSS_(Cross_Site_Scripting)_Prevention_Cheat_Sheet

https://blog.veracode.com/2014/03/guidelines-for-setting-security-headers/

CWE Id

933

WASC Id

14

Low (Medium)X-Content-Type-Options Header Missing

Description

The Anti-MIME-Sniffing header X-Content-Type-Options was not set to 'nosniff'. This allows older versions of Internet Explorer and Chrome to perform MIME-sniffing on the response body, potentially causing the response body to be interpreted and displayed as a content type other than the declared content type. Current (early 2014) and legacy versions of Firefox will use the declared content type (if one is set), rather than performing MIME-sniffing.
URL
https://och.berkeley.edu/v2/js/registration.min.1430390459.js
Other information
This issue still applies to error type pages (401, 403, 500, etc) as those pages are often still affected by injection issues, in which case there is still concern for browsers sniffing pages away from their actual content type.

Solution

Ensure that the application/web server sets the Content-Type header appropriately, and that it sets the X-Content-Type-Options header to 'nosniff' for all web pages.

If possible, ensure that the end user uses a standards-compliant and modern web browser that does not perform MIME-sniffing at all, or that can be directed by the web application/web server to not perform MIME-sniffing.

Reference

http://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/ie/gg622941%28v=vs.85%29.aspx

https://www.owasp.org/index.php/List_of_useful_HTTP_headers

WASC Id

15

Reference

http://www.owasp.org/index.php/Testing_for_cookies_attributes_(OWASP-SM-002)

WASC Id

13

WASC Id

13

Low (Medium)Incomplete or No Cache-control and Pragma HTTP Header Set

Description

The cache-control and pragma HTTP header have not been set properly or are missing allowing the browser and proxies to cache content.
URL
https://och.berkeley.edu/registration/guest
Evidence
no-store, no-cache, must-revalidate, post-check=0, pre-check=0

Solution

Whenever possible ensure the cache-control HTTP header is set with no-cache, no-store, must-revalidate, private; and that the pragma HTTP header is set with no-cache.

Reference

https://www.owasp.org/index.php/Session_Management_Cheat_Sheet#Web_Content_Caching

CWE Id

525

WASC Id

13

Low (Medium)Cross-Domain JavaScript Source File Inclusion

Description

The page at the following URL includes one or more script files from a third-party domain
URL
https://och.berkeley.edu/registration/guest
Parameter
//ajax.googleapis.com/ajax/libs/jquery/1.11.1/jquery.min.js
Evidence
//ajax.googleapis.com/ajax/libs/jquery/1.11.1/jquery.min.js

Solution

Ensure JavaScript source files are loaded from only trusted sources, and the sources can't be controlled by end users of the application

Reference

Low (Medium)Cross-Domain JavaScript Source File Inclusion

Description

The page at the following URL includes one or more script files from a third-party domain
URL
https://och.berkeley.edu/registration/guest
Parameter
//translate.google.com/translate_a/element.js?cb=googleTranslateElementInit
Evidence
//translate.google.com/translate_a/element.js?cb=googleTranslateElementInit

Solution

Ensure JavaScript source files are loaded from only trusted sources, and the sources can't be controlled by end users of the application

Reference

Low (Medium)Web Browser XSS Protection Not Enabled

Description

Web Browser XSS Protection is not enabled, or is disabled by the configuration of the 'X-XSS-Protection' HTTP response header on the web server
URL
https://och.berkeley.edu/registration/guest
Other information
The X-XSS-Protection HTTP response header allows the web server to enable or disable the web browser's XSS protection mechanism. The following values would attempt to enable it: X-XSS-Protection: 1; mode=block X-XSS-Protection: 1; report=http://www.example.com/xss The following values would disable it: X-XSS-Protection: 0 The X-XSS-Protection HTTP response header is currently supported on Internet Explorer, Chrome and Safari (WebKit). Note that this alert is only raised if the response body could potentially contain an XSS payload (with a text-based content type, with a non-zero length).

Solution

Ensure that the web browser's XSS filter is enabled, by setting the X-XSS-Protection HTTP response header to '1'.

Reference

https://www.owasp.org/index.php/XSS_(Cross_Site_Scripting)_Prevention_Cheat_Sheet

https://blog.veracode.com/2014/03/guidelines-for-setting-security-headers/

CWE Id

933

WASC Id

14

Low (Medium)Password Autocomplete in browser

Description

AUTOCOMPLETE attribute is not disabled in HTML FORM/INPUT element containing password type input. Passwords may be stored in browsers and retrieved.
URL
https://och.berkeley.edu/registration/guest
Parameter
input
Evidence
<input type="password" name="password" id="password" value="" placeholder="Password" required>

Solution

Turn off AUTOCOMPLETE attribute in form or individual input elements containing password by using AUTOCOMPLETE='OFF'

Reference

http://msdn.microsoft.com/library/default.asp?url=/workshop/author/forms/autocomplete_ovr.asp

CWE Id

525

Low (Medium)X-Content-Type-Options Header Missing

Description

The Anti-MIME-Sniffing header X-Content-Type-Options was not set to 'nosniff'. This allows older versions of Internet Explorer and Chrome to perform MIME-sniffing on the response body, potentially causing the response body to be interpreted and displayed as a content type other than the declared content type. Current (early 2014) and legacy versions of Firefox will use the declared content type (if one is set), rather than performing MIME-sniffing.
URL
https://och.berkeley.edu/registration/guest
Other information
This issue still applies to error type pages (401, 403, 500, etc) as those pages are often still affected by injection issues, in which case there is still concern for browsers sniffing pages away from their actual content type.

Solution

Ensure that the application/web server sets the Content-Type header appropriately, and that it sets the X-Content-Type-Options header to 'nosniff' for all web pages.

If possible, ensure that the end user uses a standards-compliant and modern web browser that does not perform MIME-sniffing at all, or that can be directed by the web application/web server to not perform MIME-sniffing.

Reference

http://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/ie/gg622941%28v=vs.85%29.aspx

https://www.owasp.org/index.php/List_of_useful_HTTP_headers

WASC Id

15

Low (Medium)Incomplete or No Cache-control and Pragma HTTP Header Set

Description

The cache-control and pragma HTTP header have not been set properly or are missing allowing the browser and proxies to cache content.
URL
https://och.berkeley.edu/auth/help-cookies
Evidence
no-store, no-cache, must-revalidate, post-check=0, pre-check=0

Solution

Whenever possible ensure the cache-control HTTP header is set with no-cache, no-store, must-revalidate, private; and that the pragma HTTP header is set with no-cache.

Reference

https://www.owasp.org/index.php/Session_Management_Cheat_Sheet#Web_Content_Caching

Low (Medium)Web Browser XSS Protection Not Enabled

Description

Web Browser XSS Protection is not enabled, or is disabled by the configuration of the 'X-XSS-Protection' HTTP response header on the web server
URL
https://och.berkeley.edu/auth/help-cookies
Other information
The X-XSS-Protection HTTP response header allows the web server to enable or disable the web browser's XSS protection mechanism. The following values would attempt to enable it: X-XSS-Protection: 1; mode=block X-XSS-Protection: 1; report=http://www.example.com/xss The following values would disable it: X-XSS-Protection: 0 The X-XSS-Protection HTTP response header is currently supported on Internet Explorer, Chrome and Safari (WebKit). Note that this alert is only raised if the response body could potentially contain an XSS payload (with a text-based content type, with a non-zero length).

Solution

Ensure that the web browser's XSS filter is enabled, by setting the X-XSS-Protection HTTP response header to '1'.

Reference

https://www.owasp.org/index.php/XSS_(Cross_Site_Scripting)_Prevention_Cheat_Sheet

https://blog.veracode.com/2014/03/guidelines-for-setting-security-headers/

This allows older versions of Internet Explorer and Chrome to perform MIME-sniffing on the response body, potentially causing the response body to be interpreted and displayed as a content type other than the declared content type. CWE Id

525

Low (Medium)Cookie set without HttpOnly flag

Description

A cookie has been set without the HttpOnly flag, which means that the cookie can be accessed by JavaScript. If a malicious script can be run on this page then the cookie will be accessible and can be transmitted to another site. If this is a session cookie then session hijacking may be possible.
URL
https://och.berkeley.edu/auth/cas?login=1
Parameter
PHPSESSID=tr50i1fh4lt3drj2ekikmt2g92; path=/
Evidence
PHPSESSID=tr50i1fh4lt3drj2ekikmt2g92; path=/

Solution

Ensure that the HttpOnly flag is set for all cookies.

Reference

www.owasp.org/index.php/HttpOnly

WASC Id

13

Low (Medium)Cookie set without HttpOnly flag

Description

A cookie has been set without the HttpOnly flag, which means that the cookie can be accessed by JavaScript. If a malicious script can be run on this page then the cookie will be accessible and can be transmitted to another site. If this is a session cookie then session hijacking may be possible.
URL
https://och.berkeley.edu/auth/cas?login=1
Parameter
visid_incap_496857=9lg6vzr7QsSN+7QZDSWmUPzw1VYAAAAAQUIPAAAAAAB3Ij+Dtid2MIGCe0/8FRrB; expires=Wed, 01 Mar 2017 12:23:48 GMT; path=/; Domain=.berkeley.edu
Evidence
visid_incap_496857=9lg6vzr7QsSN+7QZDSWmUPzw1VYAAAAAQUIPAAAAAAB3Ij+Dtid2MIGCe0/8FRrB; expires=Wed, 01 Mar 2017 12:23:48 GMT; path=/; Domain=.berkeley.edu

Solution

Ensure that the HttpOnly flag is set for all cookies.

Reference

www.owasp.org/index.php/HttpOnly

WASC Id

13

Low (Medium)Cookie set without HttpOnly flag

Description

A cookie has been set without the HttpOnly flag, which means that the cookie can be accessed by JavaScript. If a malicious script can be run on this page then the cookie will be accessible and can be transmitted to another site. If this is a session cookie then session hijacking may be possible.
URL
https://och.berkeley.edu/auth/cas?login=1
Parameter
incap_ses_124_496857=JpAHcbZNHRyn5L5nPoq4Afzw1VYAAAAAS9hZur0LosO/hwcl+EpQCA==; path=/; Domain=.berkeley.edu
Evidence
incap_ses_124_496857=JpAHcbZNHRyn5L5nPoq4Afzw1VYAAAAAS9hZur0LosO/hwcl+EpQCA==; path=/; Domain=.berkeley.edu

Solution

Ensure that the HttpOnly flag is set for all cookies.

Reference

www.owasp.org/index.php/HttpOnly

WASC Id

13

Low (Medium)Cookie set without secure flag

Description

A cookie has been set without the secure flag, which means that the cookie can be accessed via unencrypted connections.
URL
https://och.berkeley.edu/auth/cas?login=1
Parameter
PHPSESSID=tr50i1fh4lt3drj2ekikmt2g92; path=/
Evidence
PHPSESSID=tr50i1fh4lt3drj2ekikmt2g92; path=/

Solution

Whenever a cookie contains sensitive information or is a session token, then it should always be passed using an encrypted tunnel. Ensure that the secure flag is set for cookies containing such sensitive information.

Reference

http://www.owasp.org/index.php/Testing_for_cookies_attributes_(OWASP-SM-002)

WASC Id

13

Low (Medium)Cookie set without secure flag

Description

A cookie has been set without the secure flag, which means that the cookie can be accessed via unencrypted connections.
URL
https://och.berkeley.edu/auth/cas?login=1
Parameter
visid_incap_496857=9lg6vzr7QsSN+7QZDSWmUPzw1VYAAAAAQUIPAAAAAAB3Ij+Dtid2MIGCe0/8FRrB; expires=Wed, 01 Mar 2017 12:23:48 GMT; path=/; Domain=.berkeley.edu
Evidence
visid_incap_496857=9lg6vzr7QsSN+7QZDSWmUPzw1VYAAAAAQUIPAAAAAAB3Ij+Dtid2MIGCe0/8FRrB; expires=Wed, 01 Mar 2017 12:23:48 GMT; path=/; Domain=.berkeley.edu

Whenever a cookie contains sensitive information or is a session token, then it should always be passed using an encrypted tunnel. Ensure that the secure flag is set for cookies containing such sensitive information.

http://www.owasp.org/index.php/Testing_for_cookies_attributes_(OWASP-SM-002)

WASC Id

13

Low (Medium)Cookie set without secure flag

Description

A cookie has been set without the secure flag, which means that the cookie can be accessed via unencrypted connections.
URL
https://och.berkeley.edu/auth/cas?login=1
Parameter
incap_ses_124_496857=JpAHcbZNHRyn5L5nPoq4Afzw1VYAAAAAS9hZur0LosO/hwcl+EpQCA==; path=/; Domain=.berkeley.edu
Evidence
incap_ses_124_496857=JpAHcbZNHRyn5L5nPoq4Afzw1VYAAAAAS9hZur0LosO/hwcl+EpQCA==; path=/; Domain=.berkeley.edu

Solution

Whenever a cookie contains sensitive information or is a session token, then it should always be passed using an encrypted tunnel. Ensure that the secure flag is set for cookies containing such sensitive information.

Reference

http://www.owasp.org/index.php/Testing_for_cookies_attributes_(OWASP-SM-002)

WASC Id

13

Low (Medium)Web Browser XSS Protection Not Enabled

Description

Web Browser XSS Protection is not enabled, or is disabled by the configuration of the 'X-XSS-Protection' HTTP response header on the web server
URL
https://och.berkeley.edu/auth/cas?login=1
Other information
The X-XSS-Protection HTTP response header allows the web server to enable or disable the web browser's XSS protection mechanism. The following values would attempt to enable it: X-XSS-Protection: 1; mode=block X-XSS-Protection: 1; report=http://www.example.com/xss The following values would disable it: X-XSS-Protection: 0 The X-XSS-Protection HTTP response header is currently supported on Internet Explorer, Chrome and Safari (WebKit). Note that this alert is only raised if the response body could potentially contain an XSS payload (with a text-based content type, with a non-zero length).

Solution

Ensure that the web browser's XSS filter is enabled, by setting the X-XSS-Protection HTTP response header to '1'.

Reference

https://www.owasp.org/index.php/XSS_(Cross_Site_Scripting)_Prevention_Cheat_Sheet

https://blog.veracode.com/2014/03/guidelines-for-setting-security-headers/

CWE Id

933

WASC Id

14

Low (Medium)X-Content-Type-Options Header Missing

Description

The Anti-MIME-Sniffing header X-Content-Type-Options was not set to 'nosniff'. This allows older versions of Internet Explorer and Chrome to perform MIME-sniffing on the response body, potentially causing the response body to be interpreted and displayed as a content type other than the declared content type. Current (early 2014) and legacy versions of Firefox will use the declared content type (if one is set), rather than performing MIME-sniffing.
URL
https://och.berkeley.edu/auth/cas?login=1
Other information
This issue still applies to error type pages (401, 403, 500, etc) as those pages are often still affected by injection issues, in which case there is still concern for browsers sniffing pages away from their actual content type.

Solution

Ensure that the application/web server sets the Content-Type header appropriately, and that it sets the X-Content-Type-Options header to 'nosniff' for all web pages.

If possible, ensure that the end user uses a standards-compliant and modern web browser that does not perform MIME-sniffing at all, or that can be directed by the web application/web server to not perform MIME-sniffing.

Reference

http://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/ie/gg622941%28v=vs.85%29.aspx

https://www.owasp.org/index.php/List_of_useful_HTTP_headers

WASC Id

15

Low (Medium)Incomplete or No Cache-control and Pragma HTTP Header Set

Description

The cache-control and pragma HTTP header have not been set properly or are missing allowing the browser and proxies to cache content.
URL
https://och.berkeley.edu/auth/forgot-auth
Evidence
no-store, no-cache, must-revalidate, post-check=0, pre-check=0

Solution

Whenever possible ensure the cache-control HTTP header is set with no-cache, no-store, must-revalidate, private; and that the pragma HTTP header is set with no-cache.

Reference

https://www.owasp.org/index.php/Session_Management_Cheat_Sheet#Web_Content_Caching

CWE Id

525

Low (Medium)Cookie set without HttpOnly flag

Description

A cookie has been set without the HttpOnly flag, which means that the cookie can be accessed by JavaScript. If a malicious script can be run on this page then the cookie will be accessible and can be transmitted to another site. If this is a session cookie then session hijacking may be possible.

https://och.berkeley.edu/auth/forgot-auth
Parameter

Evidence
PHPSESSID=3keahmhc40ti24ol4e1tgbn8d4; path=/

Solution

Reference

www.owasp.org/index.php/HttpOnly

13

Low (Medium)Cross-Domain JavaScript Source File Inclusion

Description

The page at the following URL includes one or more script files from a third-party domain
URL
https://och.berkeley.edu/auth/forgot-auth
Parameter
//ajax.googleapis.com/ajax/libs/jquery/1.11.1/jquery.min.js
Evidence
//ajax.googleapis.com/ajax/libs/jquery/1.11.1/jquery.min.js

Solution

Ensure JavaScript source files are loaded from only trusted sources, and the sources can't be controlled by end users of the application

Reference

Low (Medium)Cross-Domain JavaScript Source File Inclusion

Description

The page at the following URL includes one or more script files from a third-party domain
URL
https://och.berkeley.edu/auth/forgot-auth
Parameter
//translate.google.com/translate_a/element.js?cb=googleTranslateElementInit
Evidence
//translate.google.com/translate_a/element.js?cb=googleTranslateElementInit

Solution

Ensure JavaScript source files are loaded from only trusted sources, and the sources can't be controlled by end users of the application

Reference

Low (Medium)Web Browser XSS Protection Not Enabled

Description

Web Browser XSS Protection is not enabled, or is disabled by the configuration of the 'X-XSS-Protection' HTTP response header on the web server
URL
https://och.berkeley.edu/auth/forgot-auth
Other information
The X-XSS-Protection HTTP response header allows the web server to enable or disable the web browser's XSS protection mechanism. The following values would attempt to enable it: X-XSS-Protection: 1; mode=block X-XSS-Protection: 1; report=http://www.example.com/xss The following values would disable it: X-XSS-Protection: 0 The X-XSS-Protection HTTP response header is currently supported on Internet Explorer, Chrome and Safari (WebKit). Note that this alert is only raised if the response body could potentially contain an XSS payload (with a text-based content type, with a non-zero length).

Solution

Ensure that the web browser's XSS filter is enabled, by setting the X-XSS-Protection HTTP response header to '1'.

Reference

https://www.owasp.org/index.php/XSS_(Cross_Site_Scripting)_Prevention_Cheat_Sheet

https://blog.veracode.com/2014/03/guidelines-for-setting-security-headers/

Ensure that the HttpOnly flag is set for all cookies.

Reference

www.owasp.org/index.php/HttpOnly

WASC Id

13

Low (Medium)Cookie set without HttpOnly flag

Description

A cookie has been set without the HttpOnly flag, which means that the cookie can be accessed by JavaScript. If a malicious script can be run on this page then the cookie will be accessible and can be transmitted to another site. If this is a session cookie then session hijacking may be possible.
URL
https://och.berkeley.edu/auth/login
Parameter
visid_incap_496857=E2r+hbXkT7mHUOiYo/6GE/3w1VYAAAAAQUIPAAAAAADLcByscikd8yy8qYFkio7t; expires=Wed, 01 Mar 2017 12:24:07 GMT; path=/; Domain=.berkeley.edu

Solution

Ensure that the HttpOnly flag is set for all cookies.

13

Description

A cookie has been set without the HttpOnly flag, which means that the cookie can be accessed by JavaScript. If a malicious script can be run on this page then the cookie will be accessible and can be transmitted to another site. If this is a session cookie then session hijacking may be possible.

WASC Id

13

Low (Medium)Cookie set without secure flag

Description

A cookie has been set without the secure flag, which means that the cookie can be accessed via unencrypted connections.
URL
https://och.berkeley.edu/auth/login
Parameter
PHPSESSID=qair3hj797eml834pp0iupeu76; path=/
Evidence
PHPSESSID=qair3hj797eml834pp0iupeu76; path=/

Solution

Whenever a cookie contains sensitive information or is a session token, then it should always be passed using an encrypted tunnel. Ensure that the secure flag is set for cookies containing such sensitive information.

Reference

http://www.owasp.org/index.php/Testing_for_cookies_attributes_(OWASP-SM-002)

WASC Id

A cookie has been set without the secure flag, which means that the cookie can be accessed via unencrypted connections.
URL
https://och.berkeley.edu/auth/login

Description

URL
https://och.berkeley.edu/auth/login
Parameter
incap_ses_124_496857=/nnSM85rjido575nPoq4Af3w1VYAAAAADLvZ7swftG2HCWv95lUISA==; path=/; Domain=.berkeley.edu

WASC Id

13

Low (Medium)Cross-Domain JavaScript Source File Inclusion

Description

The page at the following URL includes one or more script files from a third-party domain
URL
https://och.berkeley.edu/auth/login
Parameter
//ajax.googleapis.com/ajax/libs/jquery/1.11.1/jquery.min.js
Evidence
//ajax.googleapis.com/ajax/libs/jquery/1.11.1/jquery.min.js

Solution

Ensure JavaScript source files are loaded from only trusted sources, and the sources can't be controlled by end users of the application

Reference

Low (Medium)Cross-Domain JavaScript Source File Inclusion

Description

The page at the following URL includes one or more script files from a third-party domain
URL
https://och.berkeley.edu/auth/login
Parameter
//translate.google.com/translate_a/element.js?cb=googleTranslateElementInit
Evidence
//translate.google.com/translate_a/element.js?cb=googleTranslateElementInit

Solution

Ensure JavaScript source files are loaded from only trusted sources, and the sources can't be controlled by end users of the application

Reference

Low (Medium)Web Browser XSS Protection Not Enabled

Description

Web Browser XSS Protection is not enabled, or is disabled by the configuration of the 'X-XSS-Protection' HTTP response header on the web server
URL
https://och.berkeley.edu/auth/login
Other information
The X-XSS-Protection HTTP response header allows the web server to enable or disable the web browser's XSS protection mechanism. The following values would attempt to enable it: X-XSS-Protection: 1; mode=block X-XSS-Protection: 1; report=http://www.example.com/xss The following values would disable it: X-XSS-Protection: 0 The X-XSS-Protection HTTP response header is currently supported on Internet Explorer, Chrome and Safari (WebKit). Note that this alert is only raised if the response body could potentially contain an XSS payload (with a text-based content type, with a non-zero length).

Solution

Ensure that the web browser's XSS filter is enabled, by setting the X-XSS-Protection HTTP response header to '1'.

Reference

https://www.owasp.org/index.php/XSS_(Cross_Site_Scripting)_Prevention_Cheat_Sheet

https://blog.veracode.com/2014/03/guidelines-for-setting-security-headers/

CWE Id

933

WASC Id

14

Low (Medium)Password Autocomplete in browser

Description

AUTOCOMPLETE attribute is not disabled in HTML FORM/INPUT element containing password type input. Passwords may be stored in browsers and retrieved.
URL
https://och.berkeley.edu/auth/login
Parameter
input
Evidence
<input type="password" name="password" id="password" placeholder="Enter your password" autofocus>

Solution

Turn off AUTOCOMPLETE attribute in form or individual input elements containing password by using AUTOCOMPLETE='OFF'

Reference

http://msdn.microsoft.com/library/default.asp?url=/workshop/author/forms/autocomplete_ovr.asp

CWE Id

525

Low (Medium)X-Content-Type-Options Header Missing

Description

The Anti-MIME-Sniffing header X-Content-Type-Options was not set to 'nosniff'. This allows older versions of Internet Explorer and Chrome to perform MIME-sniffing on the response body, potentially causing the response body to be interpreted and displayed as a content type other than the declared content type. Current (early 2014) and legacy versions of Firefox will use the declared content type (if one is set), rather than performing MIME-sniffing.
URL
https://och.berkeley.edu/auth/login
Other information
This issue still applies to error type pages (401, 403, 500, etc) as those pages are often still affected by injection issues, in which case there is still concern for browsers sniffing pages away from their actual content type.

Solution

Ensure that the application/web server sets the Content-Type header appropriately, and that it sets the X-Content-Type-Options header to 'nosniff' for all web pages.

If possible, ensure that the end user uses a standards-compliant and modern web browser that does not perform MIME-sniffing at all, or that can be directed by the web application/web server to not perform MIME-sniffing.

Reference

http://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/ie/gg622941%28v=vs.85%29.aspx

https://www.owasp.org/index.php/List_of_useful_HTTP_headers

WASC Id

15

Parameter

Reference

www.owasp.org/index.php/HttpOnly

WASC Id

13

Low (Medium)Incomplete or No Cache-control and Pragma HTTP Header Set

Description

The cache-control and pragma HTTP header have not been set properly or are missing allowing the browser and proxies to cache content.
URL
https://och.berkeley.edu/help/category/property-manager
Evidence
no-store, no-cache, must-revalidate, post-check=0, pre-check=0

Solution

Whenever possible ensure the cache-control HTTP header is set with no-cache, no-store, must-revalidate, private; and that the pragma HTTP header is set with no-cache.

Reference

https://www.owasp.org/index.php/Session_Management_Cheat_Sheet#Web_Content_Caching

Low (Medium)Web Browser XSS Protection Not Enabled

Description

Web Browser XSS Protection is not enabled, or is disabled by the configuration of the 'X-XSS-Protection' HTTP response header on the web server
URL
https://och.berkeley.edu/help/category/property-manager
Other information
The X-XSS-Protection HTTP response header allows the web server to enable or disable the web browser's XSS protection mechanism. The following values would attempt to enable it: X-XSS-Protection: 1; mode=block X-XSS-Protection: 1; report=http://www.example.com/xss The following values would disable it: X-XSS-Protection: 0 The X-XSS-Protection HTTP response header is currently supported on Internet Explorer, Chrome and Safari (WebKit). Note that this alert is only raised if the response body could potentially contain an XSS payload (with a text-based content type, with a non-zero length).

Solution

Ensure that the web browser's XSS filter is enabled, by setting the X-XSS-Protection HTTP response header to '1'.

Reference

https://www.owasp.org/index.php/XSS_(Cross_Site_Scripting)_Prevention_Cheat_Sheet

https://blog.veracode.com/2014/03/guidelines-for-setting-security-headers/
