14

Low (Medium)X-Content-Type-Options Header Missing

Description

The Anti-MIME-Sniffing header X-Content-Type-Options was not set to 'nosniff'. This allows older versions of Internet Explorer and Chrome to perform MIME-sniffing on the response body, potentially causing the response body to be interpreted and displayed as a content type other than the declared content type. Current (early 2014) and legacy versions of Firefox will use the declared content type (if one is set), rather than performing MIME-sniffing.
URL
https://och.berkeley.edu/help/category/property-manager
Other information
This issue still applies to error type pages (401, 403, 500, etc) as those pages are often still affected by injection issues, in which case there is still concern for browsers sniffing pages away from their actual content type.

Solution

Ensure that the application/web server sets the Content-Type header appropriately, and that it sets the X-Content-Type-Options header to 'nosniff' for all web pages.

If possible, ensure that the end user uses a standards-compliant and modern web browser that does not perform MIME-sniffing at all, or that can be directed by the web application/web server to not perform MIME-sniffing.

http://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/ie/gg622941%28v=vs.85%29.aspx

https://www.owasp.org/index.php/List_of_useful_HTTP_headers

visid_incap_496857=hyISsm19TkeNd9xf8FvI9f7w1VYAAAAAQUIPAAAAAAD4dctqvvpmkQA4efNEkgoZ; expires=Wed, 01 Mar 2017 12:24:01 GMT; path=/; Domain=.berkeley.edu
Evidence
visid_incap_496857=hyISsm19TkeNd9xf8FvI9f7w1VYAAAAAQUIPAAAAAAD4dctqvvpmkQA4efNEkgoZ; expires=Wed, 01 Mar 2017 12:24:01 GMT; path=/; Domain=.berkeley.edu

Solution

Whenever a cookie contains sensitive information or is a session token, then it should always be passed using an encrypted tunnel. Ensure that the secure flag is set for cookies containing such sensitive information.

Reference

http://www.owasp.org/index.php/Testing_for_cookies_attributes_(OWASP-SM-002)

WASC Id

13

Low (Medium)Cookie set without secure flag

Description

A cookie has been set without the secure flag, which means that the cookie can be accessed via unencrypted connections.
URL
https://och.berkeley.edu/help/category/student-questions
Parameter
incap_ses_124_496857=N220Xh4tfQSV7b5nPoq4Af7w1VYAAAAAuCtAeIWXICMHqQR/iPXMvA==; path=/; Domain=.berkeley.edu
Evidence
incap_ses_124_496857=N220Xh4tfQSV7b5nPoq4Af7w1VYAAAAAuCtAeIWXICMHqQR/iPXMvA==; path=/; Domain=.berkeley.edu

Solution

Whenever a cookie contains sensitive information or is a session token, then it should always be passed using an encrypted tunnel. Ensure that the secure flag is set for cookies containing such sensitive information.

Reference

http://www.owasp.org/index.php/Testing_for_cookies_attributes_(OWASP-SM-002)

WASC Id

13

Low (Medium)Cross-Domain JavaScript Source File Inclusion

Description

The page at the following URL includes one or more script files from a third-party domain
URL
https://och.berkeley.edu/help/category/student-questions
Parameter
//ajax.googleapis.com/ajax/libs/jquery/1.11.1/jquery.min.js
Evidence
//ajax.googleapis.com/ajax/libs/jquery/1.11.1/jquery.min.js

Solution

Ensure JavaScript source files are loaded from only trusted sources, and the sources can't be controlled by end users of the application

Reference

Low (Medium)Cross-Domain JavaScript Source File Inclusion

Description

The page at the following URL includes one or more script files from a third-party domain
URL
https://och.berkeley.edu/help/category/student-questions
Parameter
//translate.google.com/translate_a/element.js?cb=googleTranslateElementInit
Evidence
//translate.google.com/translate_a/element.js?cb=googleTranslateElementInit

Solution

Ensure JavaScript source files are loaded from only trusted sources, and the sources can't be controlled by end users of the application

Reference

Low (Medium)Web Browser XSS Protection Not Enabled

Description

Web Browser XSS Protection is not enabled, or is disabled by the configuration of the 'X-XSS-Protection' HTTP response header on the web server
URL
https://och.berkeley.edu/help/category/student-questions
Other information
The X-XSS-Protection HTTP response header allows the web server to enable or disable the web browser's XSS protection mechanism. The following values would attempt to enable it: X-XSS-Protection: 1; mode=block X-XSS-Protection: 1; report=http://www.example.com/xss The following values would disable it: X-XSS-Protection: 0 The X-XSS-Protection HTTP response header is currently supported on Internet Explorer, Chrome and Safari (WebKit). Note that this alert is only raised if the response body could potentially contain an XSS payload (with a text-based content type, with a non-zero length).

Solution

Ensure that the web browser's XSS filter is enabled, by setting the X-XSS-Protection HTTP response header to '1'.

Reference

https://www.owasp.org/index.php/XSS_(Cross_Site_Scripting)_Prevention_Cheat_Sheet

https://blog.veracode.com/2014/03/guidelines-for-setting-security-headers/

CWE Id

933

WASC Id

14

Low (Medium)X-Content-Type-Options Header Missing

Description

The Anti-MIME-Sniffing header X-Content-Type-Options was not set to 'nosniff'. This allows older versions of Internet Explorer and Chrome to perform MIME-sniffing on the response body, potentially causing the response body to be interpreted and displayed as a content type other than the declared content type. Current (early 2014) and legacy versions of Firefox will use the declared content type (if one is set), rather than performing MIME-sniffing.
URL
https://och.berkeley.edu/help/category/student-questions
Other information
This issue still applies to error type pages (401, 403, 500, etc) as those pages are often still affected by injection issues, in which case there is still concern for browsers sniffing pages away from their actual content type.

Solution

Ensure that the application/web server sets the Content-Type header appropriately, and that it sets the X-Content-Type-Options header to 'nosniff' for all web pages.

If possible, ensure that the end user uses a standards-compliant and modern web browser that does not perform MIME-sniffing at all, or that can be directed by the web application/web server to not perform MIME-sniffing.

Reference

http://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/ie/gg622941%28v=vs.85%29.aspx

https://www.owasp.org/index.php/List_of_useful_HTTP_headers

WASC Id

15

Low (Medium)Incomplete or No Cache-control and Pragma HTTP Header Set

Description

The cache-control and pragma HTTP header have not been set properly or are missing allowing the browser and proxies to cache content.
URL
https://och.berkeley.edu/help/category/students
Evidence
no-store, no-cache, must-revalidate, post-check=0, pre-check=0

Solution

Whenever possible ensure the cache-control HTTP header is set with no-cache, no-store, must-revalidate, private; and that the pragma HTTP header is set with no-cache.

Reference

https://www.owasp.org/index.php/Session_Management_Cheat_Sheet#Web_Content_Caching

CWE Id

525

Low (Medium)Cookie set without HttpOnly flag

Description

A cookie has been set without the HttpOnly flag, which means that the cookie can be accessed by JavaScript. If a malicious script can be run on this page then the cookie will be accessible and can be transmitted to another site. If this is a session cookie then session hijacking may be possible.
URL
https://och.berkeley.edu/help/category/students
Parameter
PHPSESSID=0se4rs3ctu37bjetpgah8vf5o1; path=/
Evidence
PHPSESSID=0se4rs3ctu37bjetpgah8vf5o1; path=/

Solution

Ensure that the HttpOnly flag is set for all cookies.

Reference

www.owasp.org/index.php/HttpOnly

Low (Medium)Web Browser XSS Protection Not Enabled

Description

Web Browser XSS Protection is not enabled, or is disabled by the configuration of the 'X-XSS-Protection' HTTP response header on the web server
URL
https://och.berkeley.edu/help/category/students
Other information
The X-XSS-Protection HTTP response header allows the web server to enable or disable the web browser's XSS protection mechanism. The following values would attempt to enable it: X-XSS-Protection: 1; mode=block X-XSS-Protection: 1; report=http://www.example.com/xss The following values would disable it: X-XSS-Protection: 0 The X-XSS-Protection HTTP response header is currently supported on Internet Explorer, Chrome and Safari (WebKit). Note that this alert is only raised if the response body could potentially contain an XSS payload (with a text-based content type, with a non-zero length).

Solution

Ensure that the web browser's XSS filter is enabled, by setting the X-XSS-Protection HTTP response header to '1'.

Reference

https://www.owasp.org/index.php/XSS_(Cross_Site_Scripting)_Prevention_Cheat_Sheet

https://blog.veracode.com/2014/03/guidelines-for-setting-security-headers/

Description

This allows older versions of Internet Explorer and Chrome to perform MIME-sniffing on the response body, potentially causing the response body to be interpreted and displayed as a content type other than the declared content type. URL
https://och.berkeley.edu/help/category/students
Other information
This issue still applies to error type pages (401, 403, 500, etc) as those pages are often still affected by injection issues, in which case there is still concern for browsers sniffing pages away from their actual content type.

Solution

If possible, ensure that the end user uses a standards-compliant and modern web browser that does not perform MIME-sniffing at all, or that can be directed by the web application/web server to not perform MIME-sniffing.

http://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/ie/gg622941%28v=vs.85%29.aspx

PHPSESSID=2tno8a61325h1t4nl177m2jir4; path=/

Solution

Whenever a cookie contains sensitive information or is a session token, then it should always be passed using an encrypted tunnel. Ensure that the secure flag is set for cookies containing such sensitive information.

Reference

http://www.owasp.org/index.php/Testing_for_cookies_attributes_(OWASP-SM-002)

WASC Id

13

Low (Medium)Cookie set without secure flag

Description

A cookie has been set without the secure flag, which means that the cookie can be accessed via unencrypted connections.
URL
https://och.berkeley.edu/help/category/general-questions
Parameter
visid_incap_496857=hqTw8/OwR+KngCoj/5MRpwHx1VYAAAAAQUIPAAAAAACORWlGStfVBF+0gdDzAZ5O; expires=Wed, 01 Mar 2017 12:24:01 GMT; path=/; Domain=.berkeley.edu
Evidence
visid_incap_496857=hqTw8/OwR+KngCoj/5MRpwHx1VYAAAAAQUIPAAAAAACORWlGStfVBF+0gdDzAZ5O; expires=Wed, 01 Mar 2017 12:24:01 GMT; path=/; Domain=.berkeley.edu

Solution

Whenever a cookie contains sensitive information or is a session token, then it should always be passed using an encrypted tunnel. Ensure that the secure flag is set for cookies containing such sensitive information.

Reference

http://www.owasp.org/index.php/Testing_for_cookies_attributes_(OWASP-SM-002)

WASC Id

13

Description

A cookie has been set without the secure flag, which means that the cookie can be accessed via unencrypted connections.
URL
https://och.berkeley.edu/help/category/general-questions
Parameter
incap_ses_124_496857=Jr1Oc9mjVDQ5975nPoq4AQHx1VYAAAAAUJHlgLqDllySP9Sv+baBVA==; path=/; Domain=.berkeley.edu
Evidence
incap_ses_124_496857=Jr1Oc9mjVDQ5975nPoq4AQHx1VYAAAAAUJHlgLqDllySP9Sv+baBVA==; path=/; Domain=.berkeley.edu

http://www.owasp.org/index.php/Testing_for_cookies_attributes_(OWASP-SM-002)

WASC Id

13

Low (Medium)Cross-Domain JavaScript Source File Inclusion

Description

The page at the following URL includes one or more script files from a third-party domain
URL
https://och.berkeley.edu/help/category/general-questions
Parameter
//ajax.googleapis.com/ajax/libs/jquery/1.11.1/jquery.min.js
Evidence
//ajax.googleapis.com/ajax/libs/jquery/1.11.1/jquery.min.js

Solution

Ensure JavaScript source files are loaded from only trusted sources, and the sources can't be controlled by end users of the application

Reference

Low (Medium)Cross-Domain JavaScript Source File Inclusion

Description

The page at the following URL includes one or more script files from a third-party domain
URL
https://och.berkeley.edu/help/category/general-questions
Parameter
//translate.google.com/translate_a/element.js?cb=googleTranslateElementInit
Evidence
//translate.google.com/translate_a/element.js?cb=googleTranslateElementInit

Solution

Ensure JavaScript source files are loaded from only trusted sources, and the sources can't be controlled by end users of the application

Reference

Low (Medium)Web Browser XSS Protection Not Enabled

Description

Web Browser XSS Protection is not enabled, or is disabled by the configuration of the 'X-XSS-Protection' HTTP response header on the web server
URL
https://och.berkeley.edu/help/category/general-questions
Other information
The X-XSS-Protection HTTP response header allows the web server to enable or disable the web browser's XSS protection mechanism. The following values would attempt to enable it: X-XSS-Protection: 1; mode=block X-XSS-Protection: 1; report=http://www.example.com/xss The following values would disable it: X-XSS-Protection: 0 The X-XSS-Protection HTTP response header is currently supported on Internet Explorer, Chrome and Safari (WebKit). Note that this alert is only raised if the response body could potentially contain an XSS payload (with a text-based content type, with a non-zero length).

Solution

Ensure that the web browser's XSS filter is enabled, by setting the X-XSS-Protection HTTP response header to '1'.

Reference

https://www.owasp.org/index.php/XSS_(Cross_Site_Scripting)_Prevention_Cheat_Sheet

https://blog.veracode.com/2014/03/guidelines-for-setting-security-headers/

CWE Id

933

WASC Id

14

Low (Medium)X-Content-Type-Options Header Missing

Description

The Anti-MIME-Sniffing header X-Content-Type-Options was not set to 'nosniff'. This allows older versions of Internet Explorer and Chrome to perform MIME-sniffing on the response body, potentially causing the response body to be interpreted and displayed as a content type other than the declared content type. Current (early 2014) and legacy versions of Firefox will use the declared content type (if one is set), rather than performing MIME-sniffing.
URL
https://och.berkeley.edu/help/category/general-questions
Other information
This issue still applies to error type pages (401, 403, 500, etc) as those pages are often still affected by injection issues, in which case there is still concern for browsers sniffing pages away from their actual content type.

Solution

Ensure that the application/web server sets the Content-Type header appropriately, and that it sets the X-Content-Type-Options header to 'nosniff' for all web pages.

If possible, ensure that the end user uses a standards-compliant and modern web browser that does not perform MIME-sniffing at all, or that can be directed by the web application/web server to not perform MIME-sniffing.

Reference

http://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/ie/gg622941%28v=vs.85%29.aspx

https://www.owasp.org/index.php/List_of_useful_HTTP_headers

WASC Id

15

Low (Medium)Cookie set without HttpOnly flag

Description

A cookie has been set without the HttpOnly flag, which means that the cookie can be accessed by JavaScript. If a malicious script can be run on this page then the cookie will be accessible and can be transmitted to another site. If this is a session cookie then session hijacking may be possible.
URL
https://och.berkeley.edu/help/contact
Parameter
PHPSESSID=166g3f400lk97qcu52oibb4s56; path=/
Evidence
PHPSESSID=166g3f400lk97qcu52oibb4s56; path=/

Solution

Ensure that the HttpOnly flag is set for all cookies.

Reference

www.owasp.org/index.php/HttpOnly

WASC Id

13

Low (Medium)Incomplete or No Cache-control and Pragma HTTP Header Set

Description

The cache-control and pragma HTTP header have not been set properly or are missing allowing the browser and proxies to cache content.
URL
https://och.berkeley.edu/help/contact?msg=Password+Reset+Help
Evidence
no-store, no-cache, must-revalidate, post-check=0, pre-check=0

Solution

Whenever possible ensure the cache-control HTTP header is set with no-cache, no-store, must-revalidate, private; and that the pragma HTTP header is set with no-cache.

Reference

https://www.owasp.org/index.php/Session_Management_Cheat_Sheet#Web_Content_Caching

Low (Medium)Web Browser XSS Protection Not Enabled

Description

Web Browser XSS Protection is not enabled, or is disabled by the configuration of the 'X-XSS-Protection' HTTP response header on the web server
URL
https://och.berkeley.edu/help/contact?msg=Password+Reset+Help
Other information
The X-XSS-Protection HTTP response header allows the web server to enable or disable the web browser's XSS protection mechanism. The following values would attempt to enable it: X-XSS-Protection: 1; mode=block X-XSS-Protection: 1; report=http://www.example.com/xss The following values would disable it: X-XSS-Protection: 0 The X-XSS-Protection HTTP response header is currently supported on Internet Explorer, Chrome and Safari (WebKit). Note that this alert is only raised if the response body could potentially contain an XSS payload (with a text-based content type, with a non-zero length).

Solution

Ensure that the web browser's XSS filter is enabled, by setting the X-XSS-Protection HTTP response header to '1'.

Reference

https://www.owasp.org/index.php/XSS_(Cross_Site_Scripting)_Prevention_Cheat_Sheet

https://blog.veracode.com/2014/03/guidelines-for-setting-security-headers/

CWE Id

WASC Id

14

Low (Medium)X-Content-Type-Options Header Missing

Description

The Anti-MIME-Sniffing header X-Content-Type-Options was not set to 'nosniff'. This allows older versions of Internet Explorer and Chrome to perform MIME-sniffing on the response body, potentially causing the response body to be interpreted and displayed as a content type other than the declared content type. Current (early 2014) and legacy versions of Firefox will use the declared content type (if one is set), rather than performing MIME-sniffing.
URL
https://och.berkeley.edu/help/contact?msg=Password+Reset+Help
Other information
This issue still applies to error type pages (401, 403, 500, etc) as those pages are often still affected by injection issues, in which case there is still concern for browsers sniffing pages away from their actual content type.

Solution

Ensure that the application/web server sets the Content-Type header appropriately, and that it sets the X-Content-Type-Options header to 'nosniff' for all web pages.

If possible, ensure that the end user uses a standards-compliant and modern web browser that does not perform MIME-sniffing at all, or that can be directed by the web application/web server to not perform MIME-sniffing.

Reference

http://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/ie/gg622941%28v=vs.85%29.aspx

https://www.owasp.org/index.php/List_of_useful_HTTP_headers

Low (Medium)Web Browser XSS Protection Not Enabled

Description

Web Browser XSS Protection is not enabled, or is disabled by the configuration of the 'X-XSS-Protection' HTTP response header on the web server
URL
https://och.berkeley.edu/registration/property-manager/
Other information
The X-XSS-Protection HTTP response header allows the web server to enable or disable the web browser's XSS protection mechanism. The following values would attempt to enable it: X-XSS-Protection: 1; mode=block X-XSS-Protection: 1; report=http://www.example.com/xss The following values would disable it: X-XSS-Protection: 0 The X-XSS-Protection HTTP response header is currently supported on Internet Explorer, Chrome and Safari (WebKit). Note that this alert is only raised if the response body could potentially contain an XSS payload (with a text-based content type, with a non-zero length).

Solution

Ensure that the web browser's XSS filter is enabled, by setting the X-XSS-Protection HTTP response header to '1'.

Reference

https://www.owasp.org/index.php/XSS_(Cross_Site_Scripting)_Prevention_Cheat_Sheet

https://blog.veracode.com/2014/03/guidelines-for-setting-security-headers/

CWE Id

933

WASC Id

14

Low (Medium)X-Content-Type-Options Header Missing

Description

The Anti-MIME-Sniffing header X-Content-Type-Options was not set to 'nosniff'. This allows older versions of Internet Explorer and Chrome to perform MIME-sniffing on the response body, potentially causing the response body to be interpreted and displayed as a content type other than the declared content type. Current (early 2014) and legacy versions of Firefox will use the declared content type (if one is set), rather than performing MIME-sniffing.
URL
https://och.berkeley.edu/registration/property-manager/
Other information
This issue still applies to error type pages (401, 403, 500, etc) as those pages are often still affected by injection issues, in which case there is still concern for browsers sniffing pages away from their actual content type.

Solution

Ensure that the application/web server sets the Content-Type header appropriately, and that it sets the X-Content-Type-Options header to 'nosniff' for all web pages.

If possible, ensure that the end user uses a standards-compliant and modern web browser that does not perform MIME-sniffing at all, or that can be directed by the web application/web server to not perform MIME-sniffing.

Reference

http://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/ie/gg622941%28v=vs.85%29.aspx

https://www.owasp.org/index.php/List_of_useful_HTTP_headers

WASC Id

15

Low (Medium)Incomplete or No Cache-control and Pragma HTTP Header Set

Description

The cache-control and pragma HTTP header have not been set properly or are missing allowing the browser and proxies to cache content.
URL
https://och.berkeley.edu/auth/forgot-auth?from=help%2Fcategory%2Freset-your-password
Evidence
no-store, no-cache, must-revalidate, post-check=0, pre-check=0

Solution

Whenever possible ensure the cache-control HTTP header is set with no-cache, no-store, must-revalidate, private; and that the pragma HTTP header is set with no-cache.

Reference

https://www.owasp.org/index.php/Session_Management_Cheat_Sheet#Web_Content_Caching

CWE Id

525

Low (Medium)Cookie set without HttpOnly flag

Description

A cookie has been set without the HttpOnly flag, which means that the cookie can be accessed by JavaScript. If a malicious script can be run on this page then the cookie will be accessible and can be transmitted to another site. If this is a session cookie then session hijacking may be possible.
URL
https://och.berkeley.edu/auth/forgot-auth?from=help%2Fcategory%2Freset-your-password
Parameter
PHPSESSID=mbjusgrfnknj2h7t3pqcro4dp2; path=/
Evidence
PHPSESSID=mbjusgrfnknj2h7t3pqcro4dp2; path=/

Solution

Ensure that the HttpOnly flag is set for all cookies.

Reference

www.owasp.org/index.php/HttpOnly

WASC Id

13

Low (Medium)Cookie set without HttpOnly flag

Description

A cookie has been set without the HttpOnly flag, which means that the cookie can be accessed by JavaScript. If a malicious script can be run on this page then the cookie will be accessible and can be transmitted to another site. If this is a session cookie then session hijacking may be possible.
URL
https://och.berkeley.edu/auth/forgot-auth?from=help%2Fcategory%2Freset-your-password
Parameter
visid_incap_496857=CeDqeEtvQ0uxH0CzuL6KCQLx1VYAAAAAQUIPAAAAAABJVOJVLjOXNrEjGWn6YQ8j; expires=Wed, 01 Mar 2017 12:24:01 GMT; path=/; Domain=.berkeley.edu
Evidence
visid_incap_496857=CeDqeEtvQ0uxH0CzuL6KCQLx1VYAAAAAQUIPAAAAAABJVOJVLjOXNrEjGWn6YQ8j; expires=Wed, 01 Mar 2017 12:24:01 GMT; path=/; Domain=.berkeley.edu

Ensure that the HttpOnly flag is set for all cookies.

WASC Id

13

Low (Medium)Cookie set without HttpOnly flag

Description

A cookie has been set without the HttpOnly flag, which means that the cookie can be accessed by JavaScript. If a malicious script can be run on this page then the cookie will be accessible and can be transmitted to another site. If this is a session cookie then session hijacking may be possible.
URL
https://och.berkeley.edu/auth/forgot-auth?from=help%2Fcategory%2Freset-your-password
Parameter
incap_ses_124_496857=AJsKez/W5hAj/75nPoq4AQLx1VYAAAAA456BR/xKbiVSls3s3WtrRg==; path=/; Domain=.berkeley.edu
Evidence
incap_ses_124_496857=AJsKez/W5hAj/75nPoq4AQLx1VYAAAAA456BR/xKbiVSls3s3WtrRg==; path=/; Domain=.berkeley.edu

Solution

Ensure that the HttpOnly flag is set for all cookies.

Reference

www.owasp.org/index.php/HttpOnly

WASC Id

13

Low (Medium)Cookie set without secure flag

Description

A cookie has been set without the secure flag, which means that the cookie can be accessed via unencrypted connections.
URL
https://och.berkeley.edu/auth/forgot-auth?from=help%2Fcategory%2Freset-your-password
Parameter
PHPSESSID=mbjusgrfnknj2h7t3pqcro4dp2; path=/
Evidence
PHPSESSID=mbjusgrfnknj2h7t3pqcro4dp2; path=/

Solution

Whenever a cookie contains sensitive information or is a session token, then it should always be passed using an encrypted tunnel. Ensure that the secure flag is set for cookies containing such sensitive information.

Reference

http://www.owasp.org/index.php/Testing_for_cookies_attributes_(OWASP-SM-002)

WASC Id

13

Low (Medium)Cookie set without secure flag

Description

A cookie has been set without the secure flag, which means that the cookie can be accessed via unencrypted connections.
URL
https://och.berkeley.edu/auth/forgot-auth?from=help%2Fcategory%2Freset-your-password
Parameter
visid_incap_496857=CeDqeEtvQ0uxH0CzuL6KCQLx1VYAAAAAQUIPAAAAAABJVOJVLjOXNrEjGWn6YQ8j; expires=Wed, 01 Mar 2017 12:24:01 GMT; path=/; Domain=.berkeley.edu
Evidence

WASC Id

13

Low (Medium)Cross-Domain JavaScript Source File Inclusion

Description

The page at the following URL includes one or more script files from a third-party domain
URL
https://och.berkeley.edu/auth/forgot-auth?from=help%2Fcategory%2Freset-your-password
Parameter
//ajax.googleapis.com/ajax/libs/jquery/1.11.1/jquery.min.js
Evidence
//ajax.googleapis.com/ajax/libs/jquery/1.11.1/jquery.min.js

Solution

Ensure JavaScript source files are loaded from only trusted sources, and the sources can't be controlled by end users of the application

Reference

Low (Medium)Cross-Domain JavaScript Source File Inclusion

Description

The page at the following URL includes one or more script files from a third-party domain
URL
https://och.berkeley.edu/auth/forgot-auth?from=help%2Fcategory%2Freset-your-password
Parameter
//translate.google.com/translate_a/element.js?cb=googleTranslateElementInit
Evidence
//translate.google.com/translate_a/element.js?cb=googleTranslateElementInit

Solution

Ensure JavaScript source files are loaded from only trusted sources, and the sources can't be controlled by end users of the application

Reference

Low (Medium)Web Browser XSS Protection Not Enabled

Description

Web Browser XSS Protection is not enabled, or is disabled by the configuration of the 'X-XSS-Protection' HTTP response header on the web server
URL
https://och.berkeley.edu/auth/forgot-auth?from=help%2Fcategory%2Freset-your-password
Other information
The X-XSS-Protection HTTP response header allows the web server to enable or disable the web browser's XSS protection mechanism. The following values would attempt to enable it: X-XSS-Protection: 1; mode=block X-XSS-Protection: 1; report=http://www.example.com/xss The following values would disable it: X-XSS-Protection: 0 The X-XSS-Protection HTTP response header is currently supported on Internet Explorer, Chrome and Safari (WebKit). Note that this alert is only raised if the response body could potentially contain an XSS payload (with a text-based content type, with a non-zero length).

Solution

Ensure that the web browser's XSS filter is enabled, by setting the X-XSS-Protection HTTP response header to '1'.

Reference

https://www.owasp.org/index.php/XSS_(Cross_Site_Scripting)_Prevention_Cheat_Sheet

https://blog.veracode.com/2014/03/guidelines-for-setting-security-headers/

https://och.berkeley.edu/auth/forgot-auth?from=help%2Fcategory%2Freset-your-password
Other information
This issue still applies to error type pages (401, 403, 500, etc) as those pages are often still affected by injection issues, in which case there is still concern for browsers sniffing pages away from their actual content type.

Solution

Low (Medium)Cookie set without secure flag

Description

A cookie has been set without the secure flag, which means that the cookie can be accessed via unencrypted connections.
URL
https://och.berkeley.edu/property/for-sale-application/
Parameter
incap_ses_124_496857=F7HOFR8HyznfAb9nPoq4AQPx1VYAAAAAJ6IadE5ZLyAJPbmwbgYI1A==; path=/; Domain=.berkeley.edu
Evidence
incap_ses_124_496857=F7HOFR8HyznfAb9nPoq4AQPx1VYAAAAAJ6IadE5ZLyAJPbmwbgYI1A==; path=/; Domain=.berkeley.edu

Solution

Whenever a cookie contains sensitive information or is a session token, then it should always be passed using an encrypted tunnel. Ensure that the secure flag is set for cookies containing such sensitive information.

Reference

http://www.owasp.org/index.php/Testing_for_cookies_attributes_(OWASP-SM-002)

WASC Id

13

Low (Medium)Cross-Domain JavaScript Source File Inclusion

Description

The page at the following URL includes one or more script files from a third-party domain
URL
https://och.berkeley.edu/property/for-sale-application/
Parameter
//ajax.googleapis.com/ajax/libs/jquery/1.11.1/jquery.min.js
Evidence
//ajax.googleapis.com/ajax/libs/jquery/1.11.1/jquery.min.js

Solution

Ensure JavaScript source files are loaded from only trusted sources, and the sources can't be controlled by end users of the application

Reference

Low (Medium)Cookie set without HttpOnly flag

Description

A cookie has been set without the HttpOnly flag, which means that the cookie can be accessed by JavaScript. If a malicious script can be run on this page then the cookie will be accessible and can be transmitted to another site. If this is a session cookie then session hijacking may be possible.
URL
https://och.berkeley.edu/property/for-sale-application/
Parameter
PHPSESSID=r16edesls87hvlbv8iotb9be63; path=/
Evidence
PHPSESSID=r16edesls87hvlbv8iotb9be63; path=/

Solution

Ensure that the HttpOnly flag is set for all cookies.

Reference

www.owasp.org/index.php/HttpOnly

WASC Id

13

Low (Medium)Cross-Domain JavaScript Source File Inclusion

Description

The page at the following URL includes one or more script files from a third-party domain
URL
https://och.berkeley.edu/property/for-sale-application/
Parameter
//translate.google.com/translate_a/element.js?cb=googleTranslateElementInit
Evidence
//translate.google.com/translate_a/element.js?cb=googleTranslateElementInit

Solution

Ensure JavaScript source files are loaded from only trusted sources, and the sources can't be controlled by end users of the application

Reference

Low (Medium)Web Browser XSS Protection Not Enabled

Description

Web Browser XSS Protection is not enabled, or is disabled by the configuration of the 'X-XSS-Protection' HTTP response header on the web server
URL
https://och.berkeley.edu/property/for-sale-application/
Other information
The X-XSS-Protection HTTP response header allows the web server to enable or disable the web browser's XSS protection mechanism. The following values would attempt to enable it: X-XSS-Protection: 1; mode=block X-XSS-Protection: 1; report=http://www.example.com/xss The following values would disable it: X-XSS-Protection: 0 The X-XSS-Protection HTTP response header is currently supported on Internet Explorer, Chrome and Safari (WebKit). Note that this alert is only raised if the response body could potentially contain an XSS payload (with a text-based content type, with a non-zero length).

Solution

Ensure that the web browser's XSS filter is enabled, by setting the X-XSS-Protection HTTP response header to '1'.

Reference

https://www.owasp.org/index.php/XSS_(Cross_Site_Scripting)_Prevention_Cheat_Sheet

https://blog.veracode.com/2014/03/guidelines-for-setting-security-headers/

CWE Id

933

WASC Id

14

Low (Medium)Cookie set without HttpOnly flag

Description

A cookie has been set without the HttpOnly flag, which means that the cookie can be accessed by JavaScript. If a malicious script can be run on this page then the cookie will be accessible and can be transmitted to another site. If this is a session cookie then session hijacking may be possible.
URL
https://och.berkeley.edu/property/for-sale-application/
Parameter
visid_incap_496857=nX+Ctf8CQ7+x7LTK2xpfBgPx1VYAAAAAQUIPAAAAAADrFJNvTaWpYZYzdYJdDZqj; expires=Wed, 01 Mar 2017 12:24:07 GMT; path=/; Domain=.berkeley.edu
Evidence
visid_incap_496857=nX+Ctf8CQ7+x7LTK2xpfBgPx1VYAAAAAQUIPAAAAAADrFJNvTaWpYZYzdYJdDZqj; expires=Wed, 01 Mar 2017 12:24:07 GMT; path=/; Domain=.berkeley.edu

Solution

Ensure that the HttpOnly flag is set for all cookies.

Reference

www.owasp.org/index.php/HttpOnly

WASC Id

13

Low (Medium)X-Content-Type-Options Header Missing

Description

The Anti-MIME-Sniffing header X-Content-Type-Options was not set to 'nosniff'. This allows older versions of Internet Explorer and Chrome to perform MIME-sniffing on the response body, potentially causing the response body to be interpreted and displayed as a content type other than the declared content type. Current (early 2014) and legacy versions of Firefox will use the declared content type (if one is set), rather than performing MIME-sniffing.
URL
https://och.berkeley.edu/property/for-sale-application/
Other information
This issue still applies to error type pages (401, 403, 500, etc) as those pages are often still affected by injection issues, in which case there is still concern for browsers sniffing pages away from their actual content type.

Solution

Ensure that the application/web server sets the Content-Type header appropriately, and that it sets the X-Content-Type-Options header to 'nosniff' for all web pages.

If possible, ensure that the end user uses a standards-compliant and modern web browser that does not perform MIME-sniffing at all, or that can be directed by the web application/web server to not perform MIME-sniffing.

Reference

http://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/ie/gg622941%28v=vs.85%29.aspx

https://www.owasp.org/index.php/List_of_useful_HTTP_headers

WASC Id

15

Low (Medium)Cookie set without HttpOnly flag

Description

A cookie has been set without the HttpOnly flag, which means that the cookie can be accessed by JavaScript. If a malicious script can be run on this page then the cookie will be accessible and can be transmitted to another site. If this is a session cookie then session hijacking may be possible.
URL
https://och.berkeley.edu/property/for-sale-application/
Parameter
incap_ses_124_496857=F7HOFR8HyznfAb9nPoq4AQPx1VYAAAAAJ6IadE5ZLyAJPbmwbgYI1A==; path=/; Domain=.berkeley.edu
Evidence
incap_ses_124_496857=F7HOFR8HyznfAb9nPoq4AQPx1VYAAAAAJ6IadE5ZLyAJPbmwbgYI1A==; path=/; Domain=.berkeley.edu

Solution

Ensure that the HttpOnly flag is set for all cookies.

Reference

www.owasp.org/index.php/HttpOnly

URL
https://och.berkeley.edu/property/for-sale-application/

Evidence
visid_incap_496857=nX+Ctf8CQ7+x7LTK2xpfBgPx1VYAAAAAQUIPAAAAAADrFJNvTaWpYZYzdYJdDZqj; expires=Wed, 01 Mar 2017 12:24:07 GMT; path=/; Domain=.berkeley.edu

WASC Id

13

Low (Medium)Incomplete or No Cache-control and Pragma HTTP Header Set

Description

The cache-control and pragma HTTP header have not been set properly or are missing allowing the browser and proxies to cache content.
URL
https://och.berkeley.edu/help/contact?msg=Package%2FRate+Inquiry
Evidence
no-store, no-cache, must-revalidate, post-check=0, pre-check=0

Solution

Whenever possible ensure the cache-control HTTP header is set with no-cache, no-store, must-revalidate, private; and that the pragma HTTP header is set with no-cache.

Reference

https://www.owasp.org/index.php/Session_Management_Cheat_Sheet#Web_Content_Caching

CWE Id

525

WASC Id

13

Low (Medium)Web Browser XSS Protection Not Enabled

Description

Web Browser XSS Protection is not enabled, or is disabled by the configuration of the 'X-XSS-Protection' HTTP response header on the web server
URL
https://och.berkeley.edu/help/contact?msg=Package%2FRate+Inquiry
Other information
The X-XSS-Protection HTTP response header allows the web server to enable or disable the web browser's XSS protection mechanism. The following values would attempt to enable it: X-XSS-Protection: 1; mode=block X-XSS-Protection: 1; report=http://www.example.com/xss The following values would disable it: X-XSS-Protection: 0 The X-XSS-Protection HTTP response header is currently supported on Internet Explorer, Chrome and Safari (WebKit). Note that this alert is only raised if the response body could potentially contain an XSS payload (with a text-based content type, with a non-zero length).

Solution

Ensure that the web browser's XSS filter is enabled, by setting the X-XSS-Protection HTTP response header to '1'.

Reference

https://www.owasp.org/index.php/XSS_(Cross_Site_Scripting)_Prevention_Cheat_Sheet

https://blog.veracode.com/2014/03/guidelines-for-setting-security-headers/

CWE Id

933

WASC Id

14

Low (Medium)X-Content-Type-Options Header Missing

Description

The Anti-MIME-Sniffing header X-Content-Type-Options was not set to 'nosniff'. This allows older versions of Internet Explorer and Chrome to perform MIME-sniffing on the response body, potentially causing the response body to be interpreted and displayed as a content type other than the declared content type. Current (early 2014) and legacy versions of Firefox will use the declared content type (if one is set), rather than performing MIME-sniffing.
URL
https://och.berkeley.edu/help/contact?msg=Package%2FRate+Inquiry
Other information
This issue still applies to error type pages (401, 403, 500, etc) as those pages are often still affected by injection issues, in which case there is still concern for browsers sniffing pages away from their actual content type.

Solution

Ensure that the application/web server sets the Content-Type header appropriately, and that it sets the X-Content-Type-Options header to 'nosniff' for all web pages.

If possible, ensure that the end user uses a standards-compliant and modern web browser that does not perform MIME-sniffing at all, or that can be directed by the web application/web server to not perform MIME-sniffing.

Reference

http://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/ie/gg622941%28v=vs.85%29.aspx

https://www.owasp.org/index.php/List_of_useful_HTTP_headers

WASC Id

15

Low (Medium)Cookie set without HttpOnly flag

Description

A cookie has been set without the HttpOnly flag, which means that the cookie can be accessed by JavaScript. If a malicious script can be run on this page then the cookie will be accessible and can be transmitted to another site. If this is a session cookie then session hijacking may be possible.
URL
https://och.berkeley.edu/property/rental
Parameter
PHPSESSID=a1hh7es609uk3om03kj121r8n0; path=/
Evidence
PHPSESSID=a1hh7es609uk3om03kj121r8n0; path=/

Solution

Ensure that the HttpOnly flag is set for all cookies.

Reference

www.owasp.org/index.php/HttpOnly

https://och.berkeley.edu/property/rental

WASC Id

13

Low (Medium)Cookie set without secure flag

Description

A cookie has been set without the secure flag, which means that the cookie can be accessed via unencrypted connections.
URL
https://och.berkeley.edu/property/rental
Parameter
PHPSESSID=a1hh7es609uk3om03kj121r8n0; path=/
Evidence
PHPSESSID=a1hh7es609uk3om03kj121r8n0; path=/

Solution

Whenever a cookie contains sensitive information or is a session token, then it should always be passed using an encrypted tunnel. Ensure that the secure flag is set for cookies containing such sensitive information.

Reference

http://www.owasp.org/index.php/Testing_for_cookies_attributes_(OWASP-SM-002)

WASC Id

13

Low (Medium)Incomplete or No Cache-control and Pragma HTTP Header Set

Description

The cache-control and pragma HTTP header have not been set properly or are missing allowing the browser and proxies to cache content.
URL
https://och.berkeley.edu/custom/terms-of-service/type/student-guest
Evidence
no-store, no-cache, must-revalidate, post-check=0, pre-check=0

Solution

Whenever possible ensure the cache-control HTTP header is set with no-cache, no-store, must-revalidate, private; and that the pragma HTTP header is set with no-cache.

Reference

https://www.owasp.org/index.php/Session_Management_Cheat_Sheet#Web_Content_Caching

WASC Id

13

Low (Medium)Cross-Domain JavaScript Source File Inclusion

Description

The page at the following URL includes one or more script files from a third-party domain
URL
https://och.berkeley.edu/custom/terms-of-service/type/student-guest
Parameter
//ajax.googleapis.com/ajax/libs/jquery/1.11.1/jquery.min.js
Evidence
//ajax.googleapis.com/ajax/libs/jquery/1.11.1/jquery.min.js

Solution

Ensure JavaScript source files are loaded from only trusted sources, and the sources can't be controlled by end users of the application

Reference

Low (Medium)Cross-Domain JavaScript Source File Inclusion

Description

The page at the following URL includes one or more script files from a third-party domain
URL
https://och.berkeley.edu/custom/terms-of-service/type/student-guest
Parameter
//translate.google.com/translate_a/element.js?cb=googleTranslateElementInit
Evidence
//translate.google.com/translate_a/element.js?cb=googleTranslateElementInit

Solution

Ensure JavaScript source files are loaded from only trusted sources, and the sources can't be controlled by end users of the application

Reference

Low (Medium)Web Browser XSS Protection Not Enabled

Description

Web Browser XSS Protection is not enabled, or is disabled by the configuration of the 'X-XSS-Protection' HTTP response header on the web server
URL
https://och.berkeley.edu/custom/terms-of-service/type/student-guest
Other information
The X-XSS-Protection HTTP response header allows the web server to enable or disable the web browser's XSS protection mechanism. The following values would attempt to enable it: X-XSS-Protection: 1; mode=block X-XSS-Protection: 1; report=http://www.example.com/xss The following values would disable it: X-XSS-Protection: 0 The X-XSS-Protection HTTP response header is currently supported on Internet Explorer, Chrome and Safari (WebKit). Note that this alert is only raised if the response body could potentially contain an XSS payload (with a text-based content type, with a non-zero length).

Solution

Ensure that the web browser's XSS filter is enabled, by setting the X-XSS-Protection HTTP response header to '1'.

Reference

https://www.owasp.org/index.php/XSS_(Cross_Site_Scripting)_Prevention_Cheat_Sheet

https://blog.veracode.com/2014/03/guidelines-for-setting-security-headers/

CWE Id

933

WASC Id

14

Low (Medium)X-Content-Type-Options Header Missing

Description

The Anti-MIME-Sniffing header X-Content-Type-Options was not set to 'nosniff'. This allows older versions of Internet Explorer and Chrome to perform MIME-sniffing on the response body, potentially causing the response body to be interpreted and displayed as a content type other than the declared content type. Current (early 2014) and legacy versions of Firefox will use the declared content type (if one is set), rather than performing MIME-sniffing.
URL
https://och.berkeley.edu/custom/terms-of-service/type/student-guest
Other information
This issue still applies to error type pages (401, 403, 500, etc) as those pages are often still affected by injection issues, in which case there is still concern for browsers sniffing pages away from their actual content type.

Solution

Ensure that the application/web server sets the Content-Type header appropriately, and that it sets the X-Content-Type-Options header to 'nosniff' for all web pages.

If possible, ensure that the end user uses a standards-compliant and modern web browser that does not perform MIME-sniffing at all, or that can be directed by the web application/web server to not perform MIME-sniffing.

Reference

http://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/ie/gg622941%28v=vs.85%29.aspx

https://www.owasp.org/index.php/List_of_useful_HTTP_headers

incap_ses_124_496857=9uqVRhmWV0c5E79nPoq4AQfx1VYAAAAA8JDSDGWmQ9hodglyhe1x1g==; path=/; Domain=.berkeley.edu
Evidence
incap_ses_124_496857=9uqVRhmWV0c5E79nPoq4AQfx1VYAAAAA8JDSDGWmQ9hodglyhe1x1g==; path=/; Domain=.berkeley.edu

Solution

Ensure that the HttpOnly flag is set for all cookies.

Reference

www.owasp.org/index.php/HttpOnly

WASC Id

13

Low (Medium)Cookie set without secure flag

Description

A cookie has been set without the secure flag, which means that the cookie can be accessed via unencrypted connections.
URL
https://och.berkeley.edu/auth/login
Parameter
PHPSESSID=99vbevp1qlcph89esr76ruodk4; path=/
Evidence
PHPSESSID=99vbevp1qlcph89esr76ruodk4; path=/

Solution

Whenever a cookie contains sensitive information or is a session token, then it should always be passed using an encrypted tunnel. Ensure that the secure flag is set for cookies containing such sensitive information.

Reference

http://www.owasp.org/index.php/Testing_for_cookies_attributes_(OWASP-SM-002)

Description

URL
https://och.berkeley.edu/auth/login
Parameter
incap_ses_124_496857=9uqVRhmWV0c5E79nPoq4AQfx1VYAAAAA8JDSDGWmQ9hodglyhe1x1g==; path=/; Domain=.berkeley.edu

WASC Id

13

Low (Medium)Incomplete or No Cache-control and Pragma HTTP Header Set

Description

The cache-control and pragma HTTP header have not been set properly or are missing allowing the browser and proxies to cache content.
URL
https://och.berkeley.edu/auth/forgot-auth/username/ZAP
Evidence
no-store, no-cache, must-revalidate, post-check=0, pre-check=0

Solution

Whenever possible ensure the cache-control HTTP header is set with no-cache, no-store, must-revalidate, private; and that the pragma HTTP header is set with no-cache.

Reference

https://www.owasp.org/index.php/Session_Management_Cheat_Sheet#Web_Content_Caching

CWE Id

525

Low (Medium)Cookie set without HttpOnly flag

Description

A cookie has been set without the HttpOnly flag, which means that the cookie can be accessed by JavaScript. If a malicious script can be run on this page then the cookie will be accessible and can be transmitted to another site. If this is a session cookie then session hijacking may be possible.
URL
https://och.berkeley.edu/auth/forgot-auth/username/ZAP
Parameter
PHPSESSID=ltu27gairek2a18fg4v4ak1810; path=/
Evidence
PHPSESSID=ltu27gairek2a18fg4v4ak1810; path=/

Solution

WASC Id

13

Low (Medium)Cross-Domain JavaScript Source File Inclusion

Description

The page at the following URL includes one or more script files from a third-party domain
URL
https://och.berkeley.edu/auth/forgot-auth/username/ZAP
Parameter
//ajax.googleapis.com/ajax/libs/jquery/1.11.1/jquery.min.js
Evidence
//ajax.googleapis.com/ajax/libs/jquery/1.11.1/jquery.min.js

Solution

Ensure JavaScript source files are loaded from only trusted sources, and the sources can't be controlled by end users of the application

Reference

Low (Medium)Cross-Domain JavaScript Source File Inclusion

Description

The page at the following URL includes one or more script files from a third-party domain
URL
https://och.berkeley.edu/auth/forgot-auth/username/ZAP
Parameter
//translate.google.com/translate_a/element.js?cb=googleTranslateElementInit
Evidence
//translate.google.com/translate_a/element.js?cb=googleTranslateElementInit

Solution

Ensure JavaScript source files are loaded from only trusted sources, and the sources can't be controlled by end users of the application

Reference

Low (Medium)Web Browser XSS Protection Not Enabled

Description

Web Browser XSS Protection is not enabled, or is disabled by the configuration of the 'X-XSS-Protection' HTTP response header on the web server
URL
https://och.berkeley.edu/auth/forgot-auth/username/ZAP
Other information
The X-XSS-Protection HTTP response header allows the web server to enable or disable the web browser's XSS protection mechanism. The following values would attempt to enable it: X-XSS-Protection: 1; mode=block X-XSS-Protection: 1; report=http://www.example.com/xss The following values would disable it: X-XSS-Protection: 0 The X-XSS-Protection HTTP response header is currently supported on Internet Explorer, Chrome and Safari (WebKit). Note that this alert is only raised if the response body could potentially contain an XSS payload (with a text-based content type, with a non-zero length).

Solution

Ensure that the web browser's XSS filter is enabled, by setting the X-XSS-Protection HTTP response header to '1'.

Reference

https://www.owasp.org/index.php/XSS_(Cross_Site_Scripting)_Prevention_Cheat_Sheet

https://blog.veracode.com/2014/03/guidelines-for-setting-security-headers/

CWE Id

933

WASC Id

14

Low (Medium)X-Content-Type-Options Header Missing

Description

The Anti-MIME-Sniffing header X-Content-Type-Options was not set to 'nosniff'. This allows older versions of Internet Explorer and Chrome to perform MIME-sniffing on the response body, potentially causing the response body to be interpreted and displayed as a content type other than the declared content type. Current (early 2014) and legacy versions of Firefox will use the declared content type (if one is set), rather than performing MIME-sniffing.
URL
https://och.berkeley.edu/auth/forgot-auth/username/ZAP
Other information
This issue still applies to error type pages (401, 403, 500, etc) as those pages are often still affected by injection issues, in which case there is still concern for browsers sniffing pages away from their actual content type.

Solution

Ensure that the application/web server sets the Content-Type header appropriately, and that it sets the X-Content-Type-Options header to 'nosniff' for all web pages.

If possible, ensure that the end user uses a standards-compliant and modern web browser that does not perform MIME-sniffing at all, or that can be directed by the web application/web server to not perform MIME-sniffing.

Reference

http://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/ie/gg622941%28v=vs.85%29.aspx

https://www.owasp.org/index.php/List_of_useful_HTTP_headers

WASC Id

15

Low (Medium)Incomplete or No Cache-control and Pragma HTTP Header Set

Description

The cache-control and pragma HTTP header have not been set properly or are missing allowing the browser and proxies to cache content.
URL
https://och.berkeley.edu/registration/property-manager?description=Property+Manager+Registration+Data&show_rental_license=0&step=2&type=1&unit_sel=1412
Evidence
no-store, no-cache, must-revalidate, post-check=0, pre-check=0

Solution

Whenever possible ensure the cache-control HTTP header is set with no-cache, no-store, must-revalidate, private; and that the pragma HTTP header is set with no-cache.

Reference

https://www.owasp.org/index.php/Session_Management_Cheat_Sheet#Web_Content_Caching

Low (Medium)Web Browser XSS Protection Not Enabled

Description

Web Browser XSS Protection is not enabled, or is disabled by the configuration of the 'X-XSS-Protection' HTTP response header on the web server
URL
https://och.berkeley.edu/registration/property-manager?description=Property+Manager+Registration+Data&show_rental_license=0&step=2&type=1&unit_sel=1412
Other information
The X-XSS-Protection HTTP response header allows the web server to enable or disable the web browser's XSS protection mechanism. The following values would attempt to enable it: X-XSS-Protection: 1; mode=block X-XSS-Protection: 1; report=http://www.example.com/xss The following values would disable it: X-XSS-Protection: 0 The X-XSS-Protection HTTP response header is currently supported on Internet Explorer, Chrome and Safari (WebKit). Note that this alert is only raised if the response body could potentially contain an XSS payload (with a text-based content type, with a non-zero length).

Solution

Ensure that the web browser's XSS filter is enabled, by setting the X-XSS-Protection HTTP response header to '1'.

Reference

https://www.owasp.org/index.php/XSS_(Cross_Site_Scripting)_Prevention_Cheat_Sheet

https://blog.veracode.com/2014/03/guidelines-for-setting-security-headers/

14

Low (Medium)X-Content-Type-Options Header Missing

Description

The Anti-MIME-Sniffing header X-Content-Type-Options was not set to 'nosniff'. This allows older versions of Internet Explorer and Chrome to perform MIME-sniffing on the response body, potentially causing the response body to be interpreted and displayed as a content type other than the declared content type. Current (early 2014) and legacy versions of Firefox will use the declared content type (if one is set), rather than performing MIME-sniffing.
URL
https://och.berkeley.edu/registration/property-manager?description=Property+Manager+Registration+Data&show_rental_license=0&step=2&type=1&unit_sel=1412
Other information
This issue still applies to error type pages (401, 403, 500, etc) as those pages are often still affected by injection issues, in which case there is still concern for browsers sniffing pages away from their actual content type.

Solution

Ensure that the application/web server sets the Content-Type header appropriately, and that it sets the X-Content-Type-Options header to 'nosniff' for all web pages.

If possible, ensure that the end user uses a standards-compliant and modern web browser that does not perform MIME-sniffing at all, or that can be directed by the web application/web server to not perform MIME-sniffing.

Reference

http://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/ie/gg622941%28v=vs.85%29.aspx

https://www.owasp.org/index.php/List_of_useful_HTTP_headers

https://och.berkeley.edu/auth/forgot-auth?from
Parameter
visid_incap_496857=EBmT1oh4T4qhvWjv8uS2hAfx1VYAAAAAQUIPAAAAAAAM77NLqh5WsDeibfVfToa4; expires=Wed, 01 Mar 2017 12:23:46 GMT; path=/; Domain=.berkeley.edu
Evidence
visid_incap_496857=EBmT1oh4T4qhvWjv8uS2hAfx1VYAAAAAQUIPAAAAAAAM77NLqh5WsDeibfVfToa4; expires=Wed, 01 Mar 2017 12:23:46 GMT; path=/; Domain=.berkeley.edu

Solution

Whenever a cookie contains sensitive information or is a session token, then it should always be passed using an encrypted tunnel. Ensure that the secure flag is set for cookies containing such sensitive information.

Reference

http://www.owasp.org/index.php/Testing_for_cookies_attributes_(OWASP-SM-002)

WASC Id

13

Low (Medium)Cookie set without secure flag

Description

A cookie has been set without the secure flag, which means that the cookie can be accessed via unencrypted connections.
URL
https://och.berkeley.edu/auth/forgot-auth?from
Parameter
incap_ses_124_496857=gipHb19aowiAFr9nPoq4AQfx1VYAAAAAcUBFyRzOA3RpY8TOyB5JCg==; path=/; Domain=.berkeley.edu
Evidence
incap_ses_124_496857=gipHb19aowiAFr9nPoq4AQfx1VYAAAAAcUBFyRzOA3RpY8TOyB5JCg==; path=/; Domain=.berkeley.edu

Solution

Whenever a cookie contains sensitive information or is a session token, then it should always be passed using an encrypted tunnel. Ensure that the secure flag is set for cookies containing such sensitive information.

Reference

http://www.owasp.org/index.php/Testing_for_cookies_attributes_(OWASP-SM-002)

WASC Id

13

Low (Medium)Cross-Domain JavaScript Source File Inclusion

Description

The page at the following URL includes one or more script files from a third-party domain
URL
https://och.berkeley.edu/auth/forgot-auth?from
Parameter
//ajax.googleapis.com/ajax/libs/jquery/1.11.1/jquery.min.js
Evidence
//ajax.googleapis.com/ajax/libs/jquery/1.11.1/jquery.min.js

Solution

Ensure JavaScript source files are loaded from only trusted sources, and the sources can't be controlled by end users of the application

Reference

Low (Medium)Cross-Domain JavaScript Source File Inclusion

Description

The page at the following URL includes one or more script files from a third-party domain
URL
https://och.berkeley.edu/auth/forgot-auth?from
Parameter
//translate.google.com/translate_a/element.js?cb=googleTranslateElementInit
Evidence
//translate.google.com/translate_a/element.js?cb=googleTranslateElementInit

Solution

Ensure JavaScript source files are loaded from only trusted sources, and the sources can't be controlled by end users of the application

Reference

Low (Medium)Web Browser XSS Protection Not Enabled

Description

Web Browser XSS Protection is not enabled, or is disabled by the configuration of the 'X-XSS-Protection' HTTP response header on the web server
URL
https://och.berkeley.edu/auth/forgot-auth?from
Other information
The X-XSS-Protection HTTP response header allows the web server to enable or disable the web browser's XSS protection mechanism. The following values would attempt to enable it: X-XSS-Protection: 1; mode=block X-XSS-Protection: 1; report=http://www.example.com/xss The following values would disable it: X-XSS-Protection: 0 The X-XSS-Protection HTTP response header is currently supported on Internet Explorer, Chrome and Safari (WebKit). Note that this alert is only raised if the response body could potentially contain an XSS payload (with a text-based content type, with a non-zero length).

Solution

Ensure that the web browser's XSS filter is enabled, by setting the X-XSS-Protection HTTP response header to '1'.

Reference

https://www.owasp.org/index.php/XSS_(Cross_Site_Scripting)_Prevention_Cheat_Sheet

https://blog.veracode.com/2014/03/guidelines-for-setting-security-headers/

CWE Id

933

WASC Id

14

Low (Medium)X-Content-Type-Options Header Missing

Description

The Anti-MIME-Sniffing header X-Content-Type-Options was not set to 'nosniff'. This allows older versions of Internet Explorer and Chrome to perform MIME-sniffing on the response body, potentially causing the response body to be interpreted and displayed as a content type other than the declared content type. Current (early 2014) and legacy versions of Firefox will use the declared content type (if one is set), rather than performing MIME-sniffing.
URL
https://och.berkeley.edu/auth/forgot-auth?from
Other information
This issue still applies to error type pages (401, 403, 500, etc) as those pages are often still affected by injection issues, in which case there is still concern for browsers sniffing pages away from their actual content type.

Solution

Ensure that the application/web server sets the Content-Type header appropriately, and that it sets the X-Content-Type-Options header to 'nosniff' for all web pages.

If possible, ensure that the end user uses a standards-compliant and modern web browser that does not perform MIME-sniffing at all, or that can be directed by the web application/web server to not perform MIME-sniffing.

Reference

http://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/ie/gg622941%28v=vs.85%29.aspx

https://www.owasp.org/index.php/List_of_useful_HTTP_headers

WASC Id

15

Low (Medium)Incomplete or No Cache-control and Pragma HTTP Header Set

Description

The cache-control and pragma HTTP header have not been set properly or are missing allowing the browser and proxies to cache content.
URL
https://och.berkeley.edu/help/category/individual-private-owner
Evidence
no-store, no-cache, must-revalidate, post-check=0, pre-check=0

Solution

Whenever possible ensure the cache-control HTTP header is set with no-cache, no-store, must-revalidate, private; and that the pragma HTTP header is set with no-cache.

Reference

https://www.owasp.org/index.php/Session_Management_Cheat_Sheet#Web_Content_Caching

CWE Id

525

Low (Medium)Cookie set without HttpOnly flag

Description

A cookie has been set without the HttpOnly flag, which means that the cookie can be accessed by JavaScript. If a malicious script can be run on this page then the cookie will be accessible and can be transmitted to another site. If this is a session cookie then session hijacking may be possible.
URL
https://och.berkeley.edu/help/category/individual-private-owner
Parameter
PHPSESSID=t99o1qls4pshp6em9vejimlrs0; path=/
Evidence
PHPSESSID=t99o1qls4pshp6em9vejimlrs0; path=/

Solution

Ensure that the HttpOnly flag is set for all cookies.

Reference

www.owasp.org/index.php/HttpOnly

WASC Id

13

Low (Medium)X-Content-Type-Options Header Missing

Description

The Anti-MIME-Sniffing header X-Content-Type-Options was not set to 'nosniff'. This allows older versions of Internet Explorer and Chrome to perform MIME-sniffing on the response body, potentially causing the response body to be interpreted and displayed as a content type other than the declared content type. Current (early 2014) and legacy versions of Firefox will use the declared content type (if one is set), rather than performing MIME-sniffing.
URL
https://och.berkeley.edu/help/category/individual-private-owner
Other information
This issue still applies to error type pages (401, 403, 500, etc) as those pages are often still affected by injection issues, in which case there is still concern for browsers sniffing pages away from their actual content type.

Solution

Ensure that the application/web server sets the Content-Type header appropriately, and that it sets the X-Content-Type-Options header to 'nosniff' for all web pages.

If possible, ensure that the end user uses a standards-compliant and modern web browser that does not perform MIME-sniffing at all, or that can be directed by the web application/web server to not perform MIME-sniffing.

Reference

http://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/ie/gg622941%28v=vs.85%29.aspx

https://www.owasp.org/index.php/List_of_useful_HTTP_headers

Low (Medium)Web Browser XSS Protection Not Enabled

Description

Web Browser XSS Protection is not enabled, or is disabled by the configuration of the 'X-XSS-Protection' HTTP response header on the web server
URL
https://och.berkeley.edu/help/category/individual-private-owner
Other information
The X-XSS-Protection HTTP response header allows the web server to enable or disable the web browser's XSS protection mechanism. The following values would attempt to enable it: X-XSS-Protection: 1; mode=block X-XSS-Protection: 1; report=http://www.example.com/xss The following values would disable it: X-XSS-Protection: 0 The X-XSS-Protection HTTP response header is currently supported on Internet Explorer, Chrome and Safari (WebKit). Note that this alert is only raised if the response body could potentially contain an XSS payload (with a text-based content type, with a non-zero length).

Solution

Ensure that the web browser's XSS filter is enabled, by setting the X-XSS-Protection HTTP response header to '1'.

Reference

https://www.owasp.org/index.php/XSS_(Cross_Site_Scripting)_Prevention_Cheat_Sheet

https://blog.veracode.com/2014/03/guidelines-for-setting-security-headers/

Low (Medium)Cookie set without secure flag

Description

A cookie has been set without the secure flag, which means that the cookie can be accessed via unencrypted connections.
URL
https://och.berkeley.edu/help/article/how-do-i-contact-a-listing
Parameter
PHPSESSID=l5rednfle2u3jqcs0jfoh37tv0; path=/
Evidence
PHPSESSID=l5rednfle2u3jqcs0jfoh37tv0; path=/

Solution

Whenever a cookie contains sensitive information or is a session token, then it should always be passed using an encrypted tunnel. Ensure that the secure flag is set for cookies containing such sensitive information.

Reference

http://www.owasp.org/index.php/Testing_for_cookies_attributes_(OWASP-SM-002)

WASC Id

13

Low (Medium)Cookie set without secure flag

Description

A cookie has been set without the secure flag, which means that the cookie can be accessed via unencrypted connections.
URL
https://och.berkeley.edu/help/article/how-do-i-contact-a-listing
Parameter
visid_incap_496857=yUqayL+vQxKlm9K9wPMzYAjx1VYAAAAAQUIPAAAAAAAv05gJLXQIEBtGResD5Wnj; expires=Wed, 01 Mar 2017 12:24:06 GMT; path=/; Domain=.berkeley.edu
Evidence
visid_incap_496857=yUqayL+vQxKlm9K9wPMzYAjx1VYAAAAAQUIPAAAAAAAv05gJLXQIEBtGResD5Wnj; expires=Wed, 01 Mar 2017 12:24:06 GMT; path=/; Domain=.berkeley.edu

Solution

Whenever a cookie contains sensitive information or is a session token, then it should always be passed using an encrypted tunnel. Ensure that the secure flag is set for cookies containing such sensitive information.

Reference

http://www.owasp.org/index.php/Testing_for_cookies_attributes_(OWASP-SM-002)

WASC Id

13

Low (Medium)Cookie set without secure flag

Description

A cookie has been set without the secure flag, which means that the cookie can be accessed via unencrypted connections.
URL
https://och.berkeley.edu/help/article/how-do-i-contact-a-listing
Parameter
incap_ses_124_496857=nqFnPoZ3BWfPGr9nPoq4AQjx1VYAAAAAZOx26i86Zak2+GYgW+YXiQ==; path=/; Domain=.berkeley.edu
Evidence
incap_ses_124_496857=nqFnPoZ3BWfPGr9nPoq4AQjx1VYAAAAAZOx26i86Zak2+GYgW+YXiQ==; path=/; Domain=.berkeley.edu

Solution

Whenever a cookie contains sensitive information or is a session token, then it should always be passed using an encrypted tunnel. Ensure that the secure flag is set for cookies containing such sensitive information.

Reference

http://www.owasp.org/index.php/Testing_for_cookies_attributes_(OWASP-SM-002)

WASC Id

13

Low (Medium)Cross-Domain JavaScript Source File Inclusion

Description

The page at the following URL includes one or more script files from a third-party domain
URL
https://och.berkeley.edu/help/article/how-do-i-contact-a-listing
Parameter
//ajax.googleapis.com/ajax/libs/jquery/1.11.1/jquery.min.js
Evidence
//ajax.googleapis.com/ajax/libs/jquery/1.11.1/jquery.min.js

Solution

Ensure JavaScript source files are loaded from only trusted sources, and the sources can't be controlled by end users of the application

Reference

Low (Medium)Cross-Domain JavaScript Source File Inclusion

Description

The page at the following URL includes one or more script files from a third-party domain
URL
https://och.berkeley.edu/help/article/how-do-i-contact-a-listing
Parameter
//translate.google.com/translate_a/element.js?cb=googleTranslateElementInit
Evidence
//translate.google.com/translate_a/element.js?cb=googleTranslateElementInit

Solution

Ensure JavaScript source files are loaded from only trusted sources, and the sources can't be controlled by end users of the application

Reference

Low (Medium)Web Browser XSS Protection Not Enabled

Description

Web Browser XSS Protection is not enabled, or is disabled by the configuration of the 'X-XSS-Protection' HTTP response header on the web server
URL
https://och.berkeley.edu/help/article/how-do-i-contact-a-listing
Other information
The X-XSS-Protection HTTP response header allows the web server to enable or disable the web browser's XSS protection mechanism. The following values would attempt to enable it: X-XSS-Protection: 1; mode=block X-XSS-Protection: 1; report=http://www.example.com/xss The following values would disable it: X-XSS-Protection: 0 The X-XSS-Protection HTTP response header is currently supported on Internet Explorer, Chrome and Safari (WebKit). Note that this alert is only raised if the response body could potentially contain an XSS payload (with a text-based content type, with a non-zero length).

Solution

Ensure that the web browser's XSS filter is enabled, by setting the X-XSS-Protection HTTP response header to '1'.

Reference

https://www.owasp.org/index.php/XSS_(Cross_Site_Scripting)_Prevention_Cheat_Sheet

https://blog.veracode.com/2014/03/guidelines-for-setting-security-headers/

CWE Id

933

WASC Id

14

Low (Medium)X-Content-Type-Options Header Missing

Description

The Anti-MIME-Sniffing header X-Content-Type-Options was not set to 'nosniff'. This allows older versions of Internet Explorer and Chrome to perform MIME-sniffing on the response body, potentially causing the response body to be interpreted and displayed as a content type other than the declared content type. Current (early 2014) and legacy versions of Firefox will use the declared content type (if one is set), rather than performing MIME-sniffing.
URL
https://och.berkeley.edu/help/article/how-do-i-contact-a-listing
Other information
This issue still applies to error type pages (401, 403, 500, etc) as those pages are often still affected by injection issues, in which case there is still concern for browsers sniffing pages away from their actual content type.

Solution

Ensure that the application/web server sets the Content-Type header appropriately, and that it sets the X-Content-Type-Options header to 'nosniff' for all web pages.

If possible, ensure that the end user uses a standards-compliant and modern web browser that does not perform MIME-sniffing at all, or that can be directed by the web application/web server to not perform MIME-sniffing.

Reference

http://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/ie/gg622941%28v=vs.85%29.aspx

https://www.owasp.org/index.php/List_of_useful_HTTP_headers

WASC Id

15

Low (Medium)Incomplete or No Cache-control and Pragma HTTP Header Set

Description

The cache-control and pragma HTTP header have not been set properly or are missing allowing the browser and proxies to cache content.
URL
https://och.berkeley.edu/help/article/how-do-i-find-roommates
Evidence
no-store, no-cache, must-revalidate, post-check=0, pre-check=0

Solution

Whenever possible ensure the cache-control HTTP header is set with no-cache, no-store, must-revalidate, private; and that the pragma HTTP header is set with no-cache.

Reference

https://www.owasp.org/index.php/Session_Management_Cheat_Sheet#Web_Content_Caching

CWE Id

525

Low (Medium)Cookie set without HttpOnly flag

Description

A cookie has been set without the HttpOnly flag, which means that the cookie can be accessed by JavaScript. If a malicious script can be run on this page then the cookie will be accessible and can be transmitted to another site. If this is a session cookie then session hijacking may be possible.
URL
https://och.berkeley.edu/help/article/how-do-i-find-roommates
Parameter
PHPSESSID=8h0kvr4mlu7augh837h7pkt1v7; path=/
Evidence
PHPSESSID=8h0kvr4mlu7augh837h7pkt1v7; path=/

Solution

Ensure that the HttpOnly flag is set for all cookies.

Reference

www.owasp.org/index.php/HttpOnly

WASC Id

Description

URL
https://och.berkeley.edu/help/article/how-do-i-find-roommates
Other information
The X-XSS-Protection HTTP response header allows the web server to enable or disable the web browser's XSS protection mechanism. The following values would attempt to enable it: X-XSS-Protection: 1; mode=block X-XSS-Protection: 1; report=http://www.example.com/xss The following values would disable it: X-XSS-Protection: 0 The X-XSS-Protection HTTP response header is currently supported on Internet Explorer, Chrome and Safari (WebKit). Note that this alert is only raised if the response body could potentially contain an XSS payload (with a text-based content type, with a non-zero length).

Solution

Ensure that the web browser's XSS filter is enabled, by setting the X-XSS-Protection HTTP response header to '1'.

Reference

https://www.owasp.org/index.php/XSS_(Cross_Site_Scripting)_Prevention_Cheat_Sheet

https://och.berkeley.edu/help/article/how-do-i-contact-a-potential-roommate
Parameter
visid_incap_496857=sMnBnV5oRtip3aOoqS+CdQnx1VYAAAAAQUIPAAAAAACmh/by5REGj0YSXs5DDeKO; expires=Wed, 01 Mar 2017 12:24:01 GMT; path=/; Domain=.berkeley.edu
Evidence
visid_incap_496857=sMnBnV5oRtip3aOoqS+CdQnx1VYAAAAAQUIPAAAAAACmh/by5REGj0YSXs5DDeKO; expires=Wed, 01 Mar 2017 12:24:01 GMT; path=/; Domain=.berkeley.edu

Solution

Ensure that the HttpOnly flag is set for all cookies.

Reference

www.owasp.org/index.php/HttpOnly

WASC Id

13

Low (Medium)Cookie set without HttpOnly flag

Description

A cookie has been set without the HttpOnly flag, which means that the cookie can be accessed by JavaScript. If a malicious script can be run on this page then the cookie will be accessible and can be transmitted to another site. If this is a session cookie then session hijacking may be possible.
URL
https://och.berkeley.edu/help/article/how-do-i-contact-a-potential-roommate
Parameter
incap_ses_124_496857=24vfWWrtnXjnHb9nPoq4AQnx1VYAAAAAkgdrABsIoUN6E3+ZFyZAVA==; path=/; Domain=.berkeley.edu
Evidence
incap_ses_124_496857=24vfWWrtnXjnHb9nPoq4AQnx1VYAAAAAkgdrABsIoUN6E3+ZFyZAVA==; path=/; Domain=.berkeley.edu

Solution

Ensure that the HttpOnly flag is set for all cookies.

Reference

www.owasp.org/index.php/HttpOnly

WASC Id

13

Low (Medium)Cookie set without secure flag

Description

A cookie has been set without the secure flag, which means that the cookie can be accessed via unencrypted connections.
URL
https://och.berkeley.edu/help/article/how-do-i-contact-a-potential-roommate
Parameter
PHPSESSID=7ekc572nor5o28etrcdg8su3o6; path=/
Evidence
PHPSESSID=7ekc572nor5o28etrcdg8su3o6; path=/

Solution

Whenever a cookie contains sensitive information or is a session token, then it should always be passed using an encrypted tunnel. Ensure that the secure flag is set for cookies containing such sensitive information.

Reference

http://www.owasp.org/index.php/Testing_for_cookies_attributes_(OWASP-SM-002)

WASC Id

13

Low (Medium)Cookie set without secure flag

Description

A cookie has been set without the secure flag, which means that the cookie can be accessed via unencrypted connections.
URL
https://och.berkeley.edu/help/article/how-do-i-contact-a-potential-roommate
Parameter
visid_incap_496857=sMnBnV5oRtip3aOoqS+CdQnx1VYAAAAAQUIPAAAAAACmh/by5REGj0YSXs5DDeKO; expires=Wed, 01 Mar 2017 12:24:01 GMT; path=/; Domain=.berkeley.edu
Evidence
visid_incap_496857=sMnBnV5oRtip3aOoqS+CdQnx1VYAAAAAQUIPAAAAAACmh/by5REGj0YSXs5DDeKO; expires=Wed, 01 Mar 2017 12:24:01 GMT; path=/; Domain=.berkeley.edu

http://www.owasp.org/index.php/Testing_for_cookies_attributes_(OWASP-SM-002)

WASC Id

13

Low (Medium)Cookie set without secure flag

Description

A cookie has been set without the secure flag, which means that the cookie can be accessed via unencrypted connections.
URL
https://och.berkeley.edu/help/article/how-do-i-contact-a-potential-roommate
Parameter
incap_ses_124_496857=24vfWWrtnXjnHb9nPoq4AQnx1VYAAAAAkgdrABsIoUN6E3+ZFyZAVA==; path=/; Domain=.berkeley.edu

http://www.owasp.org/index.php/Testing_for_cookies_attributes_(OWASP-SM-002)

WASC Id

13

Low (Medium)Cross-Domain JavaScript Source File Inclusion

Description

The page at the following URL includes one or more script files from a third-party domain
URL
https://och.berkeley.edu/help/article/how-do-i-contact-a-potential-roommate
Parameter
//ajax.googleapis.com/ajax/libs/jquery/1.11.1/jquery.min.js
Evidence
//ajax.googleapis.com/ajax/libs/jquery/1.11.1/jquery.min.js

Solution

Ensure JavaScript source files are loaded from only trusted sources, and the sources can't be controlled by end users of the application

Reference

Low (Medium)Cross-Domain JavaScript Source File Inclusion

Description

The page at the following URL includes one or more script files from a third-party domain
URL
https://och.berkeley.edu/help/article/how-do-i-contact-a-potential-roommate
Parameter
//translate.google.com/translate_a/element.js?cb=googleTranslateElementInit
Evidence
//translate.google.com/translate_a/element.js?cb=googleTranslateElementInit

Solution

Ensure JavaScript source files are loaded from only trusted sources, and the sources can't be controlled by end users of the application

Reference

Low (Medium)Web Browser XSS Protection Not Enabled

Description

Web Browser XSS Protection is not enabled, or is disabled by the configuration of the 'X-XSS-Protection' HTTP response header on the web server
URL
https://och.berkeley.edu/help/article/how-do-i-contact-a-potential-roommate
Other information
The X-XSS-Protection HTTP response header allows the web server to enable or disable the web browser's XSS protection mechanism. The following values would attempt to enable it: X-XSS-Protection: 1; mode=block X-XSS-Protection: 1; report=http://www.example.com/xss The following values would disable it: X-XSS-Protection: 0 The X-XSS-Protection HTTP response header is currently supported on Internet Explorer, Chrome and Safari (WebKit). Note that this alert is only raised if the response body could potentially contain an XSS payload (with a text-based content type, with a non-zero length).

Solution

Ensure that the web browser's XSS filter is enabled, by setting the X-XSS-Protection HTTP response header to '1'.

Reference

https://www.owasp.org/index.php/XSS_(Cross_Site_Scripting)_Prevention_Cheat_Sheet

https://blog.veracode.com/2014/03/guidelines-for-setting-security-headers/

CWE Id

933

WASC Id

14

Low (Medium)X-Content-Type-Options Header Missing

Description

The Anti-MIME-Sniffing header X-Content-Type-Options was not set to 'nosniff'. This allows older versions of Internet Explorer and Chrome to perform MIME-sniffing on the response body, potentially causing the response body to be interpreted and displayed as a content type other than the declared content type. Current (early 2014) and legacy versions of Firefox will use the declared content type (if one is set), rather than performing MIME-sniffing.
URL
https://och.berkeley.edu/help/article/how-do-i-contact-a-potential-roommate
Other information
This issue still applies to error type pages (401, 403, 500, etc) as those pages are often still affected by injection issues, in which case there is still concern for browsers sniffing pages away from their actual content type.

Solution

Ensure that the application/web server sets the Content-Type header appropriately, and that it sets the X-Content-Type-Options header to 'nosniff' for all web pages.

If possible, ensure that the end user uses a standards-compliant and modern web browser that does not perform MIME-sniffing at all, or that can be directed by the web application/web server to not perform MIME-sniffing.

Reference

http://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/ie/gg622941%28v=vs.85%29.aspx

https://www.owasp.org/index.php/List_of_useful_HTTP_headers

WASC Id

15

Low (Medium)Incomplete or No Cache-control and Pragma HTTP Header Set

Description

The cache-control and pragma HTTP header have not been set properly or are missing allowing the browser and proxies to cache content.
URL
https://och.berkeley.edu/help/article/creating-account
Evidence
no-store, no-cache, must-revalidate, post-check=0, pre-check=0

Solution

Whenever possible ensure the cache-control HTTP header is set with no-cache, no-store, must-revalidate, private; and that the pragma HTTP header is set with no-cache.

Reference

https://www.owasp.org/index.php/Session_Management_Cheat_Sheet#Web_Content_Caching

CWE Id

525

Low (Medium)Cookie set without HttpOnly flag

Description

A cookie has been set without the HttpOnly flag, which means that the cookie can be accessed by JavaScript. If a malicious script can be run on this page then the cookie will be accessible and can be transmitted to another site. If this is a session cookie then session hijacking may be possible.
URL
https://och.berkeley.edu/help/article/creating-account
Parameter
PHPSESSID=basp07pd8eqfvmlpb9ahvf2jo0; path=/
Evidence
PHPSESSID=basp07pd8eqfvmlpb9ahvf2jo0; path=/

Solution

Ensure that the HttpOnly flag is set for all cookies.

Reference

www.owasp.org/index.php/HttpOnly
